SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

The Australian Government recently looked at the legal position of companies incorporated abroad which do business in Australia, whether through a branch, local subsidiary or otherwise. One finding was that an Australian court may be called upon to make a decision on a dispute involving such companies by referring to foreign laws, and may well find itself in a situation where it has to choose between conflicting laws of two or more foreign jurisdictions. For example, the court may have to address such questions as the validity of the incorporation of a foreign company, the ownership of shares of such a company or, more generally, the rights and obligations of a foreign company.

2. As a result of the examination, the Government concluded that in some circumstances there were no clear and predictable statutory rules which would overcome the uncertainties relating to claims of corporations of unrecognised states and governments.

3. It is the policy of the Australian Government to encourage foreign investment which it judges to be in the national interest. The Government wishes to ensure that investors can make important decisions in the confidence that their legal rights in Australia will not be adversely affected by extraneous considerations such as the legal status of the territory in which their business is incorporated.

4. The Australian legal system clearly meets this objective in most cases and obviously provides impartial legal services of high quality. However, it has become apparent that the traditional common law approach to the position of foreign corporations under Australian law may not, in some cases, adequately take account of the changes in the international trading system and foreign investment patterns in Australia.

5. Within Australia, there are now corporate entities from diverse political and legal systems and with various ownership arrangements. The sums involved in investment are often large and it is understandable that in such circumstances investors require certainty as to their legal status. In some countries, for example the United States, the courts have clarified the legal status of companies incorporated in unrecognised entities. However this is not the case in Australia and the approach an Australian court would take in dealing with a case involving the rights of foreign corporations from some parts of the world remains unclear.

6. This Bill seeks to address these issues. It deals in general terms with the situation where an Australian court has to determine the legal rights of a foreign corporation by reference to foreign law. Thus, when the ordinary rules of private international law require that rights of a foreign company be determined by reference to a foreign law, the Bill will ensure that the law to be applied will be determined by the place of incorporation of the company, without regard to the political circumstances, questions of official recognition or otherwise of the government authorities there, or the legal status of the place of incorporation.

7. The Bill's approach takes into account the Government's change in recognition policy announced by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on 19 January 1988. Under that policy, Australia no longer takes a position on the recognition or non-recognition of particular governments. Australia recognises states only.

8. The government considers that it would now be appropriate to provide for protection of the legal rights of companies incorporated in unrecognised entities. Australian courts, when confronted with cases in which foreign relations questions are raised, traditionally have attached considerable importance to the attitude of the executive government. The Australian Government's view is that as a matter of public policy, the foreign relations considerations should not normally be the overriding factor in the determination of private legal rights, particularly those involving commercial transactions. The Government considers that Australia's public policy interests can be preserved on the one hand, while on the other hand normal commercial relations between private parties can be determined by reference, where relevant, to the law in fact in operation in the place of incorporation.

9. There is no financial cost to the Commonwealth. I note however that passage of the Bill is likely to attract additional foreign investment into Australia. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 December 1989.
Clause 81. Scrutiny of votes in House of Representatives elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions to direct to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) about clause 81. Clause 81 deals with a number of matters arising in relation to section 274 of the principal Act and relates primarily to the issue of the resolving of deadlocks, for example, in those odd cases-theoretical cases, almost-where there is an equality of votes. I cannot recall any situation where there has been an equality of votes at the end of a count. I think the closest I can recall was in New South Wales in, I think, the 1962 State election where in the seat of Lismore the thing was eventually decided by two votes. The Minister undoubtedly has some better recollection of precise circumstances where these things need to be addressed. Subclause (k), in relation to new subclause 274 (9), which appears on page 50 of the Bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: If, on any count, 2 or more candidates have an equal number of votes and one of them has to be excluded, the Divisional Returning Officer shall decide which of them shall be excluded.
Can the Minister tell me by what method the returning officer is to decide which of them is to be excluded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that it is specified, other than by reading other sections of the Act. I would think that it would be done by lot. Senator Puplick might leave that with me while I chase it up. This whole section came out of the Nunawading election in which 116,000 votes were cast and at the end of the day the vote was deadlocked. The returning officer decided to do a draw out of a ballot box to determine the winner. That drew criticism at the time because a lot of us thought that the whole exercise was pointless. When there is a drawn election there is no way a court of disputed returns will not find one vote missing and overturn it. One of the recommendations is that when there is equality of votes-in terms of the final two candidates-it will go straight to a court of disputed returns in any event, and save everyone a bit of money.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to how candidates are eliminated, in my experience it has always been done by a draw from a ballot box. I may have to take that question on notice. At some stage that particular practice may need a more specific reference in the Act, and I think that it would be the will of the Parliament anyway. I suppose it could be taken in two ways. If we are talking about candidates getting primary votes and drawing having to be eliminated, I think that it would have to be done by lot. If we are talking about further down the count after some preferences have been distributed, I think that it should be the person who had the greatest number of primary votes. I will take that on board and pray that it will not happen at the next election. Even if it does, it may well be the ruling of the Electoral Commissioner-having listened to the debate between Senator Puplick and me today-that that will be the procedure. I am sure that it can be done by way of regulation, or a direction that that course be followed even if it is not covered or we cannot find it in the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely the point I wanted to make in the course of the debate. There have been essentially three ways in which deadlocks have been broken. One has been by simply drawing from a barrel. It is often a matter of curiosity, depending on which system one uses. For example, in my own political party, when it comes to preselections the name is drawn out of a hat and the person whose name is drawn out is the one who loses. Under our method of doing it, the person whose name remains in the hat is the successful candidate. But essentially there are three methods. It can be done by lot or by the casting vote of a prescribed divisional returning officer. Proposed subsection (13) provides that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Divisional Returning Officer for a Division shall not vote in a House of Representatives election . . .

That mirrors part of the old subsection (9) of section 274. There is a direction which says that where there is equality of votes at a stage which is subsequent to the count of the first preference votes-in other words, where the tie has resulted after preferences have been allocated between candidates the candidate who is eliminated should be the candidate who received fewer primary votes. I think that, in fact, is a fair and proper way of going about things. I specifically asked the Minister about it because I think that if we have an equality of votes after the second, third, fourth, fifteenth distribution of preferences a prejudice should lie in favour of the candidate who polled the greater number of primary votes. I think it would perhaps have been better that the thing should have been specified in the legislation; if it is not it may well be that by direction and by regulation that rule can be put in place. It is our view that that is the proper way to go when the tie has resulted from a situation of counting the votes after the stage of counting purely the primary votes. I just wanted to put that on the record.

The second thing in relation to clause 81 is, in fact, that matter of the disqualification of the divisional returning officer from voting at any stage during the course of these counts. The current section 274 subsection (9) provides that the divisional returning officer shall have a casting vote. It provides that he shall not have a deliberate vote, but he shall have a casting vote. The section says, in part:

. . . and if, in the final count, 2 candidates have an equal number of votes, the Divisional Returning Officer shall decide by his casting vote which shall be elected, but, except as provided in this sub-section, he shall not vote at the election.

I just wanted to establish that it is the Government's intention in this legislation that, in fact, divisional returning officers around Australia will now, by this Act, in fact be precluded by statute from casting any vote, their own personal vote, at any stage in the determination of the outcome of a House of Representatives or a Senate election. I believe that is the consequence of passing this but I just want the Minister to confirm that, in fact, it is the intention of the Government by this new subsection (13) to provide that its own divisional returning officers are by statute disenfranchised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 81, proposed subsection (13), implies that only one type of divisional returning officer is disqualified; those who live in that particular division would be disqualified from voting. That is how I read that. My own experience is that, apart from in country areas-and that is something we might have to look at in the long term-very rarely do divisional returning officers live in their divisions. I have virtually never struck it; they always seem to live on the other side of the city and that is why we cannot get to the postal votes until 9.30 instead of 9.00, but that is another story. That is how I would read that-that they cannot vote in the division in which they live.
—So they can't vote in the division in which they are the DRO?
—That is right.
—Not in the division in which they live?
—If the two things combine, that would be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 82 to 93-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 58, clause 93, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
``(2) Section 297 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following subsection:

`(2) A payment under this Division is not to be made in respect of votes given in an election for a candidate or a group unless there is laid before each House of the Parliament, or if a House is not sitting, there is delivered to the Presiding Officer of that House, or in his or her absence, the Deputy Presiding Officer, for laying before that House on the next day of sitting, a statement by the Electoral Commissioner, in the prescribed form, that, in respect of the candidate or the group, the Electoral Commissioner is satisfied that there has been full disclosure of gifts for the purpose of section 304 of this Act.'.''.
(2) Page 60, paragraph 95 (fig. 1) (c), lines 30 and 31, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(c) by omitting subsections (5), (6), (7) and (8).''.
(3) Page 110, Schedule 2, leave out the proposed amendment to subparagraph 304 (5) (b) (i).

The aim of these amendments is to require that all donations made to political parties be made public. That has been our Party's policy since inception, and we believe that, following the implementation of half of that policy over the last couple of elections-that is, that donations provided to political parties for election purposes have been made public-there is a very strong reason now, in the light of quite a number of matters that have gone on, for all donations to be made public. Indeed, this particular idea received very strong support from the outgoing Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes, when on his last day of office he made the statement that the necessity for full disclosure had been demonstrated in the Queensland Fitzgerald inquiry and in the hearings of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption.

The proposition for full disclosure, I think, has quite some considerable support. For example, in the lead-up to the Queensland State election the leader of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Ash Forward-probably those who know him would hardly describe him as a radical-spoke about the importance of this particular issue. He said this:
I think the Fitzgerald inquiry showed that the National Party had clearly got donations for favours.

He said that all donations to political parties, including compulsory union levies which went to the Labor Party, should be identified by law, otherwise `it leads to all sorts of corruption and problems'. So I think there is a range of reasons as to why one would want to move to this next step.

The problems that we are facing I think are simply going to increase over time. In fact, the former senior counsel for the Fitzgerald inquiry, Mr Gary Crooke, QC, is quoted in the Age on 15 November as saying that governments should revise their methods of collecting political donations if they are serious about fighting corruption. He told the Fourth International Anti-Corruption Conference that the area of political donations was ripe for abuse, and it was too easy to camouflage donations that would result in corrupt influence. I quote from the paper he gave, when he said:
The very procedure of political donations does create a climate and a platform that, unless controlled, can be very much open to abuse.

In fact, there have been some recent current affairs programs-Four Corners is one that I would refer to-which can show how in fact political parties are able to move around the current disclosure provisions. So we have this climate operating, and I think that we have now seen in the electorate a very marked and very strong reaction to the exposure of political corruption in Queensland. It is not something that members of the community are willing to put up with. They want the game cleaned up and I think they want to be sure that those who are elected to office are elected in an honest and open contest.

The arguments we have had previously in this place about the ability to keep secret donations that go to political parties in some form or another have been convincingly lost within the community-and I think for a very good reason. The community is willing to override in this case what might be seen as a principle-that if one gives a donation to somebody or other, one should not have to tell anybody about it-for the specific reason that we are dealing with the fundamental structure of government and with something which is of vital interest to every member of the community. In doing so they want to have it out in the open, above board and without any strings attached to the exercises that go on.

The amendment, cast in the way that I have sought, would require that under this division a payment-that is, a public funding payment-would not be made until the Electoral Commissioner was satisfied that there had been a full disclosure of gifts. I have adopted this method because there are obvious problems in the way that political parties organise themselves in the States. For example, some quite strict laws have been introduced into the New South Wales Parliament. The New South Wales Parliament made laws with regard to the disclosure of donations. Those donations were sent to the Australian Capital Territory, which is outside the legislative jurisdiction of the New South Wales Parliament, and were then funnelled back in. I think that that demonstrates that there is a willingness on the part of political parties to avoid those types of pressures on them and to come clean about their political donations.

What I have sought to do is impose a penalty if there is not full disclosure of all donations made to political parties, and that includes moneys which circulate around at the State level, so that State political parties, or constituent bodies within political parties that are fighting Federal elections, cannot simply take out money and pop it into those accounts, thereby avoiding the normal Federal jurisdiction, and then funnel them back in in some other way. If the Commissioner is not satisfied that there has been a complete disclosure of gifts, a penalty will be imposed. The penalty can be quite high regarding public funding. But I do not believe that the community would wish to engage in the public funding of a political party that had not fully disclosed all the donations that it had received in any account.

Essentially, we are trying to avoid the brown paper bag syndrome set in place in Queensland, that disrupted so much of political and commercial life in that State for so long. I believe that one of the factors at the Federal level that has been really something of a grace-and probably one cannot find too many of them-is the absence of corruption at the Federal level, in fact, probably for the whole of Federation. However, that has to be under pressure simply because of the enormous amounts of money that are now necessary to run a modern political party and a modern campaign in our society. I think that we have an obligation to make it very clear and to be very open with the public about what goes on so that not only is justice done in this regard but also that it is seen to be done so that political parties running for office can say to the electorate that there is nothing hidden, there are no donations slipping around the back way, and that everything is up-front and out in the open. I think that in those circumstances the public will have much more confidence in the political process which I think all honourable senators wish would occur. For that reason I have moved the three amendments, which would require the disclosure of all gifts received by political parties and impose a penalty of not receiving public funding until such disclosures had been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting these amendments at this time. We find problems with them-not in principle, as Senator Macklin will be well aware-but in terms of the practicality of application, as he has expressed it, in the Act and with the timing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go to the basic issue. I believe, as Senator Macklin has said, that there can be problems with donations. That was one of the reasons I supported public funding: to try to relieve political parties of their reliance on private finance. Unfortunately, the cost of campaigning has well and truly outstripped any thought of that theory working. We have had problems. The Labor Party had problems with a donation from Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Ltd which resulted in one of our key members being fined $50 or something.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not going to prevent him coming into the Senate.

—Senator, in all fairness, we also have to note what the magistrate said, because this particular person was tried, hanged and quartered-the whole lot-before his case came up. The magistrate said that he was not basically at fault other than through inadvertence. Senator Stone would be very interested in this other case. Why does he not go to the Northern Territory and look at Carpentaria Pty Ltd? We are talking not about ten grand here but about $394,000 being donated to his Party up there through a shelf company which has--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties combine up there into the Country-Liberal Party (CLP). It was certainly the CLP when the first $280,000 donation came through from a non-trading $2 shelf company. It was only through a degree of legal expertise that they have snuck through and not been convicted.
—Is this like the activities of the Vice-President of the Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Goodhew, who has been reported in yesterday's press?
—No, Senator, that is a separate matter. That is an industrial matter to do with the deregistration of unions.
—But we don't know where the funds went or what they were used for, do we!

—Let me draw the honourable senator's attention to his colleagues receiving $125,000 from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd before the last election. It has never been denied. No-one has jumped to his feet and said, `Hey, we did not get $125,000'. Where is it, Senator Stone? It has not been declared yet. Where is it?

SPEECH.PARA: When those provisions were put into the Act in 1983 and 1984-and I suggest honourable senators read the Hansard-no-one said that they would cleanse the whole system. Senator Macklin and I are probably on record-I know that I am and I think Senator Macklin is too-as saying that they would have no more than moral sanction, would address the issue around the edges, but were not part of a comprehensive Act of Parliament to enforce total declaration. Nor did we ever say it would be totally effective-and nor has it been. It has been less effective than one would have wanted. We have page after page here which can be slipped through so easily. Imagine how easy it is going to be to slip through Senator Macklin's amendments, which do not come to more than about 40 sentences. We have always had that constitutional problem of forcing State branches, for State electoral purposes, to declare donations. What power do we have in relation to the declaration of donations towards municipal campaigns?

I just wonder how any party is going to get public funding under Senator Macklin's particular proposal. I mean, there are so many different unions! His Party might have only five or six branches in the State of Victoria that have to be audited-I do not know. We are not the biggest Party in history in Victoria, but we have 38 Federal accounts; 88 State accounts; several upper House accounts; 300 or 400 branch accounts-and on it goes. I believe that, after the next election, given the report on advertising et cetera, this whole issue is going to be addressed. I do not think it can be addressed two to six months out from an election. I do not think it can be addressed in the way Senator Macklin seeks to amend the Act, although I must acknowledge that the basic principle of the approach that he has taken-that is, donations do not have to be declared but, then again, one does not have to take any public funding-is the necessary lever. That is right in concept, I think; that is the only way we can do it.

I suggest to Senator Macklin that he would need a far more extensive amendment of the Act to make this effective, to do it two to six months out from an election. There would need to be other trade-offs, otherwise a lot more donations may dry up and, therefore, the ratio we determine between donations and public funding would no longer apply. There would be all these sorts of problems with these suggested amendments on disclosure. The Government cannot support them this time, but puts everyone on notice. Long term, in principle we agree with total disclosure and total auditing of political parties. That is our belief-into the open. We will get applauded by newspaper reporters and newspaper owners for that. I would like to see their books opened up, too, before they get too cheeky on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be supporting the Democrat amendment. While I agree with some of the points that Senator Ray has made in relation to the question of practicalities, I put on record the continuing opposition of the Liberal and National parties to the whole system of public funding, to the attendant provisions in the Electoral Act and to the various regulations which are necessary to give effect to that. I would not want it to be assumed that, simply because Senator Ray and I take the same view in opposing the Democrat amendment, we do so on precisely the same grounds.
—Thank you.

—Senator Ray and I have a quite fundamental difference of opinion about the question of public funding and, as a result, about the nature of disclosure, and the proper responsibilities and the proper degree of scrutiny which should apply to private organisations such as the political parties in Australia. Our objection, therefore, to Senator Macklin's amendment is not only because of the technical and practical difficulties to which the Minister has made reference, but also because we object fundamentally to the system which Senator Macklin's amendment is seeking to expand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The best arguments to the proposition I was advancing were in the banter across the chamber between Senator Stone and Senator Ray. They were able, on their feet, to swap instances which had occurred in one another's parties, straight off the top of their heads. If they are able to do so, what does the public think about this matter? Obviously, the public is sick and tired of it and wants it cleaned up. I urge that we clean it up now, before the next election. The time to do it is now, when there is strong public support for this proposition. That has been demonstrated in the Queensland election in an overwhelming way.

SPEECH.PARA: People do not want corruption in politics. We have to show that there is none. I am no saying that there is, necessarily. I have said that at the Federal level an excellent level of propriety is displayed by all political parties. I am not confident that that will continue under the types of pressures that Senator Ray referred to, such as the costs of advertising and the need to bring in vast sums of money. Millions of dollars are needed to finance an election. I urge that we move now, before the next election, to cut off opportunities for people who may be tempted to sell favours for money so that they can lever themselves into government.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 94 and 95-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 96 (Expenditure incurred for political purposes).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the Opposition opposes clause 96 and will be voting against it. This is a clause which further deals with some of these matters in relation to donations to political parties. As you would know, Mr Chairman, the next piece of legislation which we are to debate in this chamber once we have got past the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill is a Bill about privacy. This is a new section to go into the Act which, in fact, once again tramples upon the privacy of individuals who wish to participate in the political process. It provides that in relation to a gift certain things must be made public. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the case of a gift made on behalf of the members of an unincorporated association-
we have to have supplied, in a public fashion-
(a) the name of the association; and
(b) the names and addresses of the members of the executive committee (however described) of the association;

Here, in fact, is an amendment to electoral law which says in relation to the disclosure of gifts that all of the names and addresses of the members of an executive committee, however described-in other words, whether it is an executive committee, a management committee, a board, whatever terminology is used-are to be made public. It is proposed that section 305 of the principal Act be amended by deleting the current paragraph 3 (b). The current paragraph 3 (b) of the existing Act states:

The reference to the relevant details, in relation to a gift, shall be read as a reference to the amount or value of the gift, the date on which the gift was made and the name and address of the person who made the gift.

The new provision goes beyond the question of the person who made the gift, who in many cases in relation to an incorporated association would be some sort of chief executive officer-a secretary, a treasurer or a president. He or she would be the person who made the gift. The gift would be disclosed under the existing Act in relation to the amount or value of the gift, the date on which the gift was made and the name and the address of the person who made the gift. Now it will not be just the person who gave the gift and who is the responsible officer who will be identified by name and address. The names and addresses of all of the members of the executive committee however described are to be placed on some sort of public register.

I do not know the extent to which there has been, in terms of practical experience, any difficulty in establishing the nature of the gift, the value of the gift, the date on which the gift has been made or in identifying the source of that gift by identifying the particular individual who has been responsible or who, under the Electoral Act, is held responsible for having given that donation. We have not had donations which in that sense have been untraceable, which have been inadequately specified in relation to the name and address of the person responsible for making the gift. But now every single member of the executive committee, or whatever term is to be used, of an unincorporated association is to have his or her name and address entered on a public register. So in other words, if one wishes to find out the names and personal addresses of all the people who are on the executive committee of an unincorporated association which has made a donation to a political party, which comes within the ambit of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, that will have to be disclosed.

I cannot for the life of me see what is added to, in terms of the public knowledge which proponents of the public funding system find attractive, by splashing the personal names and addresses of all of the members of the executive committee across the public record, their addresses in particular. Why should people have access to that sort of information? Why should the personal addresses of people who are on the executive committees of unincorporated associations that make donations to political parties be a matter of public record? What happens, for example, if there are persons who quite legitimately are on the electoral roll but who have their addresses specifically excluded from the electoral roll because that is the security requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let them give the address of the association.

—Because that is the security requirement? That interjection is indicative of what a farcical sort of extension this is-`Let them give a post-office box. Let them give a holiday home in another State'. What is actually advanced by requiring that these names and addresses be made? I know what the answer to that is. We all know what the answer to that is. It is typical of the ongoing, intrusive invasion of personal privacy which has been a hallmark and feature of government in this country for the last 6 1/2 years and which has been a hallmark of the use of the Electoral Act for quite bogus purposes to intrude upon the personal rights, the personal privacy and the personal affairs of individuals in this country. It is absolutely disgraceful that we are using the Commonwealth Electoral Act to further invade the privacy of individuals for what I see as no good purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: What is wanted by those who believe in this system of disclosure is information regarding what money or gift was given, what its value was, when it was given, to whom it was given and by which organisation it was given. That is already provided for in the Act, in existing section 305 (2) (b), which is now being repealed in order to make these names and addresses even more publicly available. The Opposition does not believe that there is any justification whatsoever for this further invasion of privacy being undertaken under the guise of amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Sections 304 and 305 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act require disclosure of relevant details of each gift above the disclosable level. That disclosable level is $1,000 or more for a gift to a political party, Senate group or third party-a third party being an individual or organisation not directly seeking election but participating in an election campaign-or, on the other hand, a $200 or more gift to a candidate. Relevant details include the name and address of the person who made the gift. Under section 306 it is unlawful to receive a gift of $1,000 or more, or in the case of a candidate $200 or more, unless the name and address of the person making the gift are made known. An unlawful gift has to be forfeited to the Crown; in other words, any anonymous donation above that level-even if it is made up of four or five different units that come to that level-must be forfeited to the Crown.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Electoral Commission sought legal advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions as to whether an unincorporated association was a person under the disclosure provisions. The request was made in relation to a gift to a political party under section 304 but the advice provided is also relevant to sections 305 and 306. The Director of Public Prosecutions advised as follows:
. . . it is my view that an unincorporated association, which is not a legal entity, cannot be a `person' for the purposes of that provision.

An unincorporated association is in the eyes of the law no more than the aggregate of its individual members. If a gift is made to a political party by an unincorporated association, the gift is made jointly by members of the association. Compliance with section 304 (4) probably requires that when a gift is made by an unincorporated association the name and address of each member of that association must be disclosed.

He further indicated that it would be difficult, and may in some cases be impossible, for a political party to provide the name and address of every member of an unincorporated association which has made a gift to it. He pointed out:

The membership of unincorporated associations is often large and fluctuating and it may be difficult to determine whether a particular individual is a member at any given time. The cost to a political party of identifying and naming all members of an unincorporated association may exceed the value of the gift . . .

Strict enforcement of section 304 (4), and section 306 dealing with anonymous gifts, could have the practical effect of preventing political parties from accepting gifts from unincorporated associations . . .

So there is the view of the Director of Public Prosecutions. It was on this basis that the Commission, therefore, decided to accept disclosure of names and addresses of the members of the managing body as the source of the gift by the association. Since the present provisions of the Act have led people into the error of thinking that they are complying with the legislation by naming an unincorporated association as a donor of a gift, the Commission raised this matter with the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The Joint Select Committee recommended that an Act be amended so that in respect of a gift by an unincorporated association it specifies that disclosure is required of the name of the unincorporated association and the names and addresses of the members of the managing body, however described. I think it was in his speech at the second reading stage that Senator Puplick criticised this particular section. Senator Puplick has put his own views today.

I will just go through the issues that I think are raised. Companies which are incorporated are persons. The disclosure requirements in relation to corporations are unchanged. Only the name and address of a donor corporation are required to be disclosed. Trade unions which are federally or State registered have a status which is effectively corporate status and therefore are persons for the purposes of disclosure. Only the name and address of a donor union are required to be disclosed. For unincorporated companies and unions which are not registered federally or under State industrial legislation the disclosure requirements are less intrusive under the proposed amendment which requires disclosure of names and addresses of members of executive committees, however described, than under the current legislation which requires disclosure of the names and addresses of every member of the association.

In summary, Senator Puplick has made a philosophical assessment of how intrusive into privacy this Government is; I do not accept that. Listening to him, one would be led to understand there is almost some conspiracy in which a set of Stalinists have decided to intrude themselves into society as much as possible. I do not really think Senator Puplick believes that. But just on that question of privacy, by deleting this section the Opposition would be broadening the scope for any intrusion that is necessary, because the Electoral Commission, on the advice of the Director of Public Prosecutions, is going to have to insist that the name and address of every member of the organisation be disclosed, otherwise the donation will be returned. That is the effect of opposing this clause.

The effect of this clause is that only the executive of the association or unincorporated body need have the names and addresses. That is not an ideal thing from Senator Puplick's point of view because I guess what he would really like to do is just remove the whole thing holus-bolus, but that is not the choice now before the Senate. The choice is the degree of intrusion, and this represents much less intrusion into the process than that which would occur if the Act were left unamended or unchanged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I was going to make a very similar point to the one that Senator Ray ended up on, and that is that if we accepted the Opposition's amendment we would have to have everybody's name and everybody's address. If Senator Puplick is concerned about that, as he seemed to be in his speech, it is very odd that he is moving this particular amendment because the provision in the amending legislation at least corrals it to the executive committee. The acceptance of his amendment would in fact require-and I am quite sure that the Commission would have to work on the advice given by the Director of Public Prosecutions-extension of the requirement to all members. I remember discussing this matter. It certainly seemed to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that the simplest way was in fact to deal with the executives. This is normally the case with regard to unincorporated associations. So we believe that it is sufficient that members of the executive be identified. We do not agree with Senator Puplick that every member of the organisation should be identified. This is a workable mechanism to deal with the problem that has arisen. I think Senator Puplick's proposition takes it back into that area which quite frankly is unworkable because of the fluctuating and almost indefinite nature of most unincorporated associations.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As I understood it-and perhaps the Minister could enlighten me-the addresses referred to in that clause are not necessarily the private addresses of individuals. Could the Minister explain to the Committee the interpretation of the word `addresses' contained in that clause? I assumed that it would refer to the official addresses of those individuals which, of course, could be the company office in each case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I think the best definition of it would be the address at which a summons could be served, not a post office box. In other words, I think one could put one's private address, one's business address but not `post office box so and so'. I think that is essentially the way it would be approached, on the basis of the address one would normally give at which a summons could be served.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 97 to 109-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 65, after clause 109, insert the following new clause:
Misleading or deceptive publications etc
``109A. Section 329 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsection:
`(2) A person shall not, during the relevant period in relation to an election under this Act, authorise to be printed, published or distributed, any electoral matter containing a statement:
(a) that is untrue; and
(b) that is, or is likely to be, misleading or deceptive.'; and
(b) by inserting `, (2)' after `sub-section (1)' in subsection (4).''.
(6) Page 68, after clause 117, insert the following new clause:
Injunctions
``117a. Section 383 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by inserting after `Act' in subsection (1) `(other than subsection 329 (2))'; and
(b) by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsection:

`(1a) Where a person has engaged, is engaging or is proposing to engage in any conduct that constituted, constitutes or would constitute a contravention of subsection 329 (2) of this Act, a prescribed court may, on the application of the Electoral Commission, grant an injunction restraining the person from engaging in the conduct and, if in the opinion of the court it is desirable to do so, requiring that person to do any act or thing.'.''.

I have moved the first of these amendments on previous occasions, as the Committee will be aware. It is an endeavour to institute the first step only in bringing political advertising into line with all other advertising. It is modelled on the Trade Practices Act. The difficulties that have been raised in the past have been taken on board. It does not seek to solve anything-I acknowledge that-but it does seek to make a first step with regard to this matter. The amendment states:
. . . any electoral matter containing a statement:
(a) that is untrue; and
(b) that is, or is likely to be, misleading or deceptive.'; and . . .

They are essentially the two provisions in the Trade Practices Act that apply to any commercial advertiser seeking to advertise his or her product in the Australian community. I readily acknowledge that this does not include those statements which could be either true or false. For example, it cannot cover statements of future activities; statements about what somebody will do in the future. They are not statements of truth and hence are not caught up under this definition. This refers only to those statements which have a truth value in that very strict sense. Basically, it refers to statements from the past and statements in print or in writing. For example, it would refer to a statement like: `The Australian Labor Party's policy is such and such'. If that quotation were incorrect, untrue or if it were done in such a way as to be misleading or deceptive, it would be caught up under this provision.

So this is an attempt to take away what a lot of people in the community, quite rightly, have seen as a licence on the part of politicians to be able to lie and yet an obligation imposed on ordinary advertisers, ordinary people operating in the community, by politicians not to do so-in other words, a double standard. We have passed a law through this place imposing that obligation and yet we have refused to submit-even in a small way, such as is contained in my amendments-to that restriction.

It is a restriction that extends to a very limited range of statements but it would be the first step to solving a problem that has been raised many times in the past: that we are happy to impose on others restrictions that we are not happy to take on ourselves. If this Parliament believes that it is important for somebody advertising soap to tell the truth, when a political party makes a statement about the printed policy of another political party it ought to be obliged to tell the truth.

I find it very difficult to understand how we can say to small and large businesses out there, `You tell the truth about your products when you advertise. However, we don't have to. You are dealing with soap. We are dealing with governing the community and putting in place laws. We do not have to abide by those strictures'. I do not think that is acceptable. I do not think that anyone believes, or would seriously want to argue, that that is acceptable. This amendment is framed, firstly, to catch only those statements which have a truth value. As honourable senators would know, that is a limited range of statements. Secondly, it is framed to catch what is or is likely to be misleading or deceptive. In other words, it is a double whammy. It is not just trying to pick up something inadvertent or even something which may be untrue but which is not likely to be deceptive. It is a double whammy exercise based on the Trade Practices Act. I believe that it ought to apply to politicians, as it applies to everybody else in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is the third or fourth time we have debated this issue, and I will not take long. I refer everyone to my previous comments made in Hansard in 1983, 1984 and at whatever other time. I have a problem with the definition of `truth'-I always have had in terms of legislating for it. One does not need to have done too much historiography to understand the difficulty of establishing what a fact is or what a fact is not. As to whether a statement is truthful, that depends from which perspective you approach it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am even more opposed, of course, to the reliance on the Electoral Commission as the body that initiates injunctions. I acknowledge that each time Senator Macklin puts up his proposal it is slightly more refined and has fewer problems with it, but it does create immense problems for the Electoral Commission-a body that always seeks to play a neutral role in the election process, a democratic process. It would put inordinate pressure on the Commission. Finally, if carried here today, it would be a great boon to my enemies-the lawyers. They would lap up hundreds of thousands of dollars in injunctions and court cases et cetera. Political parties would be impoverished and the lawyers, as always, would come out on top. I think I had better finish before the Temporary Chairman sends me a sarcastic note!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that the Chairman's sarcastic note would go something to the effect:

SPEECH.PARA: What is truth? said jesting Pilate, and would not stay for an answer.

I suspect that is the basis of his sarcastic note. I endorse the general thrust of what Senator Ray has had to say. In terms of the definition of `truth', it is certainly possible that one would be able to state that the policy of a particular party is A, B and C; and it is testable, I guess, in some fashion as to whether that commitment actually appears in some written document or some printed document. If one then goes on to say, that, of course, the consequence of that is that the following will be the impact upon our lives, upon our country, upon the educational system, or whatever, the question of who is going to determine whether in fact that is true or untrue is really a matter to be left to the judgment of the electors.

Senator Ray is also correct in saying that the proposed new section 383, which would be inserted by the Democrats' amendment, imposes a very considerable burden on the Electoral Commission to make applications to the prescribed court, for the court then to start determining these matters for endless arguments in the court as to what is true and what is not true and whether in fact it is likely to be misleading or deceptive. It does seem to me that the judgment in these things is one which electors are capable of making and which they have traditionally been capable of making.

Senator Macklin basically says, `The electors are too dopey to know what is true and what is not true and therefore we need the Electoral Commission and a prescribed court and all of Senator Ray's friends in the legal profession to work out what is true and what is not true, what should be injunctive and what should be permitted'. That just seems to me to be so totally unworkable as to fail on the very face of it. The Opposition does not support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I just find the last comment absolutely extraordinary because in fact this Parliament has passed an Act imposing those particular words on the general business community and requiring the general business community to abide by them. What we are saying is, `You lot do that, we will do something else, thank you very much'. I do not think that the community is very happy to wear that type of thing any longer. The community is very much about cleaning up the political act in all types of areas. If we believe that it is worth while in the advertising of soap that people tell the truth and do not seek to deceive, surely when we seek to advertise about who should govern the country, the very least we could actually come up to are the standards of people who are advertising for soap.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put.
That the amendments (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 110 to 113-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again have a matter to raise with the Minister which relates to clause 114. Clause 114 deals with amendments to section 360 of the principal Act regarding the power of the Court of Disputed Returns. It is proposed to insert a new subsection (2a) in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Unless the Court considers it desirable in the public interest, it shall not grant to a party to a petition leave to inspect a document that is not relevant to a matter identified in the petition as a matter on which the petitioner relies.

It does seem to me that in fact this casts the onus the wrong way round: if the object of the Court of Disputed Returns is to ensure that everything is done to ensure that an election is a fair election, that it is open and above board and that parties have access to all of the information, what this section should have said, in my view, is that, unless the court believes that it is in the public interest to withhold a document, then in fact it should make all documents available. I believe that it is the correct way when dealing with a matter like a Court of Disputed Returns to cast the onus the other way round-to say, `In order to be perfectly acceptable we ought to have a system in which anything is discoverable unless the Court believes there is a public interest that it should not be'.

What has happened is that this has been put the other way round. It has been put on the basis that, unless the Court believes that it is desirable in the public interest, it shall not grant-it is prohibited from granting-access to a document that is not relevant to a matter identified in the petition as a matter upon which a petitioner relies. In other words, I go to the Court of Disputed Returns; in my petition I indicate that I am relying upon certain things; I have access to the documents which the Court has and which go to those matters upon which I have said I am relying-but if there is a document lying around there which in fact substantiates my case that the election should be declared null and void but I have not previously identified it in terms of my petition, it casts the onus on the court to determine that there is a public interest that I should have access to it although I had not previously identified it in the petition. It means that if I do not get the petition exactly right I may in fact fail, and that failure may in fact be a consequence of what amounts to a legal technicality-the petition was not exactly correct.

The Committee must bear in mind that the Court of Disputed Returns decision is final, unappealable. It is not as if this matter is then subject to some further evaluation in a higher court. The decisions of a Court of Disputed Returns are by virtue of the Electoral Act final and unappealable. It does seem to me that in fact this really should have been cast the other way round to say that, unless the Court considers that it is desirable in the public interest that a document not be granted to a petitioner or that access to a document not be granted to a petitioner, it shall make available to a petitioner any matter in the possession of the Court. I am curious as to whether in fact there is some substantial principle here that the Government relies upon to have cast the onus one way when I think the burden of the argument should have compelled the onus to be cast the other way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that Senator Puplick's characterisation is accurate but it does derive from the Nunawading case, as much as these amendments do. What proposed new subsection (2a) is trying to define is the degree to which a petitioner can go on a fishing exercise. What happened in Nunawading was that virtually every accusation made as to irregularity at the time a petition was taken out was dismissed-at great expense in tracking down virtually every allegation. However, petitioners were allowed to go on a fishing expedition that turned up other material. This does not seek to halt that. What this seeks to do is to say that petitioners must have some reasonably based ground to seek those documents. I might point out that virtually all the documents concerned here anyway can be FOIed, as was done in the case of Fadden in 1984 but never proceeded with to finality. I am sure Hamish Lenecker and Co. actually FOIed all the necessary documents to get the relevant information. So there is an alternative route. But what this provision is trying to do is say yes to fishing expeditions, but not long-line fishing expeditions; I am sure honourable senators know what I mean. There is discretion in the court and I cannot imagine a court not having a fairly reasonable interpretation of the degree to which that discretion can be used. The provision says that a person cannot put in a petition to the Court of Disputed Returns and just head it, `We was robbed', then arrive in court and ask for documents to be made available. A person must have some grounds not just general grounds, to go to the court in the first place. That is what this proposed new subsection, arising out of the Nunawading case, seeks to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The principal Act in paragraph 360 (1) (iii) grants to the court powers to allow it to grant to any party to a petition leave to inspect in the presence of a prescribed officer the rolls and other documents, excluding of course, the ballot papers, used at or in connection with any election and to take, in the presence of the prescribed officer, extracts from those rolls and documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new subsection (2a) actually amends subsection (2), which simply allows the court to exercise all and any of its powers under this section, in its discretion in thinking it just and sufficient. The amendment to which Senator Puplick has drawn our attention, quite properly, is not necessary. The court already has the power to operate in a just and sufficient fashion. If it does not believe that the long-line fishing expedition that Senator Ray referred to is in fact just and proper, taking into account all of these matters, then the court will simply decline to allow the person to do that. It seems to me that it is better in these matters to leave that discretion in the hands of the court than to seek to confine them in the way this provision does.

If it is the wish to refer in some way to this I think that the construction Senator Puplick has raised is the proper one at this time. We should see how that operates before we go any further. I am not at all sure that we should move hurriedly on the basis of one exercise to circumscribe in such a fashion. The onus is upon the court to do whatever is in the public interest. I would have thought in some way the public interest is probably served by making sure we get the right person elected. In that sense this would probably not be a very onerous imposition on the court; it would simply say that any of the documents possibly may allude to, support or in some way bolster the case that is brought. We are not dealing with an extensive number of cases. At the end of the day I think it is probably better to have as open and as full an operation with regard to these matters as it is possible to achieve. I presume that Senator Puplick is saying that the Opposition proposes to vote against clause 114. I indicate that we would join the Opposition in that.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 114 (Powers of Court).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I simply indicate that for the reasons I have discussed I will be seeking to vote for the deletion of clause 114. I understand that Senator Macklin from the Democrats will be joining us in that regard. Whether a division is necessary or not, I leave to the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 74, after clause 127, insert the following new clauses:
Distribution to electors of arguments for and against proposed law
``127a. Section 11 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection (4) `The' and substituting `Subject to section 11a, the'.
``127b. After section 11 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
Advertising relating to referendums

`11a. (1) The Commonwealth, a State, a Territory or a local governing body shall not expend money in promoting, directly or indirectly, by way of advertisements of any kind, the case in favour of or against a proposed law unless the Electoral Commission has approved the proposed expenditure under this section.

`(2) Where the Commonwealth, a State, a Territory or a local governing body proposes to expend money in promoting, by way of advertisements of any kind, the case in favour of or against a proposed law, the Commonwealth, the State, the Territory or the local governing body may make a written application to the Electoral Commission for approval of the proposed expenditure.
`(3) An application shall be made in accordance with a form approved by the Electoral Commission and shall set out details of the proposed expenditure.

`(4) Where an application is made in relation to the promotion of the case in favour of or against a proposed law, the Electoral Commission shall not approve the proposed expenditure unless the Electoral Commission is satisfied that:
(a) the details set out in the application are correct; and

(b) the Commonwealth, the State, the Territory or the local governing body, as the case may be, has paid to a fund established for the purpose of promoting the case against or in favour of, as the case may be, the proposed law an amount not less than the amount of the proposed expenditure.
`(5) The Electoral Commission shall consider each application made under this section and shall give to the applicant:

(a) if the Electoral Commission approves the proposed expenditure-a certificate (in this section called an `approval certificate') stating that the Electoral Commission has approved the proposed expenditure and setting out the amount of the proposed expenditure; or
(b) if the Electoral Commission does not approve the proposed expenditure-a notice in writing of its decision setting out its reasons for that decision.
`(6) This section does not apply to expenditure:
(a) on a matter referred to in a paragraph of subsection 11 (4); or
(b) on the salaries and allowances of:
(i) members of the Parliament of a State or the legislature of a Territory or a local governing body; or
(ii) members of the public service of a State or of a Territory or employees of a local governing body.

`(7) The Electoral Commission, the Commonwealth, a State, a Territory, a local governing body or an elector may institute proceedings in the High Court for an injunction preventing the broadcasting, publishing or printing of an advertisement relating to a referendum in respect of which an approval certificate is required but has not been issued.
`(8) Where:
(a) money is paid into a fund under this section; and
(b) the money is not applied, or is not wholly applied, in promoting, by way of advertisements of any kind, the case against or the case in favour of, as the case may be, a proposed law;
the person having control of the fund shall pay that money, or the remainder of that money, as the case may be, to the government or local government body that paid the money into the fund.
`(9) This section binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, of each State and of each Territory.

`(10) For the purposes of this section, ``local governing body'' means a local governing body established by or under a law of a State or Territory, other than a body the sole or principal function of which is to provide a particular service such as the supply of electricity or water, and includes a body established by local governing bodies for the purpose of representing their interests.'.''.

The particular proposition here is the issue of government spending during the constitutional referenda campaigns. As the Minister well knows, this goes back quite a considerable time and has been the subject of fairly heated debate in this chamber going back to 1983, as I remember. Most recently, of course, in the lead-up to the September 1988 referendum campaigns we saw again the expenditure of vast sums of public funds by State governments, in particular, and also by local government bodies. Indeed, I made a submission last year on behalf of my Party, the Australian Democrats, to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, expressing the grave concern that we had on this question.

Honourable senators would be aware that as the Act now stands the Commonwealth Government spending on the Yes and the No cases must be conducted within the guidelines of an amendment made to the Act in 1984 which I moved and which stipulated that Commonwealth moneys should be evenly divided between the Yes and the No cases. This had been a matter of convention until that point but, in seeking to depart from that, it seemed to us at that time, and still seems to us, that it is reasonable that any public funds spent at the Commonwealth level should be equally divided.

What I am seeking to do now is to apply that principle, that equality of funding to State and local government expenditure, during a referendum campaign. Obviously, of course, there are questions that may be put which could affect State and local government. Indeed, in the last referendum campaign there was an endeavour to enshrine local governments within our constitutional structure. Certainly, it should be entitled to put its views to the electorate. However, we believe that, if the current context is allowed to continue, those public funds at the Commonwealth level have to be dealt with in an even-handed way and yet at State and local government level they can be dealt with in any way they wish. In the current context, of course, where the Australian Labor Party controls all but one of the State governments in Australia, it obviously would be in an extremely advantageous situation if it wished to engage in a public spending exercise. It could do so very simply and very easily by bypassing the obligation that is imposed upon the Commonwealth and instead seeking to pick up those funds through the State governments' expenditure on a referendum campaign, whether it be for the Yes or No case. In fact, during the last referendum the then National Party State Government in Queensland spent about $1m promoting the No case, and the No case alone.

It is interesting to go back to the Hansard records of the 1984 debate when the Opposition parties argued very strongly for equality in public funding for the Yes and the No case and for a decision to be left to the electors; in other words, that public funds should not be used in such a way as to seek to prejudice the case but rather to state the case for both sides and then leave it to the electorate to make a decision. I do not want to go into great detail as to the type of exercise that was run in Queensland but rather to refer only to the principles. The thrust of these clauses is to require Commonwealth, State and local government to get the Electoral Commission's approval for expenditure. They would have to make an application for the expenditure of the money and the approval would be given through an approval certificate. The money then spent would have to be accounted for. There are other safeguards built into the Act in a way that would enable enforcement of this.

Of course, some objections could be raised with regard to the legal and constitutional powers to do this, and in the drawing up of these amendments I have sought advice on both of those levels and the advice has been very clear that there are no constitutional barriers under section 128 to this exercise. Section 128 provides that when a proposed law is submitted to the electors, the votes should be taken in such a manner as the Parliament prescribes. Clearly when a question in a referendum goes to the people to alter the Constitution, the Commonwealth, through the Parliament, may make laws with respect to the manner in which such votes are taken. Section 51 of the Constitution states:
The Parliament shall, . . . have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-
(XXXIX.) Matters incidental to the execution of any power vested by this Constitution in the Parliament or in either House thereof, . . .

Given that the Parliament has the power to make laws with respect to Federal elections and referenda, the Democrats believe that it equally has the power to legislate in the field of State, Territory and local government expenditure on referendum questions and that it ought to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I could, I suppose, put forward a number of points on this but I make only one that I regard as the overwhelmingly relevant one, which is that this will simply be struck down in the courts as it is not constitutional. The Australian Electoral Commission would not have those powers over local governments or State governments and therefore I do not see much point in proceeding.

—I agree entirely with what the Minister has just said-that is, the point that I had marked in my notes in terms of the relationship between the Commonwealth Electoral Commission and the government of a State or Territory or a local government body. For those reasons we will not support the Democrat amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that neither the Minister nor Senator Puplick was listening to my last comments. They merely asserted the opposite. In no way would this be struck down in the courts given the fact that the Parliament actually has the power to make laws with regard to the holding of referenda campaigns and also the power, under section 51 of the Constitution, to make laws incidental to the holding of any of those campaigns. This is an incidental power and it would be relied upon as being sufficient to carry the day. Indeed if it were not, I would refer the Minister to many other clauses of the Bill which are also dependent upon those incidental powers. For example, it is possible for the Commonwealth Parliament to make laws on the electoral items that we have been discussing which actually affect State and local government powers. Those types of exercises are often carried out under Federal legislation and in fact have overriden State and local powers precisely on the basis of the incidental power contained in section 51.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 93, after paragraph 149 (b), insert the following new paragraph:
``(ba) by adding at the end of paragraph (1) (b) `or the voter's intention is not clear';''.
(2) Page 93, after paragraph 149 (e), add the following new paragraph:
``(f) by adding at the end of the following subsection:
`(9) For the purpose of ascertaining a voter's intention, regard shall only be had to the word ``Yes'' or ``No'' written alone or without words of qualification.'.''.

These amendments relate to the formality of voting in referendums. This area has been open to a lot of debate, confusion, et cetera. The Government is seeking to make it as precise as possible so that one will not get an inconsistent interpretation. I do not regard this as a most essential area. I do not think a referendum will be put again this century. They cost $40m a pop. Anything the coalition puts up we are going to oppose out of spite, as it has done, so it is not that relevant. If we get it wrong now we will have another 10 goes at amending the Act before the next referendum comes up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed paragraph 149 (f), proposed new subsection 93 (9), leave out `written alone or without words of qualification', insert ``written alone within the square provided, irrespective of words of qualification elsewhere on the ballot paper''.

We have had a very long debate on this, I think twice already. I am not sure whether Senator Puplick was in on that one. I remember his talking about this issue. I do not know whether he was carrying it at that stage for the Opposition. We have got ourselves into an extremely difficult situation by way of formal clarification in this area. We believe that the wording I have put forward makes much clearer what would be a formal vote. The requirement for a vote to be formal is that the word `yes' or `no' is written alone in the squares on the referendum ballot paper. Any other words are irrelevant to the wish of the elector in terms of the validity of that vote. We are all aware of what happened in regard to the no dams issue. It seems to me that, provided the word `no' was written within a square and the word `dams' was written outside it, it should not have been ruled out as a valid vote.

My worry is that, the way it is expressed, it in no way refers to whether those words are inside or outside the square or anywhere else. I think we will find that we could get into more difficulties with this proposition, difficulties which would be avoided totally if, provided the `yes' and `no' were inside the square, any other words on the ballot paper were regarded as being irrelevant to the intention of the voter.

The Act now says, `Written alone or without words of qualification'. If it is written alone, how can it be written with words of qualification? What is the exact difference between the two? It makes no sense to divide them. People who have to count these votes ought to be clear that what they are looking for is a `yes' or a `no' inside the square and that everything else should be ignored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little confused about which section of the Act we are amending. The clause we have here is 149. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 93 of the principal Act is amended:

My copy of the principal Act has section 93 headed `Person entitled to enrolment and to vote', and `Informal ballot-papers' is section 268 in my copy of the Act. Can the Minister in fact tell me whether we have a misprint here? It seems to me that in fact this is not an amendment to section 93 at all; it is an amendment to section 268.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 93 of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act.

—I see. I thank the Minister for that. In that case, is it intended to replicate things, for example, in relation to the presence of the official mark in section 268 of this Act as well, or are we going to have slightly different wording between the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act and the Commonwealth Electoral Act in that regard?
—One requires numbers; one requires writing. Therefore, you have the no dams problem, et cetera.
—No. I refer to subclause 149 (b), which is before us at the moment and which says:

SPEECH.PARA: `by omitting . . . or by an official mark as prescribed' and substituting `or by the presence of the official mark'.

Those words `or by an official mark as prescribed' also occur in 268 (1) (a) and it seems to me that if in fact we are talking about the ballot paper we ought to have consistency between the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act and the Commonwealth Electoral Act in that regard and the--

TALK.START.PARA: —There is consistency, I am informed. Go back to page 48.
—I will take the Minister's word.
—Clause 79, `Informal ballot-papers', contains the same words.

—I see, yes. I stand corrected. We have canvassed the substantive matter before us at some length and Senator Short, when he spoke-I suspect some years ago-on this particular matter, indicated our view in relation to the proposed Democrats' amendment, which we will support. Senator Macklin has made out the case. It does not appear to us to make very much difference whether there are in fact words around and about it which qualify it or make it a smart comment or a particular slogan comment which people want to make, provided the word `yes' or the word `no' appears clearly within the box and can be distinguished by the Divisional Returning Officer. As a consequence, we think that is fair enough. That is the position that Senator Short put down on our behalf some years ago. We have not departed from that. As a result, I guess what we are doing here, therefore, is supporting the Government's amendment No. 10 to add the new paragraph (ba) and we are supporting the Democrats' amendment, which amends the Government's amendment No. 11 so as to make new subsection (9) read in the following fashion:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purpose of ascertaining a voter's intention, regard shall only be had to the word `yes' or `no' written alone within the square provided, irrespective of words of qualification elsewhere on the ballot paper.
We will support that amendment to the Government's amendment.
