TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that if this amendment by Senator Macklin is carried we are going to have a Mexican stand-off, because the Government will not accept it. The effect of it, of course, is that, if one were to write `yes' in the square by mistake, cross it out and write `no' adjacent to the square, then that would not be counted. People do make mistakes; we do not have rubbers on the end of pencils in the ballot box.
—Get another ballot paper.
—Oh, come on! Who knows to get another ballot paper, Senator?
—They do.

—Some people do, but what most people would do, having made a mistake, is to cross out the pencil mark and put the number adjacent to it. That is accepted in Federal elections; provided the number is properly adjacent to the square, obviously somebody has made a mistake. What this amendment is going to do is to deprive a lot of people of votes. This whole area is still unsatisfactory. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform had several goes at trying to get it right, as have Ministers and other people, including shadow Ministers. No-one has got it right yet. I am not sure that the Government amendment will get it right as it should be, but it will be a lot better without the addition of Senator Macklin's amendment, which will clearly disenfranchise a lot of people. I have no confidence that the House of Representatives will accept this amendment. I will recommend that it accepts all other amendments carried here, in spite of Government opposition, but this is one I could not support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -As the reason given for rejection of the amendment is the possible disqualification of a number of voters, I ask the Minister whether his proposal would not disqualify even more voters, or at least it would have in cases in recent history. I cannot quite remember-the Minister is better versed in this than I am-the number of people who actually wrote `no dams', but it was a concerted campaign; Thousands of people did it. The number of people who may have got it wrong inside the square, and then crossed it out, would probably be only in the hundreds. If one makes a mistake on an ordinary ballot paper, one can go and get another one. If one makes a mistake on a referendum ballot paper, one can go and get another one. So those people have an avenue of redress.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to what the Government is proposing, I find it difficult to understand what `written alone' or `irrespective of words of qualification' means but I presume that it means that if any other words appear anywhere on the ballot paper it will be invalid. That, I suggest, would rule out far more people every time. As the Minister well knows, in scrutinising these things-Senator Puplick raised this-some very ingenious suggestions arise on ballot papers as to what one can do and what one may not be able to do. People get quite inventive. But, if they are inventive, provided they stay within those parameters-a yes or no inside the square-what they write on the rest of the ballot paper in their inventiveness is irrelevant to the casting of their ballot. I believe that on balance the number of people whose votes would be ruled out if the Government's amendment were carried would be very large compared to the few who, having made a mistake, would be intimidated into not insisting on their rights and going and getting another ballot paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The old `no dams' claim is a bunch of rubbish. What the Commission was particularly worried about was that sometimes the word `no' would fall over into a square and therefore it would be taken as a No vote. SPEECH.PARA: This whole area is a mess. Senator Macklin is not going to improve it much. I am only going to improve it marginally. SPEECH.PARA: Page 112, Schedule 3, leave out the proposed amend;atments to paragraphs 93 (8) (a), 93 (8) (b), section 109 and subsection 110 (1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

This amendment concerns the rights of prisoners to vote. I do not propose to take very long on this matter. I have had some discussions with Senator Ray about it, and I wish briefly to draw attention to one thing. This huge amendment Bill runs to a grand total of 123 printed pages. It contains six schedules. Schedule 3, which is headed `Minor amendments of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918', says:
Omit the paragraph.

That gives prisoners who have been convicted and given a sentence for a particular time the right to vote. It is not a minor amendment. I think that it is just a matter of drawing to the attention of draftsmen that when a significant policy question arises it ought to be dealt with in the substantive body of an Act and not shuffled off into a schedule headed `Minor amendments'. It is a policy change and, as a result, it ought to have appeared in the substantive corpus of the Bill rather than being put in a schedule. I make that point because I think that policy questions are properly dealt with in a more up-front fashion than being described as minor amendments and stuck away in a schedule.

As to the purpose of the Opposition amendment, I have canvassed at considerable length in an earlier debate the rights of prisoners to vote and I do not intend at this hour to rehearse all of those arguments.

Our amendment would restore the situation where prisoners who were convicted of certain offences and spent terms of imprisonment of more than five years should have their voting rights terminated. I believe that is manifestly correct on its face. I believe that the new move around the country towards what is called truth in sentencing will mean that such terms of imprisonment will be imposed only where the offences are genuinely of sufficient seriousness for them to carry that length of penalty.

Rather than weary the Committee any longer, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the dissenting report, signed by former Senator the Hon. Sir John Carrick, the Hon. Michael MacKellar, MP, and Mr C. W. Blunt, MP, to report No. 2 of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform entitled The Operation during the 1984 General Election of the 1983-84 amendments to Commonwealth Electoral Legislation in which they have argued the case. I urge the Committee to support the Opposition amendment.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Recommendation 23
Abolition of Voting Restrictions on Prisoners
Currently prisoners convicted and under sentence for an offence punishable by imprisonment for 5 years or longer are denied a vote.
The majority recommendation is that all voting restrictions on prisoners (except for the crime of treason) be abolished.

This section of the Act was amended in 1983 to increase the period from 1 to 5 years. The Committee then argued that anyone convicted and sentenced to 5 years had obviously committed a serious offence. In practice most would not be first offenders.
It is now argued by the majority that the incarceration itself is sufficient restriction and that the denial of voting should not be attached.

The concept of imprisonment, apart from any rehabilitation aspects, is one of deterrent, seeking by the denial of a wide range of freedoms to provide a disincentive to crime. The person having committed an offence against society, is denied the privileges and freedoms of society of which one important one is the right to vote. In that philosophy, in the past some electoral laws provided that habitual criminals (recidivists) should be permanently denied the franchise.
The essential question is whether, in certain proven offences, voting rights should be included amongst the many other restrictions of freedoms for those in goal.
On balance the 1983 amendment appears a sensible compromise. It does not seek to penalise the minor offenders. It retains the deterrent for the more serious and recidivist offences.

The AEC has pointed to difficulties in the present wording of the Act. This can be very largely overcome by the disqualification operating not by reference to the maximum sentence but to the actual sentence or to the period that the prisoner is actually in custody.

The argument that there is a serious lack of consistency in attaching a penal sanction to an offence is not a ground for removing voting restrictions on prisoners but rather a plea to re-establish consistency. The fact that some people who commit serious offences are fined and not gaoled cannot be taken to support the freeing from gaol of all prisoners of a similar magnitude of crime.
It is a current fact of life that the conduct of penal systems is not founded totally on deterrence and rehabilitation but rather on the political economics of maintaining gaols-a low priority.

There is a need for an objective study of crime, punishment and rehabilitation to derive optimum decisions free of the grave distortions of priorities in government financing. A similar objective approach should be made to the question of whether one of the many losses of freedom impacting on certain prisoners should be the freedom to vote for a certain period.
In the interim, the 1983 amendment seems appropriate.
8 December 1986
Senator the Hon. Sir J. Carrick, KCMG
Hon. M. J. R. MacKellar, MP
Mr C. W. Blunt, MP
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We recommit this particular clause because a mistake was made in drafting. I thank the Opposition spokesman, Senator Puplick, for inadvertently alerting us to this by drawing attention to another section of the Act. When we went to the relevant section to disprove his point, we found a clause missing, that is, `Governor of a State'. We would very much like to reinsert it; otherwise, the Governor would be able to issue writs, but apparently not have to sign them. It is a bit embarrassing when such drafting errors occur, but they do occur from time to time. I thank Senator Puplick who had it raised via Neil Brown, via a constituent who picked this up. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am grateful to the Government for picking up this amendment. What in fact happened was that an elector by the name of Mrs Clare Howard wrote to Mr Warwick Smith saying that she had read the Bill and found something that she thought was totally defective about it. He sent it to Mr Neil Brown, the shadow Attorney-General, for an opinion. Mr Neil Brown wrote back to him saying that he thought Mrs Howard was absolutely correct and that the error in fact occurred in clause 49, amending section 152. They then sent it to me because I was handling the Bill here. I then gave it to the Minister who gave it to his departmental officials who had a look at it and decided that it was right after all. They have now produced this amendment to clause 49 to re-instate the requirements as far as the signing of the writs by State Governors are concerned. Mrs Clare Howard deserves whatever award it is that one hands out for members of the public in these circumstances. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the letter from Mr Brown to Mr Smith which actually sets out the details of this matter and explains the background to the amendment which the Government has now moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
5 September 1989
Mr Warwick Smith MP
Member for Bass and Shadow Minister
for Aboriginal Affairs
Suite R1 38
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Warwick,
I refer to representations you have received from Mrs Clare Howard concerning the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988 which is presently before the Senate.
Mrs Howard has drawn attention to the fact that the Bill appears to make an attempt to remove the power of State Governor to issue writs for the election of Senators for the States.
The conclusion I have come to is either Mrs Howard is right about this or we have been presented with a very bad piece of drafting which requires some explanation.
The starting point is that section 12 of the Constitution provides that writs for the election of Senators for the States are to be issued by the Governor of the State concerned.
Naturally, as this is in the Constitution, no law of the Parliament may overrule it.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act reflects this position accurately. Section 152 of the Act provides that writs for the election of Senators and Members of the House of Representatives may be in the forms set out respectively in the Schedule to the Act.

The Schedule to the Act sets out three forms; the first for the election of Senators from a State, the second for the election of Senators from a Territory and the third for the election of Members of the House of Representatives.
The first form rightly makes provision for the title of the Governor of the State and clearly is an effective means of providing a form of writ to be issued by the Governor of a State.

The second form is for the election of Senators from a Territory and this form provides for the issue of the writ by the Governor-General. That is so because there is nothing in the Constitution to prevent it and because the Commonwealth Electoral Act provides that the Governor-General may issue those writs.

The third form provides for the election of Members of the House of Representatives and also provides for the issue of that writ by the Governor-General or by the Speaker. This is also consistent with the Constitution because section 32 provides that it is the Governor-General who may issue writs for general elections of Members of the House of Representatives and section 33 provides that the Speaker is to issue a writ for an election to fill a vacancy.

Bringing the matter up-to-date, at this stage one can say that the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act are consistent with the Constitution and, for Mrs Howard's immediate question, the writ for the election of Senators from a State correctly provides for that writ to be issued by the Governor of a State.

We are now faced with the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988. Amongst other things, this Bill amends the Act by removing a lot of gender-specific language, for example, by removing ``he'' and substituting ``the person''. In the course of doing that the Bill amends the Schedules to the Commonwealth Electoral Act which set out the writs for elections. They remove the expression ``by His Excellency's Command'' from each of the writs. Having done that, clause 49 of the Bill amends section 152 of the Act by providing that the writs are to be signed.
Presumably this is because, having removed the exhortation that the writ is issued by His Excellency, it was felt that the writs should actually be signed.

Now comes the curious part which is that, as Mrs Howard has correctly pointed out, the Bill provides that the writ is to be signed ``by the Governor-General or the Speaker as the case requires''. It does not provide that the writ is to be signed by the Governor of a State, the Governor-General or the Speaker.

I have already said that the writs for the election of Senators for a State must be issued by the Governor of the State. No one else may issue them. Consequently, you would expect the Bill to provide that when you are dealing with a writ for the election of Senators for a State that that writ is to be signed by the State Governor. After all, the Bill does in fact provide that for the election of Territory Senators and Members of the House of Representatives, the writ is to be signed by the Governor-General or the Speaker as the case may be.
One would, therefore, expect a similar provision providing that in the case of a writ for the election of Senators from a State, that that writ is to be signed by the Governor of the State.
But it does not provide that and that is the curious thing.
There are two explanations for this that I can think of.
The first explanation is that it is bad drafting and that the draftsman has made a mistake. So, what we should do is to have attention drawn to this when the Bill comes on for debate in the Senate.

The other explanation takes us back to the original provision in the Constitution which, as I have said, provides that the Governor of the State may issue the writ and, by implication, no one else. That being so, perhaps a deliberate decision has been made that you simply cannot say in a Commonwealth law that the Governor of a State is to sign the writ. The argument may be that it is surplusage. In other words, no matter what you say in the Bill, the provision in the Constitution is paramount and the writ is to be issued by the Governor of the State.

The point that is difficult to understand about this explanation is that if this is so, why has the Bill taken the words ``by His Excellency's Command'' also out of the form of writ for the election of Senators from a State as well as from the other writs.
Even if this is the explanation, we should still draw attention to this in the debate on this Bill in the Senate.
I have therefore taken the liberty of sending a copy of this letter to Wal Fife, the Shadow Minister in charge of electoral matters so that the matter can be addressed.
It certainly deserves to have attention drawn to it and Mrs Howard has done us a service by directing our attention to the issue.
Yours sincerely
N. A. BROWN

I have the approval of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to incorporate his response of 11 December 1989 to questions that I raised in respect of the Film Censorship Board on that date and also my response to that letter dated 21 December 1989. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Dear Senator Harradine

I have drawn the remarks you made during the Senate's discussion of the Attorney-General's Department in the Committee consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) to the attention of the Chief Censor.
The Chief Censor has provided the following information in relation to the matters which you raised.
Awareness Campaign

The Awareness Campaign is a three way venture involving the Commonwealth, the States and the film and video industry. In general terms, its purpose is to inform the community about the classification process, what each of the classifications mean and what kind of films and videos people are likely to expect in each category. It will also focus on the work of the Office of Film and Literature Classification and the principles it employs when making classification decisions. An initial survey will establish what other areas need to be addressed. As part of that process it will continue the current practice of promoting the Office as the place where people can obtain further information about classifications or direct their views about classification decisions.

The conduct of the Campaign will be in the hands of a professional agency, chosen by all three participating parties. The manner and extent to which the Office is promoted will depend upon the recommendations of the agency. The suggestion of a 008 phone number will be considered in that context.
Non-Violent Erotica
The Board has used the term non-violent erotica to distinguish the material in the `X' category from other sexually explicit material involving violence and coercion.

Prior to the introduction of an `X' classification early in 1984 the Board's practice was to refer to sexually exploitative material which was inexplicit enough to be accommodated in a theatrical `R' classification as ``soft-core pornography''. Explicit sexual activity (even of a consenting nature) was referred to as ``hard-core pornography'' and refused classification for public exhibition. When the `X' classification for video was introduced it encompassed the previously refused material including all but extreme depictions of sexual violence, cruel acts, bestiality and child pornography.

When the `X' classification was reviewed in December 1984 it was limited to ``explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults'', but not including, ``any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind''.

This excluded material which, in the public mind, had become associated with the expression ``hard-core pornography'', and Board members in their daily reference to such material coined the phrase ``non-violent erotica'' as a suitable shorthand description of the `X' guidelines referred to above.

The description, ``non-violent erotica'', seems appropriate to differentiate between material which is in the `X' category and material which would otherwise be refused classification. For that reason it was used as a description of the `X' category on the guidelines issued by the Board.

The term ``non-violent erotica'' has never been used by the Board as an alternative to `X'. The guidelines are being reprinted to take into account amendments to the Classification of Publications Ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory in which references to ``terrorism'' have been replaced by the broader reference to ``instructs in matters of crime or violence''.
In the reprinted version, the `X' category will be summarised as ``Consenting sexually explicit material'' instead of ``non-violent erotica''.
Prominence of `X' category in Awareness Campaign

No decisions have yet been taken about what resources will be used to clarify what material is in the `X' category. The Awareness Campaign is directed overwhelmingly to the mainstream of film and video viewers. Research conducted by the Australian Institute of Criminology and the Attorney-General's Department indicated that, even in the Australian Capital Territory where `X' is legally available, less than ten per cent of the viewers hire `X'-rated material. Therefore, as Mr Dickie said to you at the Estimates Committee hearing, the major pitch of the Campaign will be about the four mainstream categories: `G', `PG', `M' and `R'.

Obviously, in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, there will need to be some reference made to the `X' category because `X'-rated material is one of the recognised categories. The question of the general confusion between the `X' and `R' categories will also have to be addressed. How important this question is in the general scheme of things and what resources will be devoted to it is something which can only be addressed when the research is being considered and resources are being allocated by the Steering Committee on the advice of the professional agency.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL TATE
Senator Brian Harradine
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
December 21, 1989
Senator The Hon. M. Tate,
Minister for Justice,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

Thank you for your letter of 11 December which included the information provided by the Chief Censor in relation to matters raised by me in the Committee's consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 1).

I cannot allow Mr Dickie's version of the ``X'' classification to go unchallenged because it is inconsistent with evidence provided by former Chief Censor Strickland to the Senate Select Committee on Video Material.

Mr Dickie says that the ``X'' classification was reviewed in December 1984 when it was limited to ``explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults but not including any depictions suggesting coercion or non-consent''.

The fact is that the review took place before the meeting of Attorneys-General in Sydney on October 26 1984 and the Film Censorship Board actually issued the guidelines in November 1984 (see JSCVM Report, volume 2, Appendix 5, Page 727). The Board had actually been applying those guidelines well before that date.

Despite the fact that the ``X'' classification was established for what is officially described as ``hard core pornography'' (see Explanatory Memorandum attached); despite the fact that physically violent pornography represented only 5% of ``X'' (A/G's Evidence JSCVM P. 03288), Mr Dickie now implies that the removal from the ``X'' classification of physically violent pornography actually removed ``hard core pornography'' from the ``X'' classification.
Referring to this very same revised ``X'' classification, former Chief Censor Janet Strickland told the Senate Select Committee on Video Material on 12 December 1984:
``Nobody has ever pretended that the X or ER or whatever you call it-R+-is anything but hard core porn.'' (SSCVM Evidence P. 134)

The information which the current Chief Censor has provided to his Minister for Parliament is thus in direct contradiction to this official evidence given on behalf of the Film Censorship Board to a Parliamentary Committee.

As pointed out in the Senate on November 23, the ``X'' rated video industry has been waging a campaign to have its hard core pornography described as non-violent erotica (NVE) and have been assisted by this incorrect description being used by the FCB in its official publication. I now have a transcript of the program on Radio 2CN (Amanda Cavell Show, November 23, 1989) to which I referred in which publicist for the ``X'' rated video industry said:

ROBBIE SWAN: Yes, look the term non violent erotica is actually used by the Film Censorship Board in its information bulletin number 22, when it sets out the classification of films in Australia. It describes X-rated movies as non violent erotica, brackets-NVE. And that's in, I'm sorry, it's the Commonwealth Film Censor. It's in there.

I now note from Mr Dickie's letter that the Film Censorship Board will be abandoning its description of this material in its official publications as ``non-violent erotica'' but will be describing it as ``consenting sexually explicit material''. This phrase is also likely to be highly misleading to the public as to the nature of the material in the ``X'' classification as well as blurring the distinction between pornography and other sexually explicit material designed for educative, health or scientific purposes (see Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, Page 45). I would also draw your attention to page 46 of the Report of the JSCVM (para 3.56) concerning the interpretation of the term ``sexually explicit'', and the inappropriate inclusion of certain material in the ``R'' classification.

The fact is that the FCB's intended use of the bland term ``consenting sexually explicit material'' for the ``X'' classification fails to convey the exploitative and degrading nature of the bulk of ``X'' rated videos which emphasise group sex and promote sexually promiscuous (AIDS high risk) behaviour.

Evidence cited by the JSCVM shows that such material engenders a ``sexually calloused and manipulative orientation towards women.'' It mediates in the mind of the habitual viewer a perception of women in general as being highly promiscuous and available.

It is interesting to note that at least four behavioural scientists whose research was submitted to the Committee saw non-violent pornographic videos as more harmful in this regard even than the violent pornography which has already been banned.

The Chief Censor has no legislative basis for describing this material other than in the terms of the Explanatory Memorandum to the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance namely ``hard core pornography''.
Yours sincerely
SENATOR BRIAN HARRADINE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Very briefly, I point out to those who will read those letters that the information which the current Chief Censor has provided to this Minister for the information of the Parliament is in direct contradiction to official evidence given by a former Chief Censor to a parliamentary select committee, namely, the Senate Select Committee on Video Material. It is very important that those interested peruse the documents that I have had incorporated. It will be my intention to continue to pursue this matter when the Senate has more opportunity to consider it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabling the other day of the annual report of the Prices Surveillance Authority has prompted me to draw to the Senate's attention a number of aspects of the work of the Authority and of the Trade Practices Commission, in particular what I perceive as an abject failure of these watchdogs to ensure that Australians gain the benefits they should gain from free market competition; that is, in the area of the purchases of food and the basis necessities of life. These benefits should include a wide variety of goods on offer and a range in terms of quality and highly competitive retail prices. The prices encountered on the weekly trip to the supermarket to buy staples, that is, groceries, fruit and vegetables, are the factor that can make or break a family budget. For this reason the roles of the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Trade Practices Commission in ensuring that consumers get the best prices that a free market can provide and in protecting them from market manipulation and profiteering and other sharp practices are potentially of enormous importance to all Australians. The Trade Practices Commission's annual report for 1988-89 rather grandly states on its fourth page:

SPEECH.PARA: The Act is a dynamic and positive instrument, deliberately designed to foster free and vigorous competition and a fair trading ethic, not simply to proscribe specified activities or conduct. As the Act demands, the Commission's overall goal remains to benefit ordinary Australians through the mechanisms of a fair, efficient and highly competitive market place'.

These are grand words, indeed, but do they really represent the reality experienced by Australian consumers? I believe emphatically that they do not. When the Act was first introduced, the market consisted of three types of players; the first were manufacturers and primary producers; the second were resellers such as wholesalers and retailers; and the third were end consumers. In this theoretical market-place which, indeed, reflected the reality of the time, consumers were protected from exploitation from two types and levels of competition. At the manufacturer level, there was competition between manufacturers in terms of both quality and price. Goods were sold to a large number of competing resellers. At the reseller level the consumer benefited from competition between retailers, each trying to outdo the other on quality and service offered to the consumer and on price. These two levels of effective competition were sufficient to guarantee to consumers both choice of quality and competitive pricing.

Over the intervening years, the Trade Practices Commission has made a number of rulings and published a number of explanatory statements, the effect of which, whatever may have been their intention, is effectively to blur the distinctions between manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, allowing them all to be categorised simply as suppliers. It has become possible for massive retailing organisations to develop in Australia. They function as wholesalers to their own retail outlets and increasingly adopt also the function of manufacturers. Where independent manufacturers remain, they have become enslaved to the retail chains because these chains have such a high level of control over the market that they have the power to destroy any manufacturer who might decline to cooperate. They could, for example, simply refuse to stop goods manufactured by a particular manufacturer, reduce the shelf space allocated to those goods, decline to promote them or price them at such exorbitant levels that consumers would turn to competing brands.

Manufacturers are thus deprived of the opportunity to compete directly with each other in terms of quality and price. The big chains have total power to determine what will be available to consumers and at what price. Consumers are thereby deprived of competition between manufacturer and manufacturer. The Trade Practices Commission has allowed this situation to develop and it is, as far as I can ascertain, doing nothing whatsoever to correct it.

The big retail chains have adopted a number of strategies to exploit their power over the manufacturers; for example, they demand that manufacturers make payments to them for the shelf space allocated to the display of their goods. These payments are an additional form of income to the retail chains. The chains also demand that the manufacturers pay for in-store promotion of the manufacturers and their products.

These practices and the enormous buying power have enabled the big chains to undercut and gradually to eliminate the old style family grocery shop. Steadily they have increased their market share until the situation has been reached where two or three major retail chains control an enormous share of the market for food and other basic consumer items in Australia. At this point the other forms of competition in terms of service offered and price by competing retail outlets is virtually eliminated. If my choice was to pay 39c for an item in a Coles supermarket in suburb X or 39c for the identical item in a near identical Woolworths supermarket in neighbouring suburb Y or 39c for the identical item in a near identical Foodland supermarket, no competition exists. Those are the three major chains in Western Australia.

It appears from their pricing policies that the major retail chains, either independently, by tacit agreement, or in some other way, have arrived at the conclusion that they can maximise their profits if they charge more or less the same price and the top price on 95 per cent or more of the items they stock at any one time and perceive to `compete' with each other by offering a limited number of so-called specials each week. Since the different retail chains offer different sets of specials each week, the consumer gains no real advantage from shopping at one of the chains rather than at another. Specials, therefore, give an appearance of cutthroat competition when no real competition exists.

A survey carried out over a three-month period by one of my consultants in Western Australia demonstrated very clearly that the big chains simply do not compete on price. Every Wednesday there are full-page advertisements in the West Australian newspaper in which the big retail chains advertise their specials for the week. By careful checking and comparison my consultant discovered that in a three-month period there was not a single example of competition between the three chains on their special offers. Each chain had a different set of specials each week and at the end of each week the specials reverted to the usual high price. He found that the specials were quite regularly rotated from chain to chain so that what was a special in Coles at 44c this week would turn up as a special in Woolworths at 44c next week and would be the same price in Foodland the week after that.

After a few weeks of monitoring prices he found he was able to predict with a high level of accuracy which items would be on special in which chain in a given week. In recent months the matches are no longer so transparently obvious, but the overall position has not changed very much. It strains credibility to believe that no collusion and price fixing is involved. If these chains were involved in genuine competition by offering special prices to attract custom without reference to one another, they must at least occasionally offer the same item at reduced prices and non-identical prices in the same week.

Due partly to the very considerable profits that this system of collusion to maintain high prices and eliminate true competition generates, the chains are in a position to build more and more vast impersonal and monumentally ugly shopping centres. Each of these destroys a given number of small family businesses, reduces choice and removes almost any sort of service to the consumer since staffing levels are reduced to the absolute minimum and very young and inexperienced staff on minimum wages are usually employed. For the hapless consumer, the result of all this is exactly what would obtain if an organised cartel of retailers had formed an agreement to control prices to their own advantage and to the disadvantage of consumers.

The Trade Practices Act contains a definition of `special offers'. The Commission has, however, refused to accept that specials are, in effect, special offers and has refused to compel the chains to follow the requirements which apply to special offers when they market their so-called specials. This is a betrayal of the interests of the consumer. What is needed is a requirement for manufacturers to stipulate a recommended retail price on all their products. A better expression would, perhaps, be a normal price. This would create competition between manufacturers on price. Consumers would know then whether prices charged to them by retailers were high or low relative to the normal price, but the Commission insists that only the retailer may exercise any control over the retail selling price. This is a licence to print money from a cash trade characterised by a captive steady demand with consumers unable to do anything about price rises. In the end we all have to eat.

It is not at all unusual for so-called specials to be at a higher price than a comparable item in another district, and the Commission has the gall to talk about competition and benefits to the consumers. The Prices Surveillance Authority is supposed to act for the benefit of the consumer, but the Trade Practices Commission spikes its guns very effectively. The Prices Surveillance Authority can only monitor the cost prices of the producer, manufacturer, and supplier. It cannot pursue its investigations into the realm of retail pricing because the Commission has resolved that the cost of the article has no relevance to the retail selling price, which is the sole concern of the retailer. The latter need pay no attention to the cost of the article to the consumer other than the market profit which can be achieved. There is an interesting paragraph in the annual report of the Prices Surveillance Authority on coffee prices. It states:

Towards the end of 1988-89 there were substantial decreases in world prices for coffee beans. The Authority has reminded the companies concerned that, while having regard to large stock holdings, long term contracts and increases in other costs, it expects that these reductions in world coffee prices should flow through to the domestic instant coffee prices early in 1989-90.

Let us wait and see. The failure of the Commission is also a failure of this Government, because the wages and prices accord is regarded as the central achievement of the Hawke Government. But that accord is a fraud, because the Government has indeed succeeded to some extent in keeping increases in wages, salaries and benefits down, but has failed utterly to keep prices down. That is why more and more Australian families are sliding steadily into poverty and despair. It is a constant source of amazement to me that unions pay a great deal of attention to wage and salary levels, but appear to do nothing to compel the Government they have supported to keep its word on prices. Gains from wage increases and social security and other benefits are totally illusory while they can be creamed off in price increases as fast as they are delivered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this Bill. This Bill is obviously concerned with the relationship between Australia and Taiwan and that relationship is, in our view, a severely and unnecessarily stunted one that requires urgent correction. In December 1972 Australia recognised the Government in Peking as the sole and legitimate Government of China and that political recognition has not changed. Nevertheless, short of political recognition, we believe that the relationship with Taiwan, covering such areas as commerce, trade, social, cultural and other areas, has been held back unnecessarily.

SPEECH.PARA: During recent years Taiwan has developed and grown at a pace difficult to imagine a decade ago and regrettably Australia has had little part in that growth. Successive Hawke Ministers have tried to justify the poor level of contacts between Australia and Taiwan as somehow being a restraint accepted in the agreement of 1972. That is incorrect. I refer simply to the recent report of Dr Ross Garnaut, who was a former Australian ambassador to China:
Within this policy there are no barriers to the development of commercial and other private relations with Taiwan.

The Hawke Government has also sought to portray its reluctance to establish close ties with Taiwan as somehow being part of a global trend. Again, that is not so. It further has suggested that encouraging contacts with Taiwan would bring retribution from the People's Republic of China. The evidence is that for those that have developed a closer, particularly economic and trade, relationship such retribution has not been forthcoming. The Hawke Government has offered little assistance in the development of the commercial relationship. As recently as 28 April this year the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) reiterated in this chamber:
It has been necessary for us to tread carefully and sensitively in further developing the trading relationship in question.

It is that reluctance to encourage the trading opportunity that has been of particular concern to us. Australia's unofficial representation in Taiwan has been minimal. Until last year only one officer was posted. There are now two officers posted to the quasi-official Australian commerce and industry office (ACIO). The result of this avoidance of contacts is poor knowledge of local Taiwanese politics and powerplays. We saw it demonstrated earlier this year with the restrictions that were introduced by Taiwan on the Australian beef trade. The Australian Government had great difficulty in knowing how to address that challenge because of a lack of adequate local knowledge.

Companies interested in setting up in Taipei have also been hindered by a lack of information regarding commercial opportunities and contacts. There is neither adequate research nor promotion in Taiwan of Australian products. What is worse is evidence of active Hawke Government discouragement of some contracts. One remembers 1987 when the tender of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, which had won a $2.5 billion engineering contract in Taiwan against international competition, was cancelled by ministerial direction, reportedly because the former Foreign Minister feared that the deal could upset China.

What we have witnessed in recent years has, as I said, been incredible economic growth within Taiwan. It now, with no natural resources, has a $US75 billion foreign exchange reserve, second only to Japan. It was the thirteenth largest trading nation in the world in 1988 and is expected to be the twelfth this year. It had an average growth rate of nine per cent over the last two decades, had a trade surplus of $US12 billion in 1988 and has a per capita income of over $US6,000, which is rapidly rising.

I want to touch briefly on some of the commercial opportunities that are being missed. Taiwan's rapidly rising standard of living and high levels of disposable income present excellent opportunities for two-way investment with Australia. Taiwan's increasing domestic demand for social and economic infrastructure is one such opportunity. Considerable opportunities exist in the area of business migration, although already our migration from Taiwan is the second largest numerically in the region. If one looks at the figures, compared with Hong Kong it is still a long way behind. Banking and financial opportunities have been missed. Tourism opportunities particularly have been neglected. In 1988, 1.6m Taiwanese tourists went abroad spending over $US4 billion. Of that number, only 1.1 per cent came to Australia. Education opportunities also abound. An estimated 40,000 Taiwanese a year study overseas, most of them going to the United States. In 1988 only 335 Taiwanese were in Australia studying, which is only 0.9 per cent of our overseas students. So those figures indicate, I would suggest, a great market that is not being tapped.

There have been problems, and there are still problems, in the relationship. How to respond to the greater assertiveness on the part of Taiwan and its increasing use of economic strength to obtain political concessions provides a challenge for the Australian Government. How to develop soundly based ties with Taiwan rather than react in an emotional way to the events that have occurred in China this year is another problem.

There must be a recognition that Taiwan is not without its problems also: labour problems are growing and it is going through a phase of political transition that could lead to extra stresses. The Australian Government also, we accept, must develop the Taiwanese relationship without jeopardising the China relationship. But these obstacles can be overcome provided the Government has foresight and behaves with commonsense.

One piece of finally obtained evidence of commonsense comes in this piece of legislation before the chamber today. I refer to the fact that the legislation will provide some investment protection, which we support. Taiwanese Government assets, investments overseas, are questionably not protected against a claim from Beijing and arguably, under the 1972 agreement, there could be an action for Beijing to claim such assets. This legislation makes it clear that such a claim would be unsuccessful. It means that there is now an opportunity for Australia at least to compete for such projects as the China Steel project, although one should stress that we nevertheless are going to have to compete against strong competition from such countries as Canada and Malaysia. Therefore this legislation, in itself, is not going to achieve the objective of attracting greater investment, but at least it will facilitate that opportunity.

The other area that remains at a totally unsatisfactory state is that of direct air links. The need for direct air links is self-evident, I would suggest. Nineteen international passenger airlines already fly into Taipei. Cathay Pacific, in which the Chinese Government itself has a 12 per cent share, has the highest frequency at about 112 flights a week. But Australia of course does not have direct air links. Why? When the Australian Government sought to negotiate-it went to China in effect to seek permission, which was not necessary under the 1972 agreement-China indicated that through a subsidiary, Australian-Asia Airlines, we would be allowed to fly to Taipei provided that we did not accept a reciprocal right, that of China Airlines to fly to Australia. Taiwan, not surprisingly, is now claiming that reciprocal right and therefore an impasse has been reached, the irony of course being that permission from China, as I said, was not required in the first instance. The cost to Australia is a loss in economic opportunity.

I have not time to deal with the internal developments. I mentioned that they will provide new and additional challenges for Australia, as will what is commonly known as the China factor. But it is worth noting now that if one looks at the relationship between China and Taiwan and how that may have been seen as necessary to restrain our developing relationship with Taiwan, one sees that many restrictions between China and Taiwan have been progressively lifted. More than 800,000 Taiwanese visited China for family reunions alone. Two-way trade in 1988 was estimated at $2.6 billion. According to China, Taiwanese have invested more than $400m in China, predominantly in low wage, labour intensive industries. Taiwanese officials even attended an Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing on 4 May and officials conducted direct negotiations over the fate of an aircraft hijacked from China to Taipei. So whilst on the one hand China has required of us considerable restrictions, it is interesting to note that on the other hand it has been developing in the meantime its relationship with Taiwan.

What is most likely to happen, and in some ways the best thing that could happen, is that the status quo in the relationship between Taiwan and China, which has existed for 40 years, should continue. The two countries should move to further reduce tensions with increased people-to-people contacts and greater economic interaction.

The future as I see it indicates that there is nothing to stop Australia from establishing a wide range of ties with Taiwan, short of political recognition. Provided that it does so sensibly and sensitively, it can have a mutually beneficial relationship with Taiwan, whatever Taiwan's political future. Hence we would suggest that it is important that the Australian Government-this Government whilst it remains in office and certainly us when we come to office-immediately review all facets of the long term Taiwan relationship and Australia's response to the challenge of greater practical interaction with Taiwan within present political constraints.

We can look at ways in which the Australian Government can facilitate documentation procedures greatly: it could allow the ACIO to process and issue visas in Taipei; it could allow it to give multi-entry business visas in Taiwan. We can look at, and should look at, the ministerial guidelines which cover the relationship, which are presently unduly bureaucratic and restrictive. We can look at ways in which there can be much more effort to disseminate information opportunities in Taiwan. We can look at the question of business immigration that I mentioned earlier and how to extend our opportunities in that regard, perhaps by placing an immigration officer with business migration experience in Taipei. We can look at perhaps giving Austrade, for the first time, a role in promoting business opportunities. We can look at putting a political officer in Taiwan-there are ways in which it could be done-so that the Australian Government could have a better understanding of the political changes that are occurring. We can look at other ways in which we can promote trade. We can look at ways in which the government departments concerned can better coordinate their contribution with the Australian Chamber of Commerce, tourism bodies and other relevant groups. As I said, we can make greater use of the education opportunities which present themselves and we can take a more realistic approach to resolving the direct air-link question, the importance of which cannot be over-emphasised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has long been a need to clarify the position and to remove any obstacles, or perceived obstacles, that there are between Australia and overseas countries as to the question of ownership of land. The Foreign Corporations (Application of Laws) Bill 1989 is particularly significant as far as Taiwan, the Republic of China, is concerned. It is on this aspect that I also wish to speak. Today is 21 December, which is particularly significant, because it was on 21 December 1972 that we signed an agreement with the People's Republic of China (PRC) which took back much of the relationship we had with the Republic of China, Taiwan since 1949. So it is fitting that on 21 December 1989 we should start restoring some of what we took away then.

SPEECH.PARA: The Republic of China has been a first class neighbour, a substantial trading partner and a strong and stable influence in our area. Its progress since 1949 has been particularly spectacular. Its economic growth, trade growth, population growth and gross domestic product growth have been absolutely tremendous. In most of those respects Taiwan is an example to us. During this period we have developed trade which now amounts to approximately $3 3/4 billion a year. Taiwan is our sixth largest customer and our eighth largest supplier of goods. It is about half the size of Tasmania but it is the twelfth major trading nation of the world.

We must contemplate that, with all the effort we have put into it and all the money we have invested in trying to establish trade with the People's Republic of China, our trade with Taiwan still exceeds our trade with the PRC by more than 50 per cent, and this is in spite of the fact that we have no official recognition of the Republic of China, Taiwan, no tourist links, no direct air flights, no official visits, no guarantees of investment integrity and not even approval for Federal members of parliament to travel there on their official passports.

Although Taiwan rates as our fifth largest trading partner and although since 1949 we have had no problems or difficulties, we maintain these totally artificial and unnecessary barriers. The Senate may recall that on 15 June I gave a notice of motion along the following lines. I had hoped to get a much stronger reaction from the Government. My notice of motion reads:
That in view of the brutal massacre in the People's Republic of China, the Senate requests the Government to reconsider Australia's relationship with the Republic of China and Taiwan with a view to-
(a) recognising the strong business and cultural links already existing between the 2 countries;
(b) establishing direct Qantas and China Airlines flights between Australia and Taipei;
(c) upgrading the existing official agencies and allowing the Taiwanese to use their official names and titles as is currently allowed in the USA, Japan, and Canada;
(d) encouraging visits of Ministers to Taiwan to attract Taiwanese capital to develop Australia's natural resources;
(e) granting visas to Taiwanese Government Ministers to enable them to come to Australia and develop stronger economic and cultural relationships with the Australian-Chinese communities; and
(f) attracting Taiwanese undergraduates to complete their tertiary education and graduate students to pursue advanced studies in Australian universities.

This legislation is a start but let us go on with the job. Why do we single out Taiwan? Why must we have other countries telling us what we can and cannot do as far as our relationship with Taiwan is concerned? Surely we can make up our own minds. What is more, nothing in the 1972 manifesto conflicts with any of these issues. The pertinent clause reads:

The Australian Government recognises the Government of the People's Republic of China as the sole legal Government of China, acknowledges the position of the Chinese Government that Taiwan is a province of the People's Republic of China, and has decided to remove its official representation from Taiwan before 25 January 1973.

That is the only reference. There is nothing there that prevents Australia from doing any of the things that I have suggested or that were suggested by Senator Hill. Right now we need Taiwanese investment in Australia. We need to further increase the amount of trade between us. We need the Taiwanese to invest in Australia in steel mills, fishing plants, electrical goods manufacture, processed food factories and so on. Honourable senators should remember that at this stage Australia still has a foreign debt of about $130 billion, while Taiwan has a credit balance of about $US75 billion, second only to Japan in the world. We should also remember that Taiwan has had a gross domestic product growth of over 8 per cent for the past 15 years. Taiwan's GDP was $US300 in 1949; in 1989 it is now up to $US7,230. Its interest rates are about 9 per cent and the inflation level about 2 3/4 per cent. Taiwan's unemployment-or over-employment-has it with a deficit employment figure of about 6 per cent, so great is its economic expansion. I remind honourable senators that Taiwan is about half the size of Tasmania.

If we pursue higher education as an industry and as an arrangement with Taiwan we should be able to gather an extra $400m or $500m a year. If we encourage investment I believe it is possible that we could gain about $1 billion to $1 1/2 billion a year from Taiwan. If we encourage tourism we should be able to increase what we now have five or 10 times over. There are fewer than 20,000 people each way at the moment when each country has about two million tourists a year. We still process our visas in Hong Kong. It takes 10 or 12 days for anybody from Taiwan to come to Australia that way. As I said before, although we have no direct flights and no tourist offices, we are in this position with our trade; we want to be able to build further on it.

Senator Hill mentioned the job done by Bill Mattingly and the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Taipei. I too would like to give enormous credit to the work that Mr Mattingly has done on behalf of Australian industry and in making the connections between Australia and Taiwan. It has been absolutely fantastic. I am aware that more and more senators, Government and Opposition alike, are going to Taiwan and every time I talk to them they seem to come back more and more impressed.

What surprises me is that I am now finding that in some respects it is far easier for people from Taiwan to deal with, go to and have various intercourse with the people on the mainland than it is for Australians. Why? We do, or do not do various things because of our perception that we might offend the People's Republic of China. The people from Taiwan can go to the mainland for bank meetings, sporting contests, family reunions, educational visits, to establish businesses and so on, yet we say we could not do that because it might upset the People's Republic of China. What an extraordinary thing! Why do we not get on and bring things up to date? This is now 1989. We are just about to verge on 1990. Let us please go back to where we were before 1972 and, without doing anything at this juncture contrary to the agreement that we have got, let us please start to bring things up to date in our relationship with Taiwan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

So with those words, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to take this opportunity, in debating the Family Law Amendment Bill, to highlight a number of areas in which I believe the Family Law Act is not functioning as well as it should or might be. In doing so, I accept what this Bill is trying to do. I note that the Bill will amend the present Family Law Act of 1975 to implement recommendations from the Australian Law Reform Commission concerning enforcement of orders made under the Act and will provide additional facilities relating to sentencing alternatives. It will also permit courts to order the arrest of people who contravene access or custody orders and will strengthen injunctions made for the personal safety of people involved in family law proceedings. All these issues are vital to people presently experiencing enormous difficulties relating to family law matters.

SPEECH.PARA: For those of us who have never experienced a marriage break-up such issues as access and custody are foreign. But the reality is that in Australia at the present time approximately one in three marriages will end in divorce and, of those who remarry, 50 per cent will seek another divorce. We are, therefore, talking about amendments that affect a very large number of people in the community. Probably the most vital aspects of family law are the provisions relating to access and custody. Understandably, these issues are the hardest to tackle and the most acrimonious debate is associated with these two particular problems.

Traditionally in the Western world, and certainly in the eyes of the Family Court, the mother is the carer of children and natural custodian. Yet I am told by the Lone Fathers Association that in fact there are in Australia at the present time 120,000 fathers looking after children on their own. As a community, we probably do not realise that there are many fathers out there looking after children. Certainly our work force and employment conditions make little acknowledgment of that particular fact. While child-care facilities and issues such as maternity leave are becoming more acceptable to employers, the issue of paternity leave is only just coming to the surface.

The Lone Fathers Association and other groups such as Parents Without Rights have fought for a long time to have society in general, and the courts in particular, acknowledge that fathers are also child carers and sole parents. Therefore, in light of the experience of their members this organisation has been a very strong advocate for revision of the Family Law Act. This group and dozens of others like it have to deal with the reality of marriage break-up every day of the year. They know the failings and weaknesses of the present legislation as well as any because they deal regularly with the administrative results. The Lone Fathers Association alone gets 3,000 calls from fathers with custody and access difficulties.

My involvement with family law and its administration has come about only since my election to the Senate-in fact, even more recently than that. Earlier this year the State conference of my Party passed a resolution calling for a thorough review of the Family Law Act and for a Senate or full parliamentary inquiry. As the only National Party Senator for New South Wales, I was approached and asked to facilitate such an inquiry. In the intervening months I have sought to do that, and on 17 October this year I gave notice of a motion which in part called for a full parliamentary inquiry into the Family Law Act and its present interpretation as soon as practicable after the commencement of the next Parliament, with particular attention being given to such issues as custody, access, maintenance and property disputes. I place on record the support that I have received from Government Ministers and senators and also the Australian Democrats on this issue. It is a matter of history that the National and Liberal parties' law and justice policy also supports such an inquiry. I quote from the relevant sections of that policy:

Review of Family Law-Community concerns about the Family Law Act will be addressed by a parliamentary committee which will review the operations of the Family Court and family law and some of the basic principles on which issues of great importance are determined.

As I said, I trust and hope that there will be a bipartisan approach to this Act by all parties after the next election. I believe that such a review is essential. Since I started my quest for this review I have heard some of the saddest stories I am ever likely to hear. One cannot imagine the pain and bitterness that are involved when a family separates. I do not believe that any piece of legislation can be perfect, particularly when it deals with such sensitive issues as children, access, custody and property. Equally, however, I do not believe that this Act and, more importantly, the interpretation and present administration of it, are fair. I believe that the present family law courts are failing the people who go to them seeking help. There are too many bizarre examples of justice for it to be accidental, but I will not go into detail on these today.

We need to get some sort of equity back into the system that deals with inequities. We do not have the wisdom of Solomon but I think we as law-makers must create a more effective justice than that which we have at present. I welcome the amendments contained in this legislation but they do not get right to the core of the problems that beset the family law. I accept that we can do little about establishing a parliamentary inquiry into this issue prior to the election, but, as I have already said, I intend to persist with and pursue this issue immediately the election is over. I repeat: I hope there is a bipartisan approach to this issue after the election.

The frustrations that people are experiencing need to be addressed. We cannot put them into the too hard basket and hope that they go away. We know what can happen when people go past their boiling point. Sadly, some family law judges have been killed and others are under 24-hour security, which indicates the seriousness of the problem. I am told that, in most cases of violence resulting from family law actions, it is lack of access to one's children that causes men, and presumably, women to become violent. Is access to be a privilege, or is to be a right? How do the courts assess custody and access? A large number of people in the community believe that these issues are judged very unfairly at the moment. The Family Law Act was hailed in 1975 as a breakthrough in the resolution of family disputes. The concept and, indeed, the legislation have many positive aspects. We need to examine these positive aspects and examine critically the down side of the law and realise that we have perhaps replaced one inexorable and unfair system with another.

The couples that are childless may both agree to divorce and where mutual agreement on property is reached, family law works well. It is a civilised and equitable system to end a marriage. If divorce cannot be painless then at least for those people the present family law system is the least painful. For those with children the present law clearly is not working.

I note that the recent Child Support (Assessment) Act has been criticised by the Law Council of Australia, which is concerned about the huge financial and social implications for second families that the implementations of the courts will increase as the Act applies to more and more families. This Act established a formula whereby set percentages are deemed an appropriate maintenance level for children. So a non-custodial parent with one child would pay 18 per cent of taxable income; two children, 27 per cent; three children, 32 per cent, and so on. The legislation has already placed enormous burdens on men with second families, yet this aspect appears not to have been considered by the draftsmen when this Act was drawn up.

Returning to this legislation, I accept that the amendments are a step in the right direction, but I do not believe that they get to the core of the problem. Even these amendments have some difficulties. I know that the Lone Fathers Association is concerned that State police, for example, should have the same powers in family law matters as Federal police. When access is denied there is little recourse for non-custodial parents and these amendments do not do much to streamline the procedure one needs to follow. It is at present necessary to develop a case of denied access and even then, in real terms, there is little that can be done. These amendments strengthen that a little but do not avoid the delays in having to go to court in the first place. That is a lengthy and potentially expensive exercise and it would seem more often than not that it is a waste of time. We must improve what we have. Mr Acting Deputy President I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a petitioning letter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
23 October 1989
Senator Brownhill
467 Peel Street
TAMWORTH 2430
Dear Senator,

We the undersigned concerned citizens, wish to bring to your notice our dissatisfaction with the present legislation pertaining to the Family Law Act. Whilst the Act, as it stands might make divorce easier, child custody has become another ``possession'', along with property settlement on the matrimonial battleground.

The Family Law Act concerns all citizens, and society as a whole has a responsibility to ensure that children caught between this conflict are not socially deprived of equal access to both parents wherever possible, a human right necessary for normal childhood development.

We suggest that the Family Law Act as it stands, frustrates and antagonises many people into violence. Research suggests that as high as one quarter of all murder victims in Australia are killed by a family member. This fact alone is a telling sign of the inadequacies of the present enactment. Further to this, it is all too easy for one partner to make allegations that a child of the marriage has been sexually abused by the estranged partner. American studies have shown that a high percentage of these alleged abuses do not occur.

Accordingly, we request that representations be made on our behalf to bring to the notice of the legislature our dissatisfaction of the Family Law legislation and further request urgent action be taken to address a totally unacceptable situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We must improve what we have; these amendments do that, but family law needs more than these amendments. I call on all honourable senators to support a parliamentary inquiry into family law administration following the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill was called out unexpectedly; I know he wanted to speak in this debate. For the benefit of time, I seek leave to have his notes incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The notes read as follows-

One of the most significant changes introduced by this Bill, and one which the Opposition welcomes, is the addition of community service orders to the penalties available to the Court for breach of orders. This will fill the gap which currently exists between minor sanctions and the most serious penalty, imprisonment, which courts are understandably reluctant to use in any but the most serious cases.

The Government has also at last recognised the usefulness of stipulating a maximum length of imprisonment in matrimonial causes. The Bill provides for the current open-ended provision to be replaced with a 12-month maximum.

In this Bill, the definition of ``judge'' for the purposes of section 14 is extended to include Judicial Registrars and Registrars of the Family Court. This is to make it clear that they all have the same obligation to consider the possibility of reconciliation between the parties to proceedings under the Act, and to direct counselling where appropriate. The emphasis on reconciliation and counselling is of course one which the Opposition strongly supports.

This Bill also confers on the Court the power, where a section 64 search warrant has been issued for a child, to order a person having information about the whereabouts of the child to provide that information to the court.

A significant change introduced by this Bill is the provision for registration of child maintenance agreements in respect of ex-nuptial children. Such agreements can already be lodged in respect of children of a marriage, but the provision for children born outside marriage is a new one, and one which is welcomed by the Opposition. Of course, this would only apply in those four States which have referred the power to legislate with respect to ex-nuptial children to the Commonwealth.
Under this Bill, the provisions in the Act dealing with sanctions for contravention of custody and access orders and injunctions, and contempt of court will be unified.
The following sanctions will be available, and they may be used singly or in combination:
imprisonment for a maximum of 12 months, which can only be imposed if the court is satisfied that there is no other way of dealing with the contravention;
suspended sentences;
fines of up to $2000 for a natural person or $10000 for a body corporate;
recognizances to be of good behaviour for up to 2 years;
community-based options such as community service orders, with a maximum number of 500 hours;
sequestration;
requirement to deliver a document to the Registrar, such as a passport; and
compensatory access orders, which are a new sanction, designed to make up for access which is lost as a result of the breach of an access order.

Other changes include the transfer of the Australian Institute of Family Studies from the Attorney-General's Department to the Department of Social Security, purportedly because of the impact of A.I.F.S. reports on the social security system.

The Opposition is supporting this Bill, and in particular we welcome the broadening of the range of sentencing options available as sanctions against contravention of court orders, and the clear statement that imprisonment is the sanction of last resort.

The only other comment that I would like to make in relation to this Bill, is to reiterate the Coalition position that, in view of the widespread community dissatisfaction with many aspects of family law and the Family Court system, they should be referred to a Committee for thorough review.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this Bill. In particular, we welcome the broadening of the range of sentencing options available as sanctions against the contravention of court orders and the clear statement that imprisonment is a sanction of last resort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was listening to the erudite remarks of my Opposition colleague Senator Brownhill, it took me as a wild fancy that here we are on the fourth day of the fifth successive sitting week on the eve of Christmas spending our lunchtime talking about family law. It could be that we would all be better off back home practising some family relationships. Let us therefore dispense with this legislation as quickly as we can.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Brownhill for his considered and thoughtful contribution to this debate. Many of the sentiments he expressed about the trauma and difficulty attending family breakup and the consequential problems associated when custody and property matters are involved, I understand and share. Senator Brownhill made a pitch for continued bipartisan support after the next election, the implication being that after the next election I might be sitting where he is and he sitting where I am. I do not accept the implication that the Government, after the next election, will continue to welcome the Opposition's support on measures such as this. On that basis I commend the Bill for a second reading.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.42 to 2 p.m.
