I ask: Did the Minister confirm that an Australian Minister would attend the opening of a steel mill in China next year? Did he advise Senator Evans accordingly? Is not such a confirmation a breach of the 13 July constraints on the relationship?

—I welcome Senator Hill's belated efforts actually to ask me a question on this matter, although I believe it to be outside my portfolio. The allegation about the steel mill is not outside my portfolio and I intend to answer that question. Senator Hill has been making allegations, on radio and in here over the last couple of days, which, as I said yesterday, are not true. Now at last I have a question. In terms of the question put to me, I will say that the truth in respect of that allegation is that there was no such commitment.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. I refer the Minister to a report in the 19 December issue of the Courier-Mail which claims that the average number of advertisements in program breaks on television has increased from three to five in the past two years. Is the Minister aware that this report also reveals that there have been uniform increases in the average number of advertisements in all time slots? If this increase is due to the decision by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) to repeal advertising time rules for a two-year trial period, is the Government satisfied that television stations have responded responsibly to self-regulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of press reports of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's review of television advertising which shows an average increase in the number of advertisements during each interruption. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is the independent body responsible for the administration of broadcasting standards, including the question of the amount of advertising time permitted on commercial stations. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has not concluded its inquiry into the matter and it would be, therefore, somewhat premature for the Minister to comment, if indeed he wished to comment at all, before the ABT finished its inquiry. I understand that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is accepting submissions from interested parties until 5 March and public conferences are scheduled for May 1990, giving what we hope will be ample time for debate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Government's submission to the Industrial Relations Commission to increase substantially the salary package of about 1,600 members of the Commonwealth Senior Executive Service (SES). Is it true that, if this submission is approved, some Senior Executive Service members at the top of the pay scale are set to receive increases in the order of 30 per cent, the same sort of rise sought by pilots and so bitterly opposed by the Government on the ground that it would wreck the wages system? I just say to the Minister in putting this question that I certainly acknowledge the need to retain talented senior public servants and to provide more market related packages to do so. But I ask: How does the Government propose to justify increases of this magnitude within the accord framework so that other employees in Australia will have some better idea of what the rules of the game actually are?

—I do not have a great deal of information about this matter, but let me say that, as I understand it, the submission is considered by the Commonwealth to be consistent with the structural efficiency principles and with the current wage fixing guidelines in terms of the percentage payable to the work force generally. This decision also involves changes in work value. But my understanding is that members of the SES are in a somewhat anomalous position compared with the general work force in the sense that there has been no major review of salaries in this area for a very long time. I will try to obtain some further information for the honourable senator, but I think the submission was crafted to be in line with the structural efficiency principle.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer and note that he is going to seek further information. Again I stress that my view is that these changes are certainly warranted in view of the loss of very good senior managers from the Public Service. In getting that further information, will he seek confirmation that one of the major reasons for making the change is that in fact there is a serious risk of losing further senior officers simply because they are not getting comparable wage and salary packages with equivalent private sector managers and that, rather than changes in work value or any matters relating to structural efficiency, underlies this proposal by the Government? In that framework, will the Minister see that the reply covers the question of when demand for labour and the inability to maintain people in positions are relevant factors in determining wage increases? For example, staff who service aircraft have been in very short supply in Australia because the wages offered are simply not high enough to get the required number; so it is a matter of great practical importance. Will he examine that point in giving his further reply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can answer that question. In respect of the first part of the question, let me say that for some two years at least that I can remember there has been concern about the relative level of SES salaries compared with salaries offered in the private sector and there has been considerable wastage from the public sector into the private sector because of those very substantial salary differentials, apart from other things. The proposal being put to the Industrial Relations Commission in respect of Public Service salaries will not in itself address that problem because the discrepancies or differences are considerably greater still than will be rectified by this proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: I think in the second part of the question, Senator Chaney referred to the problem, of which we have all been aware, of aircraft maintenance personnel and the particular problem which Qantas Airways Ltd has had in attracting and retaining highly skilled maintenance personnel for aircraft. That is a particularly dramatic example, in the Qantas case, of skill shortage in the labour market and that has exacerbated the already difficult problems of salary differentials in terms of pirating from firms such as Qantas and so on. I do not recall the exact figures but I think Qantas brought some 60 licensed aircraft engineers from overseas and lost about 40 of them in two months. I think that is a most dramatic case. I do not think one can solve skill shortage problems by application of salary increases in terms of looking at an aggregate industry picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case Qantas is in a straitjacket.

—Let me, in terms of the original question, refer to the Qantas pilots situation. The Qantas pilots situation has turned out to be totally different from the domestic airline pilots situation, the domestic airline pilots having sought a 30 per cent increase which for a long time was not negotiable, in their terms. The Qantas pilots have, through their appropriate organisation, negotiated what was in fact a 13 or 14 per cent increase. It was regarded as consistent with the structural efficiency principle and was one which they, I think, worked hard at justifying in the Industrial Relations Commission, with undoubted success. One sees that difference in approach between the Qantas airline pilots and the domestic airline pilots. There is also, of course, capacity within the industrial relations legislation for people to seek certified agreements. There was a further ratification by the Commission last week, or early this week, of a certified agreement between Comalco--
—A further one? That is the one you have been talking about interminably.

—Even at the end of the year, when most honourable senator's are getting tired, Senator Stone seems to get more awake. I congratulate him on a splendid interjection. I have talked a lot about that. I have talked about it in terms of the principle involved. What we should all be grateful for is that the Industrial Relations Commission has recognised the principle.
—One.

—No, not one; there are others. But I do not want to talk about them because that will remind Senator Stone that I have already talked about them during the course of the year. But there are others. There is scope, of course, within the existing legislation for people to seek certificated agreements which will take account of some of the problems to which Senator Chaney adverted. On the specific question of the SES salaries I will try to obtain further information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Following the election of the Goss Labor Government I ask: Have State and Federal relations improved? In particular, can the Minister inform the Senate whether the recent change in Queensland has enhanced prospects of concluding an agreement for the funding of legal aid services in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am delighted indeed that I can report to Senator Jones that there has been a breakthrough in negotiations following the change of government in Queensland which has secured the future of the State's legal aid system. Indeed, today, together with my colleague the Queensland Attorney-General Mr Deane Wells, we are announcing a $37m package to provide for the legal aid requirements of all Queenslanders. This follows more than a year of frustration and delay because of the refusal of the former National Party Government to genuinely negotiate. Indeed, I have to tell the Senate that, unfortunately, decisions taken by the outgoing National Party Attorney-General during the election campaign had the effect of preventing aid in family law matters and to social security beneficiaries, which was absolutely dastardly, particularly as it was done during the campaign. But we overcame those problems.

ANSWER.PARA: The new arrangements for the Queensland Legal Aid Commission provide for a 55:45 percentage split between the Commonwealth and the State in the provision of its net operating costs. This will help to ensure access to the legal system for all Queenslanders. It is important for them to be able to vindicate their rights and to be effectively represented, particularly when facing a criminal charge which may result, especially, in imprisonment. The change of government in Queensland heralds, I believe, a new era of constructive cooperation between our two governments. This is a particular instance of where the social justice strategies of both governments mesh and are effective for all Queenslanders. Essentially the agreement puts a floor under the level of funding based on a long term commitment by both governments to the maintenance of an effective legal aid system. There has been a recognition by both sides of the legitimate role of the Commonwealth and State governments in the provision of adequate legal aid. Every other State and the Northern Territory have already indicated agreement with the Commonwealth. The result of Mr Wells's constructive approach is that Queenslanders are now guaranteed the protection of legal aid which had previously been in jeopardy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHINESE STUDENTS: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMANENT RESIDENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. How many applications for permanent residence have been received by the Government since 4 June 1989 from Chinese students in Australia? Given the fact that almost certain reprisals face Chinese students currently in Australia upon their return to China, how quickly are these applications being dealt with and how many have so far been granted? How many of the Chinese students in Australia took part in pro-democracy demonstrations against the Government of the People's Republic of China (PRC)? Are these students, who are particularly vulnerable to reprisals, being given special and sympathetic consideration regarding their applications for permanent resident status?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any figures immediately available, but I will fill in the background for Senator Haines's benefit so she can understand what the approach has been. On 16 June the Prime Minister announced that all PRC nationals in Australia could remain in Australia, irrespective of whether they were here illegally or legally, until 31 July 1990. One of the reasons for that extension was so that at some stage this Government could do an assessment of the position in China because one could not predict, immediately after those events, whether things would settle down or move in a particular direction. We were not anxious at that stage to encourage people to put in applications without knowing what the circumstances would be down the track.

ANSWER.PARA: Because we are now half way to that cut-off point, two weeks ago I announced that PRC nationals in Australia could extend their stay and that we would extend our protective umbrella to those people until 31 January 1991. I also said that it would be necessary for those in Australia to have valid temporary entry permits. Those who were here legally on 20 June may apply between 15 January 1990 and 31 March 1990 to stay here. Those who are here illegally may also apply for a temporary entry permit for the same period between 15 January and 31 March and they also will have protection until 31 January 1991.

I think that the time has now come for me to say that if PRC nationals in Australia believe they qualify for refugee status or whatever in this country, now is the time to apply. Whilst for the first six months after the Prime Minister's announcement we said that there was no need to hurry, we would like people to start applying-at least to apply before 31 July 1990. Normally any delay in people applying for refugee status could be taken by the relevant committee as people not being serious. We have made it quite clear in this case that that will not be a factor that intrudes in the assessment, but if people wait until after 31 July next year to apply for refugee status it may be considered that they are not serious.

Senator Haines asked me how many students participated in pro-democracy demonstrations in Australia. I do not know-I suspect 500 per cent more than actually did. But any one of these claims in the refugee area will be dealt with individually unless Cabinet, in its consideration of the overall Chinese position, decides otherwise. I will get Senator Haines the figures of how many people have applied so far. One thing she will notice is that more forms have gone out than there are PRC nationals in Australia, but many have not been filled in. I reiterate once again, even though it was part of Senator Haines's question, that recently we have made four grants-in-aid available to different Chinese organisations to give advice in this area. We have made money available to the refugee advisory case work service to advise Chinese students. Let us urge all that we know to use those services and not the shysters in the legal profession that have only one thing in mind-money.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I ask that the Minister give his answer to the Senate tomorrow, if at all possible, because there is wide interest in the Senate in the supplementary answer he may give.
—There is certainly no point of order, but you have--

—I take it, Mr President, that Senator Haines is a good ventriloquist and asked her supplementary question through Senator Teague. I am sure that I can make the figures available by tomorrow but, if I cannot, I cannot. However, I have a record of usually following up questions the next day.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister seen reports of overseas sales and other developments which indicate encouraging prospects for our coal industry? Has the Federal Government any programs or initiatives in place to assist the coal industry in terms of both sales and research and development? Is the Minister aware of any plans to abolish or limit any of these programs and initiatives? Further, is the Minister aware of warnings in yesterday's Australian newspaper by Ms Meredith Hellicar, the Executive Director of the New South Wales Coal Association, that further big increases in New South Wales Government charges could `threaten the viability of the industry's recovery?'

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can take the last part of the question first, I am aware of the expressions of concern uttered by Ms Meredith Hellicar, who appears to be now the new Executive Director of the New South Wales Coal Association. They were reported in yesterday's Australian. Yes, Senator Faulkner has accurately quoted her anxiety that the New South Wales State Government could threaten the viability of the industry's recovery. The quote goes on:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Government charges-rail freight, port loaders and coal royalties-had all risen strongly in the last year.
Ms Hellicar said the industry's stronger position was largely due to extensive restructuring of the work force, recommended by the Coal Industry Tribunal in 1988.
However, she said it was still early days and the association regarded the profit as part of an embryonic recovery.
`The industry must continue to restructure the workforce, which goes hand in hand with reducing costs'. . . .

Thus it is we have a concern on behalf of the New South Wales coal industry about what State government taxes and charges are doing to a profitability margin that is creeping up because of the structural reforms that this Government has managed to put in place and because of the decision of the Coal Industry Tribunal.

If I can go back to the earlier part of Senator Faulkner's question, the Australian coal industry is at this stage, given the fortunes of wool, probably our largest single export earner. It shipped from mine production 150 million tonnes last year, 99.3 per cent of which went to overseas markets. It earned, in 1988-89, $4.7 billion and, since it shipped more in 1989-90 than it did the previous year, will earn more this financial year. It employs over 30,000 Australians.

The Commonwealth Government has tried to assist the development of the coal industry in three ways: firstly, through grants for research and development through the national energy, research, development and demonstration program. Yesterday we passed Bills to enable the establishment of a coal research and development corporation which we hope the industry will pick up. That will encourage further research and development into not only better mining techniques but also cleaner-burning technology to enhance the sales of our product.

The two other significant bodies that we have in place are one with the New South Wales Government-the Joint Coal Board-and one of our own, the Coal Marketing and Technology Council. The purpose of the Technology Council is to enhance our coal export trade and to do a number of things in the promotion of coal associated with improved technology. The Joint Coal Board is a joint body between the Commonwealth and the State and does a whole range of activities concerning improving the productivity of mining, better health and safety, better training, and so on. It is the intention, it would appear, of the Opposition-if its program as outlined in the Economic Action Plan were to be realised-to abolish both the Joint Coal Board and the Coal Marketing and Technology Council at a time when industry spokesmen are saying that the New South Wales Government is pinching their profit by higher taxes and charges and to abolish two of the three Federal mechanisms that we have in place to try to improve the fortunes of this industry. This is at a time when we all know that, given as well the abolition proposal for capital gains tax, the President of the Liberal Party is to obtain a windfall gain of $18m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Minister been petitioned by locally engaged staff of the Australian Consulate-General in Hong Kong requesting the opportunity to migrate to Australia prior to the return to Chinese rule in 1997, in effect as a form of insurance? Is not a similar form of protection to staff being offered by other countries such as the United States, France and New Zealand? What is the position of the Government on this matter? Has the Minister responded to the petition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall seeing a petition from these particular locally engaged staff members in Hong Kong, most of whom have got a great track record in terms of serving this country. The overall policy, I think, rather than just the policy for those who work for the Australian Government, must be under consideration, although there are a lot of myths about, I must say, as to what some other countries are doing. By the time they reach Australia they tend to reach mammoth proportions and, on investigation with those home countries, then start to disappear.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been asked by different insurance companies who have staff there and others as to what the long term prospects for migration to Australia are. The general answer we give them is that, if they qualify, they may come to Australia and that, if they do not qualify, they are like anyone else. The more difficult question to solve is that, when they qualify to come, most of those companies do not want them to leave immediately. However, if they do not have some sort of long-term security and offer, they run the risk of being poached by another country. This raises a dilemma for us. Do we modify our very non-discriminatory policy and well-thought-out criteria for entry into this country in these circumstances? Of course, one of the answers long term is that many of these people who qualify under employer nomination could well come to Australia and then return short term to Hong Kong. That seems to have satisfied the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong-to explore those possibilities.

Locally engaged staff traditionally have had, though, a degree of entitlement over and above others to come to Australia. Some, I believe-I say `believe' because I have not had this confirmed-may have already been visa'd to come to Australia. Others may not have at this stage. There would be also, I think, some provision under the special eligibility criteria for migration to Australia, which covers a wide range of things, for these people to qualify under that particular scheme as well.

We also have to be conscious, though, that we do not generally go out and recruit around the world. We do not have to; we have too many inquiries as it is. People in Hong Kong are suffering from the problem of brain drain; it is a problem to the authorities in Hong Kong and we do not want to be out there actively recruiting in this regard unless it is by way of employer nomination. Hence, that is the way the Qantas Airways Ltd engineers from Hong Kong have come to Australia. For most people, employer nomination is the best route in terms of people who have served Australia well overseas. They normally are given some possibility to migrate to the country, but they must come-I think Senator Archer would have to agree-within cooee of our normal immigration requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister may have heard on the news this morning that the United Kingdom is making special arrangements for some of its people on the basis of providing them with visas now so that they will stay there. The 51 people who have petitioned the Australian Government, or who work for the Australian Government now, are in exactly the same position. If they do not get some prospect for the future after 1997, they may well leave now. We have still to run Austrade and the Immigration Department and various other things there. We need these staff to remain in Hong Kong. Has the Minister considered providing them with visas so that they will stay there until 1997, with the right to come to Australia if it is necessary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with that approach is that, once we make one exception, we make thousands world-wide and we do not have uniform criteria. As I said, in certain cases some of these people will qualify to come to Australia in any event. Some may come to Australia and return to Hong Kong to work in any event. But do not talk to me about the generosity of the United Kingdom and its treatment of people in Hong Kong. Already 4,000 or 5,000 people from Hong Kong are migrating to Australia every year, whereas Great Britain and/or Mrs Thatcher, the Prime Minister, are saying, `You can all stay out there'.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the best advice I can give-gratuitous advice, only as Immigration Minister, not as the spokesman on foreign affairs, in this chamber-is to let a lot of those people from Hong Kong enter Great Britain, firstly, to improve the cuisine. And I can tell the Senate now that the Tobys and Nigels of the stock exchange will not be drifting into work at 11 o'clock in the morning. They will either get there at 6 o'clock in the morning or they will be out of a job the next day, because Hong Kong is a vibrant, energetic community that has made enormous strides over the last two or three decades. So I do not think we can ever say that Great Britain generally has been overall more generous than we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is it a fact that the Federal Court has brought down its decision in the case concerning the New South Wales forests brought against the Minister by the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF)? Can the Minister advise honourable senators what the terms were of the court's decision? Is he in a position to advise what the implications of the decision are for the Government's policy for a settlement of the forests issue in the south-east of New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Conservation Foundation, joined by an applicant, Michael Stanley Harewood, took an application against me under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act on the basis that I had misconducted myself in declaring, examining and arriving at a prudent and feasible alternative to logging in National Estate in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales. Mr Justice Davies yesterday delivered a decision in Sydney on that application. The best way of answering the question `what did the decision do' is to quote from the minutes of the order under the heading `The Court orders' on the facing page of that decision. It says that the application be dismissed and that the applicant pay the respondent's costs of the proceedings. On the basis of that I take the 49 pages of decision that follow those orders as a vindication of the process I entered into to discover whether there were prudent and feasible alternative to logging in the National Estate in the New South Wales south-eastern forests. I note that the court has ordered the applicants to pay the costs of the proceedings; that is a decision of the court. Given the length of the case, I have to observe, in passing, that that will indeed be a fairly weighty cost.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not mean that, Senator. The question as to the terms of the decision is best answered by my being consistent in my practice on this matter of conducting our affairs openly and transparently tabling the terms of the decision, so that the Senate can have access to it and through it the public can be aware of the terms of the decision at an earlier date than it might otherwise be published.

ANSWER.PARA: Going to the other questions from Senator Schacht, I do not believe that it was necessary for the ACF to take out this application. My door has always been open and I am always available to consult on matters of this nature. Indeed, I have put in the public domain all of the information which was, by the court process, adduced in court as well. With respect to the other parts of the question concerning implications, Professor Bryant Richards, who heads the study team into the flora and fauna properties of the south-east forests will report to me at three o'clock today on his interim findings as to the properties of the south-east forests in the study area, and I will release tomorrow his report for public consumption, again consistent with my policy of open and transparent activity in this area.

In the beginning of the year the Commonwealth Government was criticised by, among others, Ian Causley, the Minister for Natural Resources in New South Wales, for improperly calculating the resource necessary to sustain the industry for 12 months. We have come to the end of our calculations and I am pleased to advise the Senate that the Commonwealth calculations in that process have been proven to be right. The industry has been sustained at the proper levels for the whole of that year and we have kept faith with that undertaking. Thus, what was held to be a device by us to misrepresent our intention is in fact no longer viable. We have performed as we said we would.

Finally, if there is a Christmas message in all of this for anyone, I would like to say that the workers in the industry deserve some recognition because, while I in no way criticise the sincerity and the idealism of environmental protesters in the south-east forests, the ordinary Australian workers who have been subjected to those protests and who are carrying out the directions of their companies ought not in any circumstances to be the meat in the sandwich. Their cause needs some consideration and I wish to record my recognition of their restraint and discipline in those circumstances and say to them, through this question, that we will get our resource calculations right again next year and we will be able to deliver to them employment security within the terms of what we seek to achieve in that agreement and that the actions of the Commonwealth are equally balanced in protecting employment and achieving a proper and genuine environmental outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It follows the answer he gave in Question Time yesterday to a question concerning Romania. What is the Australian Government's assessment of international responses to the current situation in Timisoara, Bucharest and other regions of Romania following the Romanian Army's massacre of its own citizens on Sunday? What initiatives has the Australian Government developed or responded to, in addition to those indicated yesterday, towards international sanctions against the Romanian Government to ensure that our own outrage and protest is well understood, that the Helsinki Accords are upheld and that such brutal measures are not repeated? In particular, will the Minister ensure that the Australian Ambassador to Romania communicates to the Romanian Government the resolution unanimously adopted here in the Senate yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite obvious the way the rest of the world has reacted to events in Romania. For the first time ever Eastern bloc countries are coming out and condemning the Romanian Government. The only difference is that these days there is no invasion following one of the Eastern bloc countries getting out of line. This is the first time one has got out of line more at the Stalinist end than at the libertarian end. In terms of what this Government has done, the Foreign Minister issued his press statement in Paris, I think it was. Mr Duffy issued a press statement yesterday. The Government did not quibble at all with the Senate's time being used yesterday to make the views of this nation known. As regards the final part of the question, I will ask someone to make sure that our Ambassador who covers the region passes on the Senate's resolution to the Romanian Government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. How did the Minister determine which group should receive funding from the $100,000 paid through his Department to organisations opposing the construction of a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport? Which organisations were denied funding and why? Is it true that groups receiving funding are predominantly Australian Labor Party dominated councils and groups run by officeholders of the ALP? Finally, how will funds be accounted for and what studies of the impact of a third runway will be conducted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Dunn would be aware, from the time the Government announced the third runway decision it was determined that the environmental impact statement (EIS) would be rigorous. Given that the interests, and possibly the health and safety of several hundred thousand people-certainly is so far as it was perceived by them-were to suffer immediate effects, a number of community groups, some of which had been there for quite some time and some to which were new, sought to fight the decision. Certainly, all of them wanted to make sure that they had a proper input into the EIS process. I think they were entitled to that desire.

ANSWER.PARA: Both the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, and I received quite a number of representations from community groups. I think what they were suggesting to us was that they wanted to be able to completely contribute to and review the technical issues which would be apparent in a draft EIS. They wanted to make sure that, when we reached the period for public comment, their comments were as educated as possible.

A number of groups presented proposals. Essentially they came from three groups: the Second Sydney Airport Coalition, the Airport Coordination Task Force and the Residents Opposition to the Third Runway. RORT, as the Residents Opposition to the Third Runway termed itself, and the SSAC-the Airport Coalition-had asked for money for noise studies. In particular they wanted those studies to be conducted by a Dr Bullen. The decision which Mr Willis and I came to was that provided Senator Walsh was in agreement-and that is an agreement that we have yet to secure formally-$100,000 could be transferred from Mr Willis's Department, which does not have any programs under which this sort of money can be paid, to mine, which does, so we could make money available for that purpose. As I understand it, Dr Bullen has already been sitting in on seminars that Kinhills have been conducting on the third runway and his expertise will be applied to noise studies over the coming months.

The group to which Senator Dunn referred as being dominated by ALP councils is a pretty broad group indeed. First off, it should be stated that around the airport there are quite a number of councils and they are pretty well all Labor. The fact that they are Labor councils does not mean that they are in some way prevented from contributing. The fact is that the people of those regions have voted for them in droves for all of their lives and the lives of their parents and grandparents, so why should they not be represented? I do not see that as hindering their capacity in any way. They are the elected representatives of the people. I might say that it is not just a Labor Party group, it is open to all councils. Councils such as Hunters Hill and Lane Cove have chosen not to be associated with the working class, and that is up to them. But now we face the situation where, even amongst those councils-from memory, at least two-they have independent mayors. The two councils are Leichhardt and Rockdale. My understanding is that they will continue to take part in the group. I certainly hope that is the case.

Associated with that group are quite a number of community groups such as Marrickville Airport Watch and a number of groups in the Rockdale and Botany area. So they are not all Labor Party groups: a whole range of groups are associated with that council-led group. On the basis that noise studies were to be well and truly covered by the applications made by the other two groups, they have sought to have money allocated for a number of other studies. These would involve hydrological studies in Botany Bay. Clearly, no matter where one stands on the third runway issue, there must be an effect on Botany Bay. Given that it provides a recreational amenity for hundreds of thousands of people in Sydney, there is no reason why studies should not be conducted on it. There are other health and safety aspects which concerned people there, not to mention studies on the economics of a third runway as against alternatives which must also be covered in the EIS.

What Mr Willis and I were faced with were, in our view, two entirely legitimate requests for funding, and we are meeting them. We are still to determine whether or not we will pay the money directly to the consultants who are being employed for the purpose of studying these things or whether we will pay it to the groups. But whatever happens, we will be absolutely certain that every dollar of it is accountable. I would hope that an agreement on exactly how the money can be paid, and an agreement with Senator Walsh, can be completed in the next few weeks. Then we will proceed to make sure the interests of Sydney residents-hundreds of thousands of them are involved-are properly covered. That, I would have thought, is the essence of good government and this is a good government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the $21m in the Commonwealth transitional funding trust account for the Australian Capital Territory and the Prime Minister's undertaking last month to make $7m of that amount available. I ask: When will the funds be made available to the Australian Capital Territory Government?
—Mr President, the trust account concerned is under the control of the Treasurer and not the Finance Minister, so I will have to get an answer from the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware of comments made over the last few days by Mr Bernard Collaery, Deputy Chief Minister in the Australian Capital Territory, linking the new migration legislation and associated regulations to a return to White Australia? Can the Minister assure the Senate that this is not the case? Is Mr Bernard Collaery right when he says of the Department, `It has been singularly unsuccessful in the courts in getting its way.'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —A Federal politician now faces great dangers; one could always have a casual shave at five minutes to eight in the morning without listening to local sawdust Caesars romp across the airwaves of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. That is no longer possible-and I am one of those guilty of voting for self-government in the Australian Capital Territory! Mr Collaery, however, for the first time in my listening to him has got one thing right. One of the reasons we amended the Migration Act and the regulations was that we lost in the court all the time. We lost in the court all the time because of inadequate drafting of the Act and a desire by justices, at no matter what level, to delve into merit review rather than legal matters. To help them resist that temptation we have tightened up the Act so that it is very difficult for judges to go into merits review. We have set up an independent immigration review tribunal. We went before a particular Federal Court judge 16 times for 16 losses; but we won nine of the nine cases on which we appealed. Therefore, in any future such cases we will probably be able to resist merits review.

ANSWER.PARA: The second question concerned whether we are going back to the White Australia days. I really think that is the sort of rhetoric best left for the local Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly. Mr Collaery also went on to say that he is going to use officers of his own Department, because he is also Attorney-General, to look at our Federal regulations. I am sure Senator Reid and others would be interested in that misuse of resources. Mr Collaery is, or was-and his firm still is-active in the immigration area. It was of great regret to my Department that he went into politics because the only person we never had trouble winning a case against in court was Mr Collaery. I will put up my credibility against his any day. I want to make only two points with respect to credibility. I remember a classic quote from Senator Richardson; I just have to repeat it. On 6 March this year Mr Collaery said:

As far as we're concerned, we'll form a grouping with community based people who want to really work there outside political pyramids, outside political machines and the very fact that they were there, is because we reject the concept of political party machines, so we won't form a coalition with Liberal and Labor, they will have to come down to us and find a community base.

Mr Collaery's credibility! The other thing that I found amazing about Mr Collaery was that in an earnest appeal to get votes he said that by his going into politics his law firm would lose $50,000. He then put down his pecuniary interest statement which showed that even though he had a gross income of over $145,000 a year his net income was $3,000 a year. Maybe he was paid on performance; I am not sure.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is all in the Canberra Times. Mr Collaery should go back to getting the grass cut in the Australian Capital Territory and leave us to get on with national politics.

I ask the Minister: Has he seen a document entitled `A Bill for an Act to defer observance of Christmas Day' circulating in the building in the past few days under the authority of Senator Crichton-Browne? Is there any truth in the rumours that he, as Manager of Government Business in this place, is supportive of the intent of this Bill? Is this support for reasons of kindness, out of the goodness of his heart, or in order to honour an earlier commitment given to Government senators that they would be able to spend Christmas 1989 with their families in their respective States?
—Poor families!
—Speak for yourself, Senator Chaney. Finally, will the Senate be allowed a free vote on this Bill should it come to the Senate prior to the universally recognised Christmas Day?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a real question without notice. I recall that some years ago when Senator Townley and some other colleagues circulated a menu of what we were to have on Christmas Day, giving various alternatives as to whether we wanted a Protestant or Catholic priest to give the grace, whether we wanted ham or turkey, et cetera. The only thing that disappointed me about that was that someone on my side filled it out seriously. That person is no longer here so I can at least say that. To get serious in terms of the date of Christmas Day, various biblical scholars and astrologers in the 1920s and 1930s did suggest that Christmas Day in fact was not 25 December but much later. I am sure that an erudite senator such as Senator Crichton-Browne has taken that into account. The only difficulty with that revisionist view of history is that later evidence now supports the original text in the Bible and therefore 25 December probably is the day. As everyone knows, the main reason for keeping honourable senators sitting so long is the travel allowance. Honourable senators are not only getting extra travel allowance; they cannot spend it on Christmas presents.

ANSWER.PARA: On a serious and final note, the Senate will be sitting until the third reading of the Privacy Amendment Bill and honourable senators will be out of here a minute later, I suspect. It is up to honourable senators in this chamber when we get to the third reading of the privacy Bill. It could be 3.45 p.m. on Friday, or it could be 10.30 p.m. on Saturday.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is it true that in November 1988 a working party on radiation oncology was set up under the auspices of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council (AHMAC)? Was the report of that working party presented to AHMAC in March 1989? Did that report confirm the previously documented deficiencies in the provision of radiotherapy services throughout Australia? Is this report the sixteenth such report by State and Federal governments since 1982, all of which have documented the appalling lack of radiotherapy treatment facilities and suboptimal staffing levels? Will the Minister please explain the lack of initiative by his Department to take steps to correct this abysmal situation, which in effect denies radiotherapy treatment to over 10,000 newly diagnosed cancer patients in Australia each year, not only increasing suffering but also jeopardising the chance of cure in significant numbers of patients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter's question refers to the alleged shortage of equipment and facilities for radiotherapy services and the recent report of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council on radiation oncology. The report was considered by the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council going under the acronym of AHMAC on 20 October this year but remains confidential until AHMAC has made a formal decision to release it. The figures cited by Senator Coulter of patients being denied treatment are theoretical. They rest largely on comparisons with overseas countries and the relatively low proportion of cancer patients in Australia who receive radiation therapy: 35 per cent in Australia compared with 45 to 55 per cent in comparable countries overseas. Senator Coulter's question has many aspects, and I have a brief which runs to 3 1/2 pages. It may please Senator Coulter and the Senate if I seek leave to incorporate the full details in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Senator Coulter's question refers to the alleged shortage of equipment and facilities for radiotherapy services and the recent report for the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council on Radiation Oncology.
The report was considered by AHMAC on 20 October 1989 but remains confidential until AHMAC has made a formal decision to release it.

The figures quoted by Senator Coulter of patients being denied treatment are theoretical. They rest largely on comparisons with overseas countries and the relatively low proportion of cancer patients in Australia who receive radiation therapy (35% in Australia compared with 45-55% in comparable countries overseas).
However, in considering the working party's report AHMAC was not prepared to endorse any particular referral rate.
AHMAC's decision recognises that there is no available evidence to suggest that Australian referral rates should be the same as other countries; and
In particular that there is no evidence that survival rates of cancer patients in Australia are worse than elsewhere as a consequence of the lower rate of referrals.

The AHMAC working party report also makes it clear the availability of equipment is only one of many factors which can influence the availability of, and demand for, radiotherapy. Geographical factors, the availability of radiation oncologists and therapeutic radiographers and limited knowledge of the usage of radiotherapy by referring doctors are all important factors.

Claims that there are large numbers of Australians who would benefit from radiotherapy but who do not have access because of lack of facilities are not supported by information presented to AHMAC by the working party.
A survey conducted by the working party in December 1988 found that in general there were no significant waiting lists for radiotherapy services
This would indicate that those cancer patients not receiving radiotherapy services are being treated by the other cancer treatment modalities, chemotherapy and surgery.
There is also little evidence comparing the relative effectiveness of different types of cancer treatments.

The majority of radiotherapy services are provided in the public sector which is appropriate given the generally accepted view that radiation oncology services should be provided in comprehensive centres with strong links to other services.

Public hospital services are financed through the state/Commonwealth medicare agreements. These provide annual grants which do not specify in detail what services should be financed. Thus the actual amount of Commonwealth funding cannot be specified.
Priority for and the level of funding of radiotherapy services is essentially a matter for the States.

In responding to the AHMAC report most States indicated that they are addressing the needs for radiotherapy services to 1995 and have developed, or are currently developing, strategic plans for staff and equipment levels which are generally in line with the recommendations of the working party.

In addition the Commonwealth has also made $50m available under the hospital enhancement program to be matched by states to provide $75m in both 1989-90 and 1990-91 to enable states to improve the capital equipment in public hospitals.
This follows a similar program, the teaching hospitals capital equipment program, between 1985-86 and 1987-88 under which the Commonwealth provided $150m to assist States with capital acquisition.
States determine their own priorities for capital expenditure but some of these funds have already been used for improved radiation oncology services.
For example, commencement, from June this year, of radiotherapy services at Box Hill in Victoria at a cost of $1.9m.
The potential is there for States to use most of the funds for radiation oncology services if they chose.
Funding for radiotherapy treatment has also been available for many years through medical benefits for services to private patients.
In February 1988 the Commonwealth extended its financial support to cover computerised radiotherapy planning services for private patients.
In 1988-89 total Federal Government expenditure for radiotherapy services for private patients amounted to some $11m.

The Federal Government support for private radiation oncology services is not restricted to existing facilities and new facilities are free to commence operation at any time as long as they meet State requirements for such operations. Medicare benefits would automatically be payable for new private services.
But given the high capital costs involved there is a need for a coordinated approach between the public and private sector.

Discussions are currently underway between the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health and the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists (RACR) over the expansion of services provided by private sector radiation oncology practices and schedule fees for such services.
The Minister for Community Services and Health expects to make an announcement shortly on funding for private sector units and improved schedule fees.
It is also important to recognise however that opening new private centres is not a quick solution.

Owing to the lengthy periods involved in training new radiation oncologists and therapeutic radiographers immediate provision of additional facilities may simply drain staff from existing public facilities.
And would not lead to any additional treatments until such time as extra staff are available.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Can the Minister inform the Senate of actions the Government has taken to alleviate the situation of the regrettably large number of homeless young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of accommodation for disadvantaged young people was specifically addressed in the design of the new 1989 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. At the same time, and particularly because of the initiative of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission inquiry, the Commonwealth announced in the 1989 Budget a package of measures aimed largely at assisting homeless youth. The package of assistance provides an additional $100m over the next four years. This $100m is all new money and is additional to the funding increases in the specific programs in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: The $100m covers a wide ranging package of assistance across a number of portfolios. There is particular emphasis, however, on increased accommodation and support options; improved access to health, education, training, employment and income support provisions; and counselling and mediation assistance. The package is particularly designed to focus heavily on assistance for homeless and other disadvantaged youth in a community context, to achieve positive outcomes for youth, and to ensure coordination of planning and service delivery. It is essential that we maintain effective links between the Commonwealth, the community and the States in order to ensure the success of this essential program.

There are a number of other accommodation-housing programs which will also provide assistance to homeless youth. These include accommodation programs which will provide $5m in growth funds per annum, matched dollar for dollar with the States; upgraded assessment; and improved links with other services. The crisis accommodation program will also provide growth from $19.5m in 1988-89 to $39m in 1989-90: $7m of this increase is for youth. There will be an additional $10m if the States match recurrent funding.

The local government and community housing program will add to these programs through growth from $16m in 1988-89 to $24m in 1989-90: $8m of this increase is for youth. Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, there will be an additional $310m in 1989-90 to provide improved opportunities and access to public rental housing for disadvantaged people. The special Burdekin response will provide $17m over four years matched dollar for dollar with the States. All of this is a record of achievement of which we should be proud.
