TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine asked me a question on 20 December about charging arrangements to 008 telephone services from a mobile phone. He suggested that calls were charged twice-once to the caller, and again to the 008 service provider. The response that I have from the Minister for Transport and Communications is based on advice from Telecom and is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: With the exception of customers using mobile telephones customers can now ring 008 numbers free of charge. Customers making 008 calls have been charged for the cost of a local call prior to 29 November 1989. The call customer pays call charges based on STD rates. Mobile telephone users are aware that all calls from a mobile telephone are time charged. Time charging applies for mobile telephone users irrespective of whether or not the call is to a 008 number. In the case of a mobile call to a 008 number the uniform rate of 39c a minute, day rate, applies throughout Australia. Other calls from mobile services are charged at 39c a minute up to 745 kilometres and 57c a minute over 745 kilometres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked by Senator Hill to get details about the invitation to the President of Romania to visit. Most of these details have been given in debate, so I would ask for leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
VISIT BY ROMANIAN PRESIDENT
In his 24 years in office President Ceausescu has visited a significant proportion of the countries of the world

He made it clear to the Australian Government in the lead up to the bicentennial year that he very much wished to join the many other Heads of Government and Heads of State coming to Australia in 1988
And to take advantage of what had been a long-standing invitation
In view of the commercial interests which Australia has pursued in Romania there was little option at that time but to renew an invitation

In the circumstances of the sharply deteriorating human rights situation in Romania over the last year or so, and in particular of course in the light of the shocking events of recent days, there could naturally be no question of any such invitation now being extended.
At the time of President Ceausescu's visit to Australia, the Romanian authorities sought a guarantee from the Australian Government that there would be no demonstrations mounted against him

We responded firmly that in a pluralistic democratic society we could give no such guarantee. We could provide security, but if such a guarantee were a condition of President Ceausescu's visit, we made clear that we would prefer that the visit was cancelled.
During Ceausescu's visit, the Prime Minister raised human rights issues with him and left him under no illusions about the strength of Australia's concerns.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston asked me a question regarding the allegation that Mr David Hill was involved in the consortium to purchase Channel 7. I can now inform Senator Alston that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, has today written to Mr Hill seeking an assurance from him that any possible future involvement of the Seven Network would not cause, or be likely to cause, a conflict of interest in relation to Mr Hill's responsibility with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to raise with the Minister for Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) a point for clarification in that answer. It appeared to me, and I did not take note of the answer, that in the reference to future involvement with Channel 7 the implication was that Mr Hill has been engaged in some form of contact with Channel 7. I seek some clarification from the Minister as to whether that is the case and whether the answer, which refers to any future involvement, therefore means that the Minister knows about and accepts some previous involvement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When I asked for this matter to be followed up, at about 1= o'clock today, the answer, first of all, came that Mr Willis had no knowledge of Mr Hill's involvement in Channel 7 and would not generally act on newspaper reports. We then pressed for a reply to put down here, and I have given that reply. Whether between 1 o'clock and 2 o'clock Mr Willis has become knowledgable about some other area concerning this matter, I personally do not know. I have some grave doubts that anything changed in that time period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Ray) in response to a Question without Notice asked by Senator Alston on 20 December 1989, relating to the alleged involvement of the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in the proposed purchase of a television network.

It seems to me, from what has just been said, that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, is not disputing the proposition that he has not received any communication from Mr Hill, despite the fact that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), in answer to my question the other day, made it plain that he expected that Mr Hill would advise the Minister before he contemplated any such negotiations. It therefore seems that Mr Hill has done nothing. So he has been in breach of that clear direction given, I thought, through this chamber.

More significantly, it also seems that Mr Willis is contemplating an acceptance of the negotiations on the basis of writing to Mr Hill to seek an assurance that any arrangement that he might enter into will not compromise his position as head of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I cannot see how he could fail to be compromised by any negotiations that he might enter into with a commercial broadcaster that is clearly, in many aspects of its activities, in direct competition with the ABC. I would have thought that the proper letter to be writing would be one seeking clarification, perhaps an assurance that Mr Hill has not been engaged in any such active discussions. I think one could accept the proposition that there is nothing wrong with Mr Hill being approached. But the moment that Mr Hill does anything more than reject those approaches, then I think he is in a position of potential compromise. He should immediately have brought the matter to the attention of the Minister. To the extent that he has failed to do so now I think he has been derelict in his duty. For the Minister simply to proceed on the basis that it might be possible for Mr Hill to have some future arrangement with Channel 7 and yet remain in his position as Chairman of the ABC is, I would have thought, a clear ignoring of the facts. I ask the Minister now to clarify the nature of the correspondence that Mr Willis proposes to address to Mr Hill and to assure the Senate that, if there is any suggestion of Mr Hill's presently having an intention to enter into any contractual arrangements with Channel 7, or indeed to treat seriously approaches from any of the commercial networks with a view, at some later stage, to leaving the services of the ABC, he ought to be asked to stand down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Alston. He has managed to build up about five straw men and knock them down, based on nothing. I reiterate: the question was asked yesterday, based on press speculation. Until 1 o'clock today Mr Willis had heard no further than that, other than press speculation. Just because there is press speculation, it does not necessarily mean that one has to write a letter asking for confirmation or denial. As Mr Willis sees it, if a letter is to be written it would have to come, more likely, from me, pressing to get a complete answer for Senator Alston. That is what would have motivated it-not any knowledge, as far as I know, by Mr Willis that Mr Hill has been involved in any way in this area.
—Why should a question from me lead to that outcome?
—I assume that the question was based on the same newspaper report.
—But why should you be prompted to write to Mr Hill simply because the matter is raised in the Senate? Surely, if it is a matter of concern--

—No, no. I will have one more try at explaining it to Senator Alston. He asked me a question yesterday and I answered it as far as I could go. Then I said that I would seek further information. Having contacted Mr Willis's office, it indicated that it does not normally write to people confirming or denying a matter, or anything else along those lines, on the basis of press reports. However, I felt that was still an incomplete answer because Senator Alston asked me whether Mr Willis would write to Mr Hill. I pursued that. Obviously Mr Willis, on that pursuit, agreed to write. As far as I can establish it is not based on any facts at this stage or anything else in the knowledge of Mr Willis. I can obviously check that out further. But Senator Alston is making and building up suppositions all on the basis of information that is not available either to him or to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —To be fair to my colleague Senator Alston, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has dismissed rather too readily the question that has been raised. The Minister, when he re-considers this matter, will agree, I hope, that it would have been not merely possible but absolutely normal and indeed to be expected, this matter having been raised yesterday-as the Minister says, only on the basis of a press report; nevertheless it is a serious matter-that either the Minister personally or his Senior Private Secretary would contact Mr Hill's office to inquire whether there was any truth in the report. Surely the Minister would consider that that would be the first thing that one would expect. I would expect the Minister to do it if there were some similar report about some possible dereliction of propriety in his policy administration area. That normal method of procedure, so to speak, being available, surely the Minister will agree that it is a little strange for such a reply to be provided? I understand the Minister's position; he is here only as a mouthpiece-I do not use that word in any derogatory manner-for the Minister's office. He was provided with a reply-if I heard him correctly, and I am subject to correction-to the effect that he sought an assurance from Mr Hill that at no time in the future would any action of his put him in a position of conflict of interest, or something to that effect. I hope I am not misrepresenting the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, that seems to be a very strange sort of letter to write. I hope the Minister will understand that that kind of letter incites almost as much curiosity as if no letter at all had been written. I suggest that the most expeditious way of handling this would be for the Minister perhaps to report to the Senate later today on what further inquiries the Minister's office might elicit by way of more explicit clarification of the facts of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Alston has raised and Senator Stone has followed up on still fundamentally remains unanswered. Mr Hill has had every opportunity to deny that he is in any way involved with Channel 7, or a consortium to buy Channel 7; he has deliberately declined to do so. Furthermore, I think it is important to know whether there is any clause in Mr Hill's contract with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which would indeed preclude him from entering into such negotiations and whether that is the real reason why he is declining to make any comment at all. For the public interest those questions have to be addressed by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray).

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles yesterday asked me a question about a visit by Kodak employees to Disneyland. The question had a number of wrong assumptions in it. There is no proposal, and never has been, for Kodak employees to visit Disneyland and there are no such plans in the offing for Kodak employees to visit Disneyland at company expense. However, I should say that in respect of its sales staff, Kodak runs a performance bonus scheme known as the Top Flight Club. The scheme has been there for six years and it is designed to reward sales personnel who substantially exceed their sales performance target for the year. The allegation in the question was that all Kodak's Australian sales representatives would get an overseas trip. That is not true at all. Only those who are highly successful will get an overseas trip. I am told, for example, that in some States it is unlikely that sales personnel will get a trip this year because they have not exceeded their performance targets. In other places they will.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point that such schemes are a very common form of reward in industry to sales staff. In Kodak's case the cost of the benefit is outweighed many times over by the increase in sales achieved as a result of increased motivation of the sales force. This year any successful sales personnel will be rewarded with a trip to Hawaii for one week in May next year. It is not yet possible to assess the cost to Kodak since with the sales year ending on 31 December, it is not yet known how many sales personnel will qualify for the performance incentive. As I said, the scheme has been operating at Kodak for six years. Kodak is a company with a turnover of something in the order of $450m and it is a complete red herring to try to link a practice which has been going on for six years to the Government's assistance to Kodak which will commence in January. I repeat what I said yesterday that I--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not trying to lead you to it. Why are they paying for the trips when they are getting a subsidy?
—Well, there are plenty of companies which get subsidies of one kind or another. I do not go around with a toothcomb looking at them all to see if they--
—Thirty-six million dollars?
—Yes.
—Come on-not like that.
—I beg your pardon-subsidies to the textile industry in this country total $100m each year.
—To one company?

—No, not to one company. But what has it got to do with the amount? I thought Senator Knowles was asking about a question of principle. It is not $36m anyway; it is $12m in each year. I repeat that Kodak is committed to use the bounty to invest in further export and productivity growth and, as I by implication said earlier, not one cent of taxpayers' money is being used to help Kodak employees enjoy themselves. It is a totally productivity related scheme. For example, Senator Knowles no doubt takes parliamentary trips at taxpayers' expense which are not necessarily productivity related. This is a productivity related scheme.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In the time that has been available, and with the debate which has occurred this morning over the electoral Bill, I have not had the time to give this annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) the sorts of considerations that I would have liked to have given. Nevertheless, I simply take this opportunity to comment not so much upon the report as upon the Service itself and, in particular, the announcement which was made yesterday by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) of the appointment of Dr Peter Bridgewater to be the new Director of the ANPWS succeeding Professor Derek Ovington who has held that position for a considerable period, in fact since 1976, which really is an extremely long period to have given to service of governments of all persuasions in that very important role. I put on record that although Professor Ovington has from time to time been a very controversial Director of the ANPWS, I think that in many respects he has pioneered some new and important areas of activity for that Service. I have always found him a very cooperative and courteous officer of the Commonwealth in his assistance to me as shadow Minister and in previous positions which I have held in the Senate, and a very comprehensive supplier of information as requested on Senate Estimates committees.

Dr Bridgewater, who comes to succeed Professor Ovington, was formerly the Director of Australia's Bureau of Flora and Fauna. He left Australia in July this year to take up the position as the head of Britain's major nature conservation authority, the Nature Conservancy Council. Dr Bridgewater is a trained botanist with a degree from Durham University who has worked as an environmental consultant and administrator and in various academic activities. As I have said, he was Director of the Bureau of Flora and Fauna for six years from 1982 and subsequently headed the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories' natural environment division. He served on a wide range of committees including the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources and the Australian Committee of the Man and the Biosphere Program for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. He is a person I have had the pleasure of meeting through the Department. He is an outstanding officer and I am more than pleased to see his return to Australia to take up a significant position as the Director of the ANPWS.

I referred the other day to the review of the ANPWS which had been undertaken by Mr Bruce McDonald. I have nothing further to add to the remarks which I made on that occasion other than to say, once again, that I am not attracted to the proposition to replace the ANPWS with a new statutory authority-the Australian National Conservation Authority, I think, is the proposed name for it.

I am glad to see that there is a continuing activity on the part of the Service and of the Customs officers to secure an adequate level of prosecutions of people committing breaches of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. This is a very important piece of legislation and I am glad to see that there is in the report, on pages 46 through to 49, a considerable amount of detail about the activities of both the Service and of other Commonwealth departments in ensuring that prosecutions are brought before the courts. I am glad to say that the courts are now quite clearly imposing much harsher penalties for the breach of this Act, and that is something very much to be welcomed.

I welcome this report. As usual it appears to be a report providing plenty of very sound and useful information, and I am glad to see that once again we have it before us. The only point I make in conclusion is that reports such as this should be available to honourable senators before Estimates committees meet, not right at the end of the session after the Estimates committee and appropriation procedures have been fully dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service annual report. As an environmentalist, I am always relieved when I find that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is involved in managing a resource rather than the State national parks bodies. I will talk more about that in a minute. I note that the role and structure of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is spelled out on page 1. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Mission To protect and conserve the nature conservation values of the Australian natural environment and native wildlife, in cooperation with the States and Territories as appropriate.

That is a laudable goal but, in fact, because of the way Australia is organised it is not achievable. What we have here in Australia is not a collection of real national parks. In general, what we have are State preserves; they are called national parks, but are actually run by the States and are subject to the whim of the States. The State can, at the stroke of a pen, eliminate these national parks, as has happened in Tasmania. What we really need is a real national park system run by the Federal Government, as is the case in my native United States. The national parks system in the United States has as its mission to protect in perpetuity all those areas identified as important to the environment or to the historical aspects of the United States. There is a serious commitment there. In Australia, unfortunately, we still have the idea that national parks are a luxury and we allow the States to have control.

The other issue I would like to raise is the terrible situation which now exists in the south-east corner of Australia, having to do with the logging of the National Estate. National Estate areas are areas which have been identified by the Federal Government as of importance to the country. Unfortunately, there is no real control over the State activities. There is control over Federal activities in these areas but not State activities. What we need is firm Federal control, especially in areas like the south-east forests of New South Wales which at this very moment are being logged. Our National Estate areas are threatened. Other areas which should be on the National Estate and which have been left out are being logged. This is, of course, extending across the border into Victoria, in the Errinundra Plateau. A fact of life is that ecosystems do not follow the dotted lines of administrators put on maps in the last century. The ecosystems extend across the borders and what we need is an ecosystem approach to these areas.

I would like to see all the national parks in New South Wales and Victoria and all the National Estate areas linked together in the south-eastern part of this country as the greater escarpment south-east Australia national park. That is a mouthful; but it is a beautiful area; it is a massive area. If this were a national park it would be a tremendous tourist asset to this country. Many of my colleagues in the chamber have travelled around the world and know that Australia has something to offer which is not available in other parts of the world. It used to be, but it is not any more. We need to preserve what we have. A short term approach is to rip the trees out, sell the woodchips to Japan, or build a pulp mill to use the woodchips and reduce Australia to just another tree farm. In fact, what we have is a tremendously viable ecosystem, a living museum of life forms which are many millions of years old and which should be preserved. At present they are not being preserved simply because of the fractioned nature of the control over the areas and the fact that the Federal Government does not have the power to preserve these areas. The Federal Government can recommend, but it cannot act except in the case of woodchip export licences, and it does not seem to be willing to do anything there either. We need a firm resolve on the part of the Federal Government and a mechanism to save these areas. One such mechanism would be to establish a national park in the greater escarpment of south-eastern Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to pass some brief remarks on the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service annual report for 1988-89. The section on wildlife deals, among other things, with the smuggling of Australian protected fauna. There are reports of eight successful prosecutions and another 12 outstanding. Unfortunately, these cases are probably only the tip of the iceberg. It has been estimated that thousands of Australian animals and birds are smuggled out of Australia each year and that the illegal trade in 1986 was estimated to be worth some $40m per annum. It seems certain that tougher penalties are needed which will be a real deterrent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service also needs better resourcing to enable it to detect more offenders and root out more of this pernicious trade. In my own state of Western Australia the Department of Conservation and Land Management has reported a very large number of offences against the Wildlife Conservation Act and its regulations. The 1987-88 report revealed that 103 cases were pending prosecution. The problems include the collection and smuggling of reptiles, large scale commercial flora exploitation on nature reserves, bird nest robbing and bird trapping. The loss of, and continuing threats to, native mammal and bird species is an ongoing tragedy in this country. An article in the Weekend Australian of 8-9 July appropriately entitled `Graveyard Australia' documented the disappearance of many mammals formerly widely distributed throughout the drier areas of inland Western Australia. It also detailed research involving older Aboriginal people which is attempting to ascertain their distribution before European impact eliminated them.

It is strange that Australians and people overseas quite justly agonise over the fate of the kangaroo, probably the most populous, large wild animal on earth. Yet the fate of so may other severely threatened species attracts very little attention. There are enormous problems resulting from the impact of feral animals, particularly foxes, rabbits and cats. Attempts to re-establish rock wallabies in the Western Australian wheat belt have run into severe problems with foxes. The western barred bandicoot, which was formerly well distributed on the mainland, is currently restricted to Bernier and Dorre Islands off Shark Bay. Conservationists are working to have Dirk Hartog Island protected so that these animals can be re-established there. The Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management is also conducting research with a view to reestablishing these animals on the mainland, but foxes, rabbits and feral cats are the big obstacles yet again. Land clearing, introduced plants and animals, hunting, fishing, collecting, erosion, salination and pollution all make life tenuous for Australia's threatened species.

Despite the assurances which are contained in this report about the management of the commercial kangaroo industry, there are concerns in Western Australia about the commercial exploitation of kangaroos. There is no freedom of information legislation in Western Australia and it is difficult to obtain detailed and accurate information on the industry which should be fully open to public scrutiny. Conservationists have tried to obtain accurate information on the numbers of shooters, processors, mobile chillers and the areas in which they operate, but without success. It would be excellent if the National Parks and Wildlife Service could supply this sort of information to the public. Western Australia has now approved the human consumption of kangaroo meat, but the more we allow the exploitation of animals, the more likely it is that the management program will come to reflect the requirements of the commercial industry rather than the interests of nature conservation.

I commend the work of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and call for much more strenuous efforts on the part of governments and all Australians to protect our remaining wildlife. When the Europeans arrived in Australia it was a wonderland of species found nowhere else in the world. But many have already been lost with no opportunity even to study them, or name them in some cases. It will be the ultimate tragedy if, in conservation terms, the tendency to graveyard Australia is not reversed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I am sure the National Museum of Australia must have had tongue in cheek when it put, at the beginning of this report, a photograph of the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, the Hon. Clyde Holding, running a flag up a flagpole. If there is anything that distinguishes the history of the National Museum of Australia over the life of the Hawke Labor Government, it is the extraordinary neglect of the National Museum by the Labor Government. Let me make clear once again that the Liberal and National parties have a commitment to fund the National Museum of Australia over the next five years and, in particular, to take the opportunity to ensure that it plays a major and significant role in the preservation of Australia's Aboriginal heritage.

This museum has been starved of funds. It has been the target of an ongoing, vicious assault upon its integrity and its future by the Department of Finance which has not been resisted in any adequate sense by successive arts Ministers. For example, on page 50 of this report, under the appendix which deals with outward loans, I see that the former unlamented Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, had on loan from the museum Aboriginal objects and objects from the Hon. J. B. Chifley. We know what happened to some of the Aboriginal objects-he broke them. They were sent back to the museum in a damaged condition. But the Minister was quite happy to have objects on loan. He is the only member of parliament whose name appears in the appendix as having had material on loan from the National Museum. It would be interesting to know whether other honourable senators and honourable members were given the opportunity to have material on loan from the museum which, after all, cannot be displayed adequately because the museum has not been provided with the facilities to display it. Have the rest of us been given that opportunity? The answer is clearly no. But the Minister, who had no record of fighting for the National Museum, no track record in providing assistance for the National Museum and no proven desire actually to get additional money for the museum, was perfectly happy to have its objects on display.
National Maritime Museum
National Maritime Museum

The burden of supporting the museum has fallen very much to a group of dedicated people-friends of the National Museum-under the leadership of Jack Thompson. In fact, people such as Robyn Williams, John Williamson, Margaret Whitlam, Valerie Taylor, Vincent Serventy and others in the Friends of the National Museum of Australia organisation, have been active in trying to do something about raising additional funds for it. Cooperative activities have been undertaken in the Australian Capital Territory between the local business community and the local trade union movement. In fact, local unions in the Australian Capital Territory have made a considerable effort to try to rally to the support of the National Museum. The museum had a stunningly successful open day in May this year, which I attended. Many thousands of people saw what the museum was trying to do within the very limited resources made available to it. I take this opportunity to pay particular tribute to the inaugural Director, Dr Don McMichael, who has since retired and who, for the last 6 1/2 years, has fought a very valiant and uneven struggle against the Department of Finance in an attempt to secure assistance for the National Museum of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, am very concerned about the lack of government support for the National Museum of Australia. As a person who was not born in Australia I find--
—You are the second one who has spoken on the report.
—Who was not born in Australia.

—Perhaps those of us who were not born in Australia appreciate this sort of thing more than the natives because we understand culture and the value of culture. We have had to learn about a different culture and thus we appreciate it. Like Senator Puplick, a number of people have approached me about the National Museum of Australia and the lack of support given to it.

SPEECH.PARA: This annual report is probably the slickest thing that has come out of the museum. If we look at the annual report we think that this is a going concern and that something is really happening. I think the museum has done a wonderful job in preparing this report. For instance, on page 23, under the heading `The Gallery of Aboriginal Australia' and the subheading `Activities' it is stated:
The Gallery had only two full time staff during the year and this placed a ceiling on its activities.

It certainly did. Where is the commitment? The gallery of Aboriginal Australia should be a showplace in Australia for Aboriginal arts and activities. Instead, we have two full time staff. If we read the report closely we see that it represents a sad collection of a lack of money and lack of resources. It certainly shows the will and devotion of the people who work there, but it shows no commitment on the part of the Government to come up with the money. On page 2 of the report, under the heading `Future of the Museum' we find:
The 1988/89 financial year posed major difficulties for Council due to uncertainty surrounding the Museum's future.

In bringing down the Budget in August 1988 the Government announced that consideration of development of the Museum would be deferred for five years and arrangements would be put in place to exhibit elements of the national collection including through State museums.
So the Government is going to farm this stuff out to State museums. Why? We have a national museum. All it needs is a commitment from the Government to support it. I share Senator Puplick's concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very good of Senator Sanders to predicate his remarks as being upon the judgment of those not born in Australia. It is worth putting on the record what Senator Sanders would not accept by interjection; that is that the motion that was moved by Senator Puplick was moved by someone not born in Australia. Senator Puplick, as someone born in England, was in a very good position to appreciate the very things which Senator Sanders put out. So when he makes these comments and praises people not born in this country for being able to make comments, he was in fact paying a tribute to the person who led for the Opposition. I would just like that to be on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would like to start by saying how much I have appreciated the courtesy of officers and staff of the Australian National Maritime Museum in facilitating arrangements for me to observe the growth and development of the museum and in particular pay tribute to Dr Kevin Fewster, who was appointed in December 1988 as the museum director. He comes to the museum with a very successful and distinguished record following his period with the South Australian Maritime Museum, which was the winner of the national tourism and museum award in 1988.

That having been said, I regret that I have to detain the Senate for a moment with the question of the cost of this particular institution. Honourable senators may have seen that the museum apparently is going to end up costing between $60m and $70m. It appears that it was originally believed that the cost of this museum would be $30m. The question of who is to find the additional $30m or $40m is now a matter of considerable dispute between the State of New South Wales and the Commonwealth. The facts, as I understand them, are as follows: In order to attempt to bolster the late and unlamented Premier Unsworth's re-election chances, some sort of written agreement was entered into between the Commonwealth and the then New South Wales State Government represented by Mr L. Brereton, then a Minister in the State Government and now a candidate for election to the Federal Parliament, providing the Commonwealth would assume responsibility for the first $30m worth of cost of this facility, and it is alleged that New South Wales would bear the responsibility for whatever the cost overruns were.

The land in question is owned by the State of New South Wales through the Darling Harbour Authority. We have a situation where the actual building at the moment and the land upon which it is built is owned by the State of New South Wales. The Commonwealth is now saying that the State of New South Wales is responsible for giving us the additional $30m or $40m to pay for the remaining costs of this building. The State of New South Wales is saying, quite rightly, `Just hang on a minute, this is a national museum, a Commonwealth museum, and you expect the taxpayers of New South Wales to pick up the tab for a Commonwealth facility. We are not going to pay the money and indeed unless you pay the money'-you being the Commonwealth-`we, the State of New South Wales, will not give you the museum because it is on our land', and so we have this Mexican stand-off. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, in answer to a question I asked him the other day, said that he was going to ensure that New South Wales paid up. He was very macho about this. He was going to make sure that New South Wales paid. When I pressed him and asked whether he understood that Mr Brereton had signed a blank cheque and that the taxpayers of New South Wales would be stuck with the bill, he said that that was precisely his understanding-that Mr Brereton had signed a blank cheque and that the protestations, being very properly made by Mr David Hay, the Minister for Local Government in New South Wales about being stuck with this enormous bill, were, in Senator Richardson's words, either outrageous or irrelevant.

Whatever the facts of this matter are, I hope that the National Maritime Museum Bill-we have still not dealt with it despite the fact that it has been on the Notice Paper of the House of Representatives since 1985-will be referred to a senate committee in due course under Senator Hamer's newly developed proposals, so that we can have a look at this matter a bit further. However, at this stage the evidence discloses that the shabby deal done by the Unsworth Government in an attempt to buy its re-election, and the appalling lack of propriety by Mr Brereton as the then Minister, will potentially stick the taxpayers of New South Wales with a huge bill. Mr Brereton is the real culprit in this whole shabby exercise. I hope that people bear that fully in mind when they are judging his suitability to be transferred from the Parliament of New South Wales to the House of Representatives.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, on behalf of the President, I table a report from the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House relating to proposed work in the parliamentary zone entitled Second Report Relating to a Community Based Child Care Centre in the Parliamentary Zone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Honourable senators will note that, in addition to the report which has been signed by some members of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, there is a dissenting report from three or four other members of the Committee, which is attached to it. This matter has come before the Parliament previously. Last year the Senate voted to support the concept of the erection of a child-care centre in the grounds of the old Parliament House building. One might ask, `Why are we discussing it again? Why aren't we merely approving the construction of that building?'. The reason I believe the matter is still one that should be discussed and dealt with by the Senate is that since that time information has come before the Committee which was not previously available. In fact, it is my recollection that in November last year when the Committee looked at it, and the matter was current, we were told that there were no heritage implications in relation to the development of a child-care centre in the gardens of the old Parliament House.

We now have before us a letter written by the Australian Heritage Commission, signed by Gerard Early, the Acting Director, to Mr M. Grace, dated 19 December 1989, which clearly takes the debate in a different direction. For that reason I believe that this matter should be aired again. Last time it was debated the Government supported the Cabinet decision that, come what may, a child-care centre would be located on that site. The Australian Democrats were persuaded that the need for a child-care centre was a lot greater than the heritage value of that building and its environs. I appeal to them to re-examine the situation today, in the light of the fact that there is another site a very short distance away where the child-care centre could be placed, and at considerably less cost.

The building of the old Parliament House took place in about 1925 and it was opened in 1927. I shall not go over the history of the building. There were about 12 or 14 major renovations involving adding on wings and creating courtyards. Most of us here know the history of the development of that building. An integral part of the building, initially, was the rose garden and the gardens on either side. I wish to read from the letter of the Heritage Commission I just referred to. It states:

This study has confirmed the Commission's belief that the gardens of Old Parliament House are of considerable national estate significance for the way they reveal essential elements of the taste and style of their period, most particularly the international movement of landscape design for public settings. The close relationships of gardens to public buildings was an essential feature of Canberra in the 1920s.

The gardens were laid out in 1925 to relate to the plan of the House and provide quiet retreats for rest and recreation for members and Senators. The formality of the gardens and the placement of trees to complement the low scale of the House indicate the intention of the architect J. S. Murdoch to combine the building and gardens to form an entity, which he succeeded in doing.
The way the aesthetic appeal and evidence of the form layout of the gardens has been degraded by the construction of buildings within them is made clear in the Conservation Study . . .

It goes on. We are talking particularly of the House of Representatives garden, which has within it tennis courts and a bowling green which were part of the original 1925 design. Also within it are the squash courts which were not a part of the original 1925 design. They were put there, I think, in the 1950s or early 1960s, as a reasonable facility for senators and members who were then using the building. We are talking though about a building which is at present in mothballs and which ought to be restored and made available for Australians at large. I do not think there would be anybody here who would doubt that that is what should occur.

There is still debate as to what state it should be presented. Whether it should be restored to its 1927 configuration or whether it should be renovated and restored in some other fashion is still to be determined. Because the gardens are so much an integral part of the design it is my very firm view that they should be dealt with when the building is redeveloped. There is no doubt that the squash courts probably should go because they are not part of the original gardens. There is no doubt that the annex should go. In fact, it should have already gone because when the Parliament was asked to approve of the development of that annex so as to accommodate the additional members for the electorates which were created some four or five years ago one of the key things that was put to us was that the annex would not remain, it would be only temporary. It is a matter of regret and concern that it is still standing there and has not yet been removed. I think the Government should be condemned for failing to honour its commitment. It was this Government which made the commitment to remove the annex. The House of Representatives gardens would need to be renovated in some respects to fit in with the style of the building if it were to be presented to the community in the fashion that the subcommittee of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the New Parliament House suggested.

It is the overwhelming view of Government members that come what may the child-care centre should be on those grounds. I honestly cannot understand why they are so committed to it. Certainly it seems that the child-care centre must be within the parliamentary triangle. Yet all of us know that just down the road a site is available next to the Hotel Kurrajong which could be used for a child-care centre. In fact, it would cost a great deal less to construct a child-care centre there than on this site. If it is to be built next to the provisional Parliament House there is no doubt that it will be a great deal more costly to make the design compatible, at least a little bit, with that building and the setting in which it is proposed to be put. There can be no doubt that on financial grounds the building should be, if it is to be erected, down near the Hotel Kurrajong. If one has even the slightest regard for the heritage value of the building and the gardens the child-care facility should not be built in the House of Representatives gardens. I doubt that anybody can argue with or counteract either of those views. There is, of course, the aspect of its being in the Australian Capital Territory and part of the Australian Capital Territory's funding and allocation for child-care centres. Whilst not wishing to take up too much of the Senate's time today, that is a matter that ought to be reviewed.

Canberra has quite an amount of child-care places and not all of the private centres are full at all times. There is no doubt though, as can be seen from the report of child-care services in the Australian Capital Territory prepared by Jean Gifford in December 1987, that there is still a need for child-care in Canberra. The question is: is this the place to put it? Is this the place that best serves the people of the Australian Capital Territory? Jean Gifford refers in her report on page 23 to Canberra, Belconnen and Tuggeranong as the areas with the largest number of children likely to need child-care. She goes on to state:
Demographic comparisons of regions extending beyond numbers of children reveal some differences, and many similarities.
Canberra regions have different age structures. Central Canberra has the oldest population-
let us remember, of course, that the area we are talking about is central Canberra-
Tuggeranong the youngest and each region has a distinctive age profile.

Central Canberra is more distinct than other regions in dimensions reflecting disadvantage: family income and relative numbers of single parent families, isolation of single parents and their likelihood of not working. Central North and Central South frequently show similar patterns, though Central South is a mix of disadvantaged and privileged to a greater extent than Central North.
She goes on to say:

Looking only at numbers of children and child care places available in a given region, Tuggeranong and Western Creek are lagging behind the rest of Canberra. This ignores related child care issues. . .

She then goes on to other matters. If government child-care places are to be provided in Canberra, I seriously question whether this is the right place to put them. I know we will be told that the Government has approved them. Certainly only a short time ago the government approving it was this Federal Government, which is committed to this structure, in its capacity as the minder of the Australian Capital Territory. Since then we have had a Labor Government in the Australian Capital Territory, which I believe also endorsed it. But of course it would; it virtually had no choice. I do not know whether the Government now governing the Australian Capital Territory has had the opportunity to look at this. It is coming out of its funding. It is coming out of its allocation for places for child-care in the Australian Capital Territory.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be astonished to know that this structure is to cost $400,000. Honourable senators should just think of how many child-care centres could be built in other parts of Australia, and indeed other parts of Canberra, with a sum of money as large as that. It is an enormous amount for some 40 children to be in full day care in the Australian Capital Territory. We could have a lot more places if the money were spent more wisely. Of course, I would take it one step further and say that none of the money should be spent on the capital cost of a child-care centre. The site should be made available for private development and the children who need care should be subsidised by the Government to go there. We would then probably increase tenfold the number of children for whom care could be given.

The Government has been very ambivalent about child-care. When it had the opportunity to put a child-care centre into the National Library it flatly refused to do so. The space was available and everybody expected it to be approved. But, although we lobbied as hard as we did, there was no way that this Government would agree to a child-care centre being placed in the National Library. Now it seems to have done a 180-degree turn and is totally committed to one being built on this particular site that we are discussing today, the subject of this report. When we think of the difference in cost of providing child-care in a government centre and in a private centre, it seems even more absurd that this money is being used for this purpose. I refer to the statements and admission of Senator Walsh in March of this year. He admitted that the cost per week for publicly funded child-care is $175. That figure arose out of a joint study conducted by the Department of Finance and the Department of Community Services and Health. That report was sent to Cabinet approximately 18 months ago and, to my knowledge, it has not been made public. However, in a television interview about 12 months ago, Senator Walsh cited that figure of $175 as the cost of keeping a child under two in public child-care. In private care that service can be obtained for a much lower sum.
A document produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics dealing with commercial long day child-care in Australia, at November 1988, states:
The average fee rate charged for a week of full day care was $74, ranging from $92 in ACT to $63 in Queensland.

It is not true to say that that is for a shorter period than is available in government care, and it cannot be suggested that child-care in a government centre is of a different standard from private centres because of the legislation which-at least in the Australian Capital Territory, which is the area I particularly know-requires them to meet the same standards. In fact, if child-care can be provided in Canberra at the rate of $92 per week, one should be able to provide child-care for far more children than on the present basis of it costing not less than $100 and up to $175 per week.

There are a number of grounds on which to urge the Senate not to have anything to do with this proposition. There is the enormous waste of building at a cost of $400,000; if that money is to be spent on government child-care, it could be better spent in other parts of Canberra or Australia. Also, the cost of providing child-care in this centre will be a great deal more than if the same recurrent funding were used to subsidise children in need of child-care in private institutions. The overwhelming reason for not going ahead with this project is the fact that the Government has not determined what is to happen to the provisional Parliament House and its surrounds. It is outrageous to go ahead and construct this centre in the grounds of that building before that decision has been made, and I believe most Australians would see it that way.

I certainly urge the Australian Democrats to reconsider their position in the light of the document I have referred to-the report of the Australian Heritage Commission-which was not available when they made their decision in relation to this centre. This is a most important issue that Parliament ought to examine. The Senate should not make a decision which enables the centre to go ahead until the Australian Capital Territory Government has had a further opportunity to consider whether this is the best way of spending $400,000 and providing places. We have not had any evidence or suggestion as to who will be able to use it and whether it will be restricted to people financially in need of child-care.

The people I am particularly concerned about are mothers-single parents frequently-who want to get back into the work force and need child-care yet cannot get it because the money available for it is being spent in such an extravagant fashion. Is it certain that the people who get this subsidised child-care are those people in need and not people who are on substantial incomes working in the surrounding area? I have been given no indication in the past, when this has been discussed, that that will be the case. The money available should not be spent in this fashion for the reasons that I have given. I urge the Senate to vote against the adoption of this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House.
—A distinguished member, too.

—I thank the honourable senator. I became a member of the Committee after the last election and have not participated in many of the decisions that it had to make leading up to the building of this new Parliament House. Now that much of the work related to this building has been completed, the Committee's main function is overseeing what happens within the parliamentary triangle. It is a very large Committee to deal with what, hopefully, in the long run will not be much business. Be that as it may, as a member of that Committee I have attempted to keep abreast of and catch up with the issues that the Committee has dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: The more I have heard about the ongoing saga of the child-care centre-which goes way back long before I was a member of this Committee-it seems that if a sensible decision had been made several years ago, this debate today would not be taking place. A sensible decision would have been for a child-care facility to be built within this new Parliament House. It would have been available not only for the staff here, but also as a public facility for people in the immediate area and, importantly, for visitors from around Australia. Visitors to the major buildings in the Parliamentary Triangle-Parliament House, the Australian National Gallery, the National Library or the High Court of Australia-need a child-care facility while they inspect these national institutions which their taxes have helped to pay for over many years. By not making that decision several years ago, we have let ourselves in for the argument now going on. I think in those days members of the Committee were opposed to child-care being in Parliament House for so-called ideological reasons. Those ideological reasons escape me completely and I only wish, with the wisdom of hindsight, that those people had made a different decision.

This led yesterday to the Committee meeting to debate the recommendation in this report before the Senate. I abstained in the vote on that debate because I had not been able to participate in many of the earlier decisions. I felt that I was not fully aware of all the ramifications and I felt frustrated that the proper decision had not been made several years ago. If it ever comes to a debate here in the Senate I would support the Government's decision. I want to make it quite clear that I support the provision of child-care in the immediate vicinity of this building-in the parliamentary triangle-so that people working in the triangle who need child-care can have access to it, as well as visitors from elsewhere in Australia.

Senator Reid, who is also a member of the Joint Standing Committee, has mentioned a number of reasons why it would be unwise to proceed, and there is a minority report from the Opposition as to why it should not proceed at this stage. Some of those arguments may have some validity as they deal with what is the best site. However, I only wish that the Liberal Party of Australia-which, I suspect, was then in government-had been much stronger in supporting a child-care facility in this building. If it had done so we would not now be in this position. The cost of $400,000 seems to be rather high when compared with the child-care facilities which have been built around the States. I, like a lot of people from the States, often get criticism from my constituents that taxpayers' money is providing a range of facilities in the Australian Capital Territory which is not available to the wider population in other States, and I think, in some senses, that is probably true.

I also say that in the general cost structure of the Australian Capital Territory $400,000 is probably not an unusual figure. With regard to some of the construction costs of this building-quotes from contractors and architects for what I, as a member of the Committee, considered to be minor alterations leading up to the commissioning of this building-it seems to me that the cost structure in the Australian Capital Territory building industry is much higher than in the States. That is one of the reasons why the quote of $400,000 appears to many of us from outlying States to be rather high.

The Australian Heritage Commission report, which referred to the heritage aspects of the site of the provisional Parliament House, what is going to happen to it, and so on, is mentioned in our report. That matter cannot be ignored, but I also say that when arguments are put up that one cannot build a child-care centre in the rose gardens because the children will be noisy and that this would affect the contemplative nature of the gardens, that is a pretty weak excuse. The gardens in the parliamentary triangle should be used by children, by the public, and if a bit of noise is generated from time to time, so be it. That sort of argument does not wash too well with me.

Senator Reid raised the question of an alternative site. I do not know whether the alternative site proposition has been studied closely. I think she mentioned yesterday-and I do not think she would mind my mentioning this in the Senate-that there was a site near the old Kurrajong Hotel. I do not know what standing that site has, but if that is just another way of delaying the provision of child-care in this area, I do not support the proposal. I do not support an ongoing delay. We must provide child-care facilities in the Parliamentary Triangle as soon as possible.

I do not want to delay the Senate for much longer. I wanted to explain the reason why I abstained when the vote was taken yesterday. Some people took that as showing that I was not wholeheartedly in support of the majority decision of the Committee. My main reason for abstaining was that I had missed a number of the meetings of the Committee because I was not a member of the Committee during the time leading up to these decisions being taken, so I felt that it was not appropriate for me to vote either way. But if the Senate takes a vote today, I will vote for the majority report. If there is a possibility of delaying the provision of child-care, I will support the majority report. I think this issue has taken far too long to resolve, and the reason is that many years ago members of the Committee, for stupid reasons, decided not to put child-care facilities in this building, which is the most appropriate place for them to be located.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the previous speaker, Senator Schacht, that it would have been a sensible decision to have the child-care centre located in Parliament House. With 3,500 employees here, we certainly have a need for child-care facilities in Parliament House and in the parliamentary triangle. I also agree with the previous speaker that if, in fact, the only site available in the entire Parliamentary Triangle were within the precincts of the old Parliament House, I would reluctantly agree with the proposal. In fact, there are plenty of alternatives. If Senator Schacht is worried about delaying the provision of child-care facilities, I say to him that he could accelerate such provision, not by locating the centre in the rose garden, but by using one of the alternative sites which are presently available.
—Like what?

—Alternatives such as Casey House, the old headquarters of the Australian Heritage Commission, which is just across the street in Yarralumla, and which is available. There is a bus stop at the front door, adequate parking, and proximity to Parliament House. Another alternative is Forrest Primary School. There is vacant land adjacent to the Australian Heritage Commission offices in Brisbane Avenue. There is vacant land immediately adjacent to Casey House. It we must build a new centre, it could be located on other areas of vacant land which are available. I find it ludicrous that, with all these alternatives and with the given heritage value of the precincts of the provisional Parliament House, this Government, or the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, would consider going ahead with a plan to put a child-care centre in that area. In casting about, I have found no-one with any really good reasons for putting it there. The only reason seems to be inertia-the momentum of a decision which was once made and is continuing through bureaucratic inertia.

SPEECH.PARA: Commonsense dictates that we should look at the situation as it exists and find the best possible solution-not a solution that was presented once and agreed to because the alternatives were not vetted or available, but a commonsense solution. A commonsense solution would be to use these alternative sites and not degrade the provisional Parliament House site. So I am here to inform the Senate that the Australian Democrats will not support the proposal. I went to Senator Richardson's office today and asked a staff member whether any legislation would be needed. The person thought that legislation would be needed to fund this project. If such legislation comes before the Senate, the Democrats will be strongly moved to vote against it because it will not solve the problems of child-care. It will be an expensive solution-there are other better ways of solving this problem-and it will take land which in fact is part of the national heritage. I will not speak longer on this except to say that in this instance the Democrats agree with the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether I am hearing the right words from Senator Sanders. He has actually made a speech roughly akin to that which I would like to make, which causes me some concern. Perhaps he thinks that I have seen the light; I think that probably he has. I have no fundamental disagreement with the need for child-care. In fact, I agree entirely with the need for it. As Senator Schacht has pointed out in his speech, this has been a long-I will not say acrimonious-debate. It certainly has been a long and difficult one for the people who have been involved in it until this time. I, like Senator Schacht, am a new member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House. I find that I have been given a choice between going ahead now and building a child-care centre in the House of Representatives gardens of the provisional Parliament House or finding an alternative site.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members have an absolute fixation with and determination to proceed now and put the child-care centre not only in the parliamentary triangle but in the gardens. That decision was made some time ago. As Senator Reid has pointed out, we now have some more information, which has not been addressed by Government speakers. The extra information we have comes from the Australian Heritage Commission and I will quote briefly from it. It firstly points out:
The Commission therefore strongly supports the proposal to remove the intrusive buildings-
that is, the provisional offices and the squash courts-
so that the entity of the Old Parliament House and its twin gardens will be seen and appreciated by great numbers of visitors following the opening of the complex as a major tourist attraction.

As Senator Reid pointed out, we do not know that the Government has made a decision to restore the old Parliament House in that way. Nonetheless, let us make the assumption that it has and that that is what is going to happen. The Heritage Commission says:

The proposed centre would compromise the spatial quality of the garden, destroy one of the rose gardens, and introduce an activity into the garden which is not in keeping with its historical function as a quiet place of retreat.
That seems reasonably sensible. In the executive summary to its report, it says:

The authors strongly believe that the integrity of the gardens in their 1927 form should be re-established and should then be protected in perpetuity. Most especially there should be no further development within these gardens.

If the message is not clear from those two quotations let me refer briefly to one final point. The Commission says that, in summary, it would strongly advise against the proposal for the following reasons:

1. the addition of a feature for which there has been no historic precedent runs directly contrary to the principles of the Burra Charter and the guidelines adopted by the Australian ICOMOS Committee.
2. it is contrary to the very idea for which the gardens were established . . .
3. an essential aspect of the original Parliament House building was its relationship with the adjacent gardens.
The development of child-care facilities would jeopardise that. Taking the issue of historic precedent alone provides adequate reason for not implementing this scheme.

People who presumably know more about it than I do are saying that the gardens are an essential part of the old Parliament House and there should be no further development. I do not see why we cannot accept that report and find an alternative place for the child-care centre. It does not seem to me to be that difficult. I understand the frustration of those who have been arguing for a long time for such a child-care centre but will that frustration, that absolute desperation to get there at any cost, lead them to cross a bridge that we might not want to cross-in other words, to develop the old Parliament House gardens in a way that the Heritage Commission says would destroy their historical context? We can have our cake and eat it too; we can have a child-care centre in very close proximity to the old Parliament House. Senator Reid mentioned the Kurrajong Hotel site; Senator Sanders nominated a number of other sites. It is quite clear that this child-care centre could go in other places and that it would not be too difficult to find a suitable site. By finding an alternative site we would maintain the integrity of the old Parliament House. Should we want to and should we have the money to do so, we could then turn the old Parliament House into a museum that people could come and see in its original 1927 condition.

I do not make a speech against the provision of a child-care facility. Obviously I think there are alternatives to building one for $400,000 but that is not the point that I am making today or a charge that I want to take up. I am simply making the point that we can have our cake and eat it too. We can have the child-care centre and we can maintain the integrity of the old Parliament House and, in particular, the House of Representatives gardens. No reason has been advocated for not doing that. When I raised this in the Committee hearing and asked, `Well, could somebody please explain?', I was told that the Committee had decided this matter 18 months ago or 12 months ago. Senator Reid pointed out that we have new information now. We know what the Heritage Commission says. Its members have given qualified advice, specialist advice, as to the maintenance or otherwise of the gardens in their 1927 state. We now know that the Heritage Commission thinks that the siting of the child-care facility in the gardens is a very bad idea. What does the Committee say? The Committee says, `Well, we won't take any notice of that because we decided something some time ago and so now we're going to stick with it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Heritage Commission is not God.

—The honourable senator opposite interjects `What would the Commission know about it?'. Perhaps he would like to write to the Commission, express his views and give its members his qualifications to make such comments. But I accept that members of the Commission have some qualifications in this regard, that they think the place should be preserved as nearly as possible in its 1927 state, and that no further development should take place. We can follow that advice and still have a child-care centre. To proceed with a child-care centre in the gardens is to proceed irrespective of the advice offered by the Heritage Commission. It shows a disregard of what the Commission has to say and a disregard for maintaining the old Parliament House in a particular state. More importantly, we would cross a bridge we could not then go back on. If we build a child-care facility in the gardens we are unlikely to knock it down two years or five years later when we have the money to restore the old Parliament House should we want to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a final step; it is a bridge that we would cross. We would have turned around and ripped the bridge away; we could not go back. But if we maintained the gardens we could restore the old Parliament House and still have the child-care centre. I would be very interested to hear why that is an unsatisfactory way to proceed. By choosing an alternative site, everyone would get what he wants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, I am astounded that no member of the Australian Labor Party wanted to follow up Senator Vanstone's comments because they laid the issue very clearly on the line.
—We will.

—I am glad to hear that someone will do so, apparently. In that case I trust that another member of the Opposition might be able to respond because I was hoping to have the opportunity to deal with some coherent reason why the child-care facility should proceed in the way proposed. We have not heard one reason. This is the problem the Senate faces. No coherent reason has been presented to this chamber as to why the Australian Heritage Commission's advice should be rejected out of hand or why, when many alternative sites are available, this particular site must be used.
—We haven't said that.
—It is all very well for Senator Giles to interject. This Committee was misled, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Why weren't you there yesterday?
—Because I was at a funeral, giving a eulogy.
—We didn't get your apology.
—Well, you certainly did. I advised the President.
—Senator Baume, would you address your remarks through the Chair, please?

—I will, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I object to the nature of that interjection. Had I been able to get to the meeting, I certainly would have. I advised the President in the morning that I would be unable to attend. If that is the level of response that we are going to get in this debate, that kind of personal silliness, no wonder this Committee has come to this absolutely absurd decision. This Committee was misled by Government members who assured us that there was no heritage objection to this proposal when it was debated previously. That was an absolutely disgraceful performance by Government members of this Committee.
—You weren't there.

—To most intelligent senators it would be evident from the context. The concern here is not whether there should or should not be a child-care centre. There is a case for and against it. I do not want to canvass that.
—Because you are against it.

—No, I am not. Personally, I am not opposed to the concept, but I am interested that Senator Schacht, having given an inconsequential speech, now insists on interjecting. He did not deal with why this child-care centre must be constructed in this one location. The only location in Canberra capable, according to Government members, of handling such a child-care centre is the very area where the Heritage Commission said the centre must not be. The strength of the Heritage Commission advice is striking. It says, for example:

SPEECH.PARA: The formal rose gardens and the trees and the formal garden to the east-
that is, in the House of Representatives gardens-
offers a clear image of the style of design of the 1920s. Their loss as an element of the Parliament House development would be tragic.
It is not just an inconsequential objection, by the Heritage Commission. `Their loss would be tragic', the Commission says. It goes on:
While the nature of the child care facilities has not been identified-
at the time this report was provided-
they will thus provide further intrusion into the gardens. In summary, we would strongly advise against this.
I emphasise that it says it would strongly advise against this.

I would like to refer to some other elements of this report because the case does not rest, as I said, on whether there should or should not be a child-care centre, or on whether poor decisions were made in the past. Is the Government really saying that because it made a mess of the question of child-care previously, therefore, it can make another mess in trying to correct it? That is the logic, if there is any, in the statements of Senator Schacht.

What intrigues me is this: what are the motives of those people who insist that the centre should be erected in this location? I want to look at the double standards involved. Let us compare it, for example, to the situation at Jervis Bay-this matter is very minor, of course, compared to the multi-millions of dollars involved in Jervis Bay-where multi-millions of dollars of government money was involved. Here $400,000 is to be expended, which, as Senator Reid and other honourable senators have demonstrated, could be far better spent in alternative ways and in better and more readily available sites which do not impinge on Australia's heritage. But because the Jervis Bay matter was politically useful, because there were votes involved, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intervened and said, `We don't care if no report, no environmental impact study, has been completed yet; we will intervene and ban it'. The interesting difference in this case is that the advice from the Australian Heritage Commission is, for example, that it would be a tragedy if that particular part of the gardens were disturbed, disrupted and destroyed; yet the very same Labor Government is rushing to the defence of an environmental issue when a vote is involved, when it can buy a bit of electoral support. But in this case, because the Government deems it not to be an electorally attractive matter, the heritage aspect does not matter a damn.

What is Senator Richardson doing on this matter? We have not heard from him on this issue, yet it is clearly a major environmental issue concerning Canberra, the national capital, and the nation. What is Senator Richardson, who is allegedly the Minister in charge of this kind of issue, doing? Has he bowed down to the pressure from the sisterhood opposite who are determined to have at any price this child-care centre on this location? If only we could hear the justification for pushing aside the Heritage Commission's determination. I am appalled not only at the decision but at the manner in which this decision has been taken. I have attended the meetings of the Committee. This decision was railroaded through this Committee, which was stood over by Mr Speaker, who, quite frankly, in my view rode roughshod over members of the Committee in his determination to get this matter through. As I said, I believe the Committee was grossly misled as to the attitude of the Heritage Commission when past decisions were taken on this matter.

To conclude, I would like to underline a couple of points in the Heritage Commission report that other senators have not dealt with. The conclusion of the Heritage Commission is that the whole of the old Parliament House landscape and gardens is considered to be of national significance. No comparable landscapes of equal quality from their period have been identified in Australia. I stress that no other example has been identified, according to this report, and these people opposite are happy to destroy this landscape in order to gain their objective in the short term, no matter what the cost. The report says:
They are largely intact and offer an essential contribution to the character of the Canberra landscape and its historic style and the character and style of Parliament House.

This landscape and gardens should be nominated for highlighting as a place which is significant within the area in the Register of the National Estate and should be listed by the ACT Heritage Committee.
There should be no further development within these landscapes and gardens and intrusions should be removed.
It is not a half-baked recommendation; it is strong and determined. The report goes on:
Most particularly the formal rose garden in the south-eastern corner of the site can be re-established-
that is, by the removal of the intrusions that honourable senators have already spoken about-
and those formal gardens previously present to separate the tennis courts from the Bowling Green.

The most significant aspect of these gardens is that they illustrate the sophisticated elegant simplicity of the original garden lay-out, something too rarely seen in garden treatments. Indeed, I can think of no other landscape in Australia which has the potential to provide this elegance of the 1920's.

The report then goes on to deal with other elements of the proposal.
