But the important point is that this is a once-off situation which this Government and the Labor members of the Committee want to destroy without this chamber having been presented with one coherent argument about why the Heritage Commission report should be wiped aside and why the alternative sites-which are outside the triangle and, therefore, not subject to this kind of supervision-cannot be used.

I strongly support the dissenting minority report of the members of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, and I urge the Senate to support that dissenting report and to vote against this proposal. I call on Government members to explain their position. We are now well into this debate. There have been plenty of speakers in this debate, but only one speaker from the Government. I take up Senator Colston's interjection and ask him, or whoever is going to be the next Government speaker, to justify this disgraceful decision which is aimed at damaging the environment in which the old Parliament House sits and which is in keeping with this Government's failure still to come to a decision about what to do with the old Parliament House. Do we judge from this that this is an attempt to pre-empt a decision about what is to happen about the old Parliament House, that it will not be kept in the manner in which the Australian Heritage Commission wants?

TALK.START.PARA: —It can't be now.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, if this goes through it cannot be. Is this pre-empting the decision that should be taken properly and sensibly about the future of the old Parliament House? It seems to be that it is. It is now a year and a half since we left the old Parliament House. We have yet to have a decision from this Government. We were told that the Speaker's chair could not be brought up to the new Parliament House, for example, because of its importance historically in the old Parliament House which we were told was to become a museum. We were told that that was one reason we could not bring the chair up. What is this Government doing? I am concerned that this is a clear attempt to pre-empt that decision. I urge the Senate to vote against this report, and I commend Senator Sanders for what I believe was a very sensible point of view that he presented on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to make a few brief comments because, quite honestly, I am not quite sure what the situation is at the moment. The report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House relating to a community based child-care centre in the parliamentary zone was presented on behalf of the President and a motion was moved that the Senate take note of the report. The report has been debated fairly extensively this afternoon, but the report contains the following recommendation:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends approval of the following work in the Parliamentary Zone:
the establishment of a community based child care centre adjacent to the provisional Parliament House as shown in the attached location of site plans;
and further recommends
approval of the attached National Capital Planning Authority building plans.

I am not quite sure where we are if we do not take note of the paper. It seems that the recommendation is still there and probably has to be brought before the Parliament at some subsequent stage for debate. If that recommendation is brought forward for debate I will probably make a far greater contribution than I am going to make this afternoon. I just want to make a few comments about the report in the context of the motion that we have before us to take note of the report.

I have been a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House for quite some time. I cannot quite remember when I came on it but it was probably about 1980, so I have had about 10 years experience on the Committee. It was a very interesting committee to be part of because those of us who were on it for that time actually saw through the building of this place and had a very creative time in working with the architects. But this afternoon we are not talking about the building as such, we are talking about the child-care facilities and where they might be located. I just mention, though, that in the 10 years or so that I have been associated with the Committee there has been much talk but very little action about child-care facilities here, in the parliamentary zone or nearby.

As Senator Schacht mentioned, one of the first proposals was that there be child-care facilities in the Parliament House itself. When that proposal was put forward the new Parliament House was not built, we were still looking at plans, and there was a possibility, I suppose, that an area be set aside for child-care facilities. That did not seem to proceed in any way, and some suggestions were made yesterday, when we had our meeting, that it was probably because of one of the Presiding Officers not wanting to have child-care facilities in the Parliament House. That I cannot remember because it was some time ago.

Another proposal which came after that was that there should be some child-care facilities in the grounds. The first of those suggestions was that those child-care facilities, as far as I can recall, were to be in the western side of the building; in other words, on the Senate side, somewhere between here and the road to the west. That did not proceed. One of the other suggestions-perhaps it was the third suggestion-was that the child-care facilities be near the exhibition building to the east, or even the exhibition building could be converted when it was no longer needed. I am not quite sure of the total reasons why that did not proceed, but one was that a great deal of finance would have been needed to recast the exhibition building into a child-care facility. But there was also some suggestion that because so many motor vehicles pass that site there would be too much lead in the air. I do not think that that was ever tested, but it was a suggestion that was made, and that site fell into disrepute.

A further suggestion was-and it is the suggestion that we have before us at the moment-that a child-care facility be built in the gardens of the provisional Parliament House. That is the one that is before the Committee at the moment. It seems to me that this debate has probably gone on long enough. If we continue the debate then those young people who could be using a child-care facility would probably be here in about 30 years time still debating whether we are going to have a child-care facility and where it is going to be. I do not accept that the centre should not go in the gardens. I did not bring into the Parliament this afternoon my briefing papers from yesterday, so I do not have a copy of the report by the Australian Heritage Commission. I will not go into the Heritage Commission report in great detail but as far as I can recall, it stated that if the facility were to be built in the gardens it had certain suggestions about how it could be done.

I would just like to mention something about the gardens. They were established in about 1927. It was suggested to us yesterday that they might even have been started a little before the building was opened. But we can say they were established in about 1927. We should remember that in 1927 child-care facilities were not a high priority. In fact, they were not a high priority before the Second World War. There seems to be no reason now why the centre should not be located in the gardens. Perhaps by putting it in the gardens, or in the parliamentary triangle, we in the Parliament could show to the people of Australia that we have a commitment to child-care. Perhaps in the future-this might be drawing a long bow-historians will look at this child-care centre, if it is located in the gardens, as representing a commitment by the Australian Parliament, to providing child-care facilities and this might lead to the expansion of child-care facilities throughout the nation. I feel that the opposition to this proposal is nothing more than a delaying tactic to put off the decision and to put off the facility, perhaps even until the next century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am hesitant to speak for any length on this issue which has been very thoroughly canvassed on several occasions. There is not a lot that I would want to add to the fairly comprehensive explanation that was made last time we discussed this matter in this chamber. What is intended is community-based child-care which will be operated by a community group which will take part in its management and that group will make decisions about who should be eligible for care, what charges should be made, and so forth. Capital funding has been available for some time-probably for about 18 months now-and the Department of Community Services and Health has endorsed the proposition that there should be a community-based centre. As I have said, it would be up to the committee which runs that centre to decide who the users should be.

SPEECH.PARA: My involvement in this issue goes back to the time that I was first elected to the Senate 8 1/2 years ago. As Senator Colston has said, this issue has a very long history. I would have to agree with him that, time and again, we have been faced with a spoiling operation. We have put the matter off, we have put the issue off and we have put the decision off for one reason or another. We thought that we had won on a number of occasions only to find that somebody found another reason why the centre should not be built here, there or somewhere else. Having reached the point where we had decided that the site close to the provisional Parliament House would be suitable, we are now faced with another spoiling operation.

One of the reasons why I am reluctant to continue with the debate today is that we are hearing second-hand what the Australian Heritage Commission has actually said and I have a feeling that some of the quotes have been rather selective. I am not for a minute doubting the language that has been used by the Heritage Commission but I would very much like to see what weight the Commission has put on statements such as a `tragic loss', `intrusion', and so on. I am not doubting the historical and other value of the landscape and gardens. But why would an attractive, sensitively designed child-care centre, tucked in amongst the trees in the gardens, be any more intrusive than, for example, the High Court building? If there is talk of removing buildings, putting them elsewhere, changing their style or something like that, in my estimation that building would be a prime candidate for a change on the horizon.

Senator Sanders's suggestions about renovating other buildings have been considered and rejected. For very good reasons renovations tend to be very expensive. One might finish up with something that would cost more than a new building. Its requirements might be less than adequate for a modern child-care centre that is purpose built.

From what I can see of the plan that is included in this report today, the architects have been very sensitive to the concerns that have been expressed, even those expressed by Senator Michael Baume, Senator Reid, and so forth. It seems to me that a centre of this nature would enhance what is a very beautiful area which currently does not get a great deal of use. It is a very strange experience to hear the word `degradation' being used in relation to the notion of using a piece of public land for such a purpose. Everybody who has spoken has acknowledged the need for children's services, even if those people are not quite wedded to the notion of community-based care, which is what this centre is intended to be. The decision about that piece of land was made relatively recently by the local authorities who were asked to come up with suggestions of the most appropriate land. I am really quite surprised to find now that the Opposition is saying that the suggestions for other locations are just as appropriate. I have a horrible feeling that, whichever piece of land is decided upon in this area, there will be objections of one sort or another on one ground or another and we will still be having this argument in years to come.

As I have said, a great deal can be included in a debate of this nature. I am wondering whether there is much point in continuing the debate this afternoon in view of the fact that many of us have not had the opportunity of seeing what the Heritage Commission has actually said. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief. I say to Senator Colston that this is not a delaying tactic at all. We are totally opposed to the construction of the building in the parliamentary zone for some very good reasons which I will come to in a moment. Why is the child-care building required in the zone? In my view it is because the sisterhood of this building want to stamp their mark on the precincts of Parliament House.
—It wasn't part of the sisterhood.

—I have no doubt that it is part of the sisterhood. I have no doubt that the sisterhood lobbied the Cabinet and got their way. I have no doubt that it has nothing to do with the merits or the virtues of the argument. That is why we will have the child-care centre there. I am reminded of the conduct of a particular lady when Senator Tate was strolling on the lawns of the old Parliament House. It seems to me that, in a more sophisticated way, it is a repeat of that performance. Why are we setting out the territory? Why should we not have the centre somewhere else? Why does it have to be in the parliamentary precincts? Canberra is a big place; the facility could be put anywhere. But no, it has to be put smack bang in the middle of the gardens.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Giles says that she has not got the report of the Australian Heritage Commission. The report states:
If there is no feasible and prudent alternative to building a childcare centre in the former House of Representatives gardens, the Commission would favour it . . .
It goes on to talk about the style and the approach--

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going.
—Yes, I will, if it helps. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commission would favour the approach adopted by Denton Corker Marshall in their preliminary drawings.

In other words, it says that if all else fails the Commission would support the style that has been proposed. It is not a qualified objection; it is an unqualified objection. The Commission is very clear about its views. We are told in the executive summary:

The authors strongly believe that the integrity of the gardens in their 1927 form should be re-established and should then be protected in perpetuity. Most especially there should be no further development within these gardens.

It goes on to say that the significance of the old Parliament House landscapes and gardens cannot be assessed in isolation and that the gardens are an intrinsic and integral element of the old Parliament House building. It talks about the criteria it used in drawing its conclusions. It refers, for instance, to the possession of uncommon or endangered aspects of Australia's natural and cultural history. That is one of the qualifications that caused it to make the decision it did.

The Commission talks about a focal point of a place, the Parliament House vista, being entered on the Register of the National Estate. We are told by the Australian Heritage Commission that the Parliament House courtyards are considered to be of national significance because they are an integral element of a building entered in the Register of the National Estate and contribute in a positive way to its function and character. We are told further that they are considered to be of national significance because they provide an essential open space as a balance to the enclosed courtyards of the Parliament House building, reveal essential elements of the taste and style of a period, most particularly an international movement of landscape design for public settings. This is characterised by the use of the garden beds cut into the grass sward and the creation of formal garden patterns. It goes on to tell us all about the beauty of the design and the layout of the gardens. It states:

They form an essential element of the Canberra institutional landscape established in the 1920s and as such provide a setting contributing to many of Canberra's buildings entered in the Register of the National Estate, including the Hotel Canberra, Parliament House and the Albert Hall.
It makes us wonder, really, what the Register means to this Government. We are told in the summary:
The total Parliament House landscape and gardens is considered to be of national significance. No comparable landscapes of equal quality from their period have been identified in Australia.

My goodness gracious, they have no equal anywhere in Australia! If an animal, a wombat, or an Aboriginal carving were involved, there would be guards protecting it. But because it is what it is, part of a fundamental institution of Australia, we are to plop a building in the middle of it.

The landscape and gardens should be nominated for the Register of the National Estate for highlighting as a place which is significant within the area and should be listed by the Australian Heritage Commission in the Australian Capital Territory. There should be no further development within these landscapes and gardens, and intrusions should be removed. The Commission is not talking about putting new buildings in; it is talking about dismantling the buildings already there, intrusive as they are in the gardens. We are told in the same report:

The most significant aspect of these gardens is that they illustrate the sophisticated elegant simplicity of the original garden lay-out, something too rarely seen in garden treatments. Indeed I can think of no other landscape in Australia which has the potential to provide this elegance of the 1920's.
Their loss as an element of the Parliament House development would be tragic.
This is the objective, clinical assessment made by the Australian Heritage Commission in a report-not emotional wafflings but a clinical assessment. It uses the word `tragic'. It says:
In summary, we would strongly advise against this for the following reasons:
It gives a number of reasons which I choose not to read. It says in part:
an essential aspect of the original Parliament House building was its relationship with the adjacent gardens.
Taking the issue of historic precedent alone provides adequate reason for not implementing this scheme.

We are told in a very eloquent, and might I say elegant, way by the author of this document, the Australian Heritage Commission, that under no circumstances should this child-care building be located where it is proposed.

I challenge Senator Graham Richardson to come into this Parliament and lay out for us the arguments for and against the child-care centre being built where it is proposed and explain to the Senate what was the persuasive factor that ultimately caused Cabinet to decide to build the centre where it is proposed when it could equally have been built anywhere else in Canberra. As my colleague Senator Reid said, it could have been put inside the new Parliament House as I would have thought that it would serve primarily employees and workers from within this building. Yet that is too logical, too reasonable. We have to plonk it down in splendid isolation in the gardens of the old Parliament House.

It seems to me that every time Senator Richardson makes a decision in respect of the environment and in respect of our heritage all that is in the balance is the number of votes. We saw that in Kakadu. I have no doubt that there was a time when--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Crichton-Browne has been on the subject for quite some time, but he has started to deviate into extraneous matters. It would be more profitable for us all if you could get him back to the topic.
—Order! There is no point of order. Please continue with your remarks, Senator Crichton-Browne.

—I was seeking to discover-perhaps I was soliloquising-how this decision was arrived at. To try to draw some logical threads together we must compare it with the decisions in respect of Kakadu or Jervis Bay. In the case of Kakadu, I have no doubt that there was a time when he was on the Committee when Senator Richardson shared my view, but now he has decided that the decisions on Kakadu and Jervis Bay involve votes for the Government. The test of the integrity of a Minister when making tough decisions is whether he is prepared to make a decision that costs votes. Every decision thus far made by Senator Richardson is designed and intended to win votes. I challenge him to make a decision in respect of our environment, in respect of our natural heritage, which is unpopular with the community but which is done on the basis of integrity, honesty and reasonableness. We will not find one. On this occasion, because the sisterhood got into the ear of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and no doubt of Senator Richardson and the majority of Cabinet, we are finding that a report of the Australian Heritage Commission is being totally ignored. It has not even been challenged. There is no rebuttal of it; there is no argument against it. The Government could have come forward and at least proffered some pathetic excuse for disagreeing, but even that is more than it could cope with. So we have had absolutely no response at all. As I said, the building could be built anywhere in Canberra but we are told that we have to have it in the parliamentary zone. I challenge the integrity of the Government and ask it to explain to us how it chooses to ignore the Australian Heritage Commission's recommendation. It has ignored it for political reasons because the sisterhood has decided that it wants to put its stamp on the parliamentary triangle zone.

SPEECH.PARA: I am encouraged by the Australian Democrats' moment of enlightenment-a ray of knowledge, a flash of wisdom-and to discover that on this occasion they have at least been consistent. One of the qualifications of integrity is consistency, not pragmatism. The Democrats, at least on this occasion, have said that there are some heritage considerations that outweigh the consideration of the location of this building.

We are not arguing against a child-care centre or the intention of having child-care facilities which can be used by parents who are employed in this building or in nearby buildings. We are simply arguing against the degradation, the corruption, the destruction which will take place if this building is located as proposed. We are told that there are no similar gardens anywhere in Australia or which begin to compare with them. We are told it would be tragic if these gardens were damaged. We are told that they are an intrinsic and integral part of the old Parliament House, yet none of those arguments touches the conscience or the soul of this Government. Quite frankly, it is a crude, pragmatic, political decision, done for vested interest reasons. As I started to say, I am encouraged that on this occasion the Democrats have been consistent. I trust that they will join with us in ensuring that this proposal is ignominiously dumped, that the building is located where it deserves to be and that the gardens are preserved with the integrity they deserve.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table additional information received by Estimates Committee F.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twentieth report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Possible Unauthorised Disclosure of Senate Committee Report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) endorses the findings contained in paragraph 25 of the report; and
(b) adopts the recommendations contained in paragraphs 26 and 32 of the report.
On 18 August 1989 the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on visiting nuclear powered or armed vessels, and whether a contempt was committed by a person who made such an unauthorised disclosure.

The Committee, having established through correspondence with the Chairman of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, and examination of the newspaper reports he provided, that unauthorised disclosure of the contents of the report had occurred, first investigated a possible source of the disclosure.

One member of the Standing Committee, Senator Irina Dunn, advised the Committee of Privileges that she had orally briefed media representatives about the report, which also included her dissenting report, on the day on which the report was due to be tabled. She also indicated that, while she did not distribute any documents to the media, extracts from the report and the dissent, and media releases, had been prepared in her office in anticipation of the report's tabling, and thus could have been available to the media representatives.

This Committee, in its report, draws attention to a number of circumstances which it took into account when addressing the question of whether a finding of contempt should be made. As indicated at paragraphs 22 to 24, these included the unexpected delays which occurred in the tabling of the report, and the declaration by Senator Dunn that she did not intend to obstruct the Committee or the Senate, as evidenced by her not taking advantage of opportunities to do so at any time throughout the inquiry. In particular, the Committee draws attention to Senator Dunn's apology, quoted at paragraph 23 of this report, and reminds the Senate that, in similar circumstances some years ago, when a comparable apology was made, the Senate took the matter no further.

The Committee has therefore made the following findings in relation to the matter referred to it: Firstly, the Committee has concluded that, while it is open to the Committee and the Senate to find that a contempt has been committed, in the light of all the circumstances as outlined above such a finding should not be made. Secondly, although a premature briefing of media representatives was given, and the possibility of premature access to embargoed media releases and extracts of the report, including the dissenting report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on visits to Australia by nuclear powered or armed vessels cannot be dismissed, under the circumstances of the present case no further action should be taken. In making these findings, it also reminds honourable senators of their obligations under the Privilege Resolution and Standing Order relating to unauthorised disclosure, and specifically recommends that the President draw the relevant provisions to the attention of all senators.

The Committee has also taken the opportunity to address a number of other matters arising from its consideration of this reference. The Committee comments on the general question of contempt in relation to unauthorised disclosure, the role of the media in these matters, procedures for tabling reports, on which it has made a recommendation that the matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Procedure, and procedures that committees might follow if contemplating the reference of matters to the Committee of Privileges. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE AIRLINE PILOTS' DISPUTE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the interim report of the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters I table the report of the Committee on its inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) election and electoral system. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 7 March 1989 an election for the first self-governing Assembly of the ACT was held. Many features of the election were unique in Australian parliamentary electoral history. These features included the number of candidates-117; the size of the ballot paper-one metre long; the nomination of candidates from parties opposed to the principle of self-government; candidates from a relatively large number of nonsense parties-the Surprise Party and the Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party, to name just two; and, finally, the duration of the count, which took nine weeks and two days to complete. The electoral system which was used and which is known as modified d'Hondt is unique in international electoral history. The Australian Electoral Commission described it as an `electoral system unknown to man'.

Because of concerns that the length of time taken to count the votes and the complexity of the electoral system threatened the reputation and viability of self-government in the ACT, the Senate referred these matters to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in May this year. The terms of reference were: firstly, that the Committee review the electoral systems and the election process; secondly, that the Committee particularly examine whether the deposit required to be paid by candidates is adequate and, thirdly, whether the cut-off level for unsuccessful candidates is set at the most appropriate level. The Committee found that, given the circumstances of the election, the complexity of the electoral system and a prior agreement reached with the ACT Administration, criticism that the Australian Electoral Commission had been inefficient or dilatory in the conduct of the count and had failed in its education campaign to give voters sufficient understanding of the ACT electoral system to enable them to cast effective votes, was unwarranted.

The Committee found that the level of candidate deposit was too low and the conditions for party registration in the ACT too loose to discourage the involvement of frivolous candidates and parties in ACT elections. Accordingly, it recommends the raising of the deposit from $100 to $250, the same as is required for the House of Representatives. It also recommends that, for the purpose of gaining registration for the ACT elections, political parties be required to demonstrate a minimum membership of 100.

The threshold or cutoff level of 5.56 per cent of the formal vote for unsuccessful candidates was strongly criticised as arbitrary and unfair in the evidence put to the Committee. Such a threshold represents what is known as a `droop' quota. It is the same concept as is used in the Senate and Hare-Clark systems, but it operates differently from these. First, it bears no relationship to the percentage of votes required for election under a d'Hondt system; secondly, candidates who do not achieve the threshold level on a count of first preference votes are simply excluded and are unable to benefit from the distribution of preferences. The Committee concluded that the threshold was arbitrary, but was reluctant to make any separate recommendation. The Committee has made recommendations to tidy up the arrangements for party registration and to provide for the grouping of independents on the ballot paper.

The main consideration of the Committee was directed to the first of its terms of reference, namely, the electoral system and the election process. The modified d'Hondt electoral system was strongly criticised in the evidence before the Committee. One of the features most criticised is the complexity of the deeming provisions which can easily result in a person's vote being interpreted and counted other than in the way intended. The Committee has recommended that where appropriate the Senate's formality rules and deeming provisions serve as a model for the ACT system. Very few of the submissions received by the Committee supported the retention of any sort of d'Hondt electoral system. All recommended at least some changes.

The pure d'Hondt system, which operates in some parts of Europe, is a party list system which is generally regarded as operating fairly and equitably in the allocation of seats to parties. However, it does not allow electors to vote for individual candidates within a party. The Committee considered at some length whether it was possible to find some version of a d'Hondt system which could now be considered acceptable. It concluded that it was not. Because the major parties remain divided over their preferred alternatives of single member electorates on the one hand-the Australian Labor Party's preference-and a proportional representation system with multi-member electorates on the other-the preference of the Liberal Party and the National Party, the Committee decided it would be preferable to allow the people of the ACT to choose between three alternatives in a referendum, and has recommended accordingly. The Committee has also recommended that the Commonwealth fund a referendum offering these two alternatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrat and the Independent on the Committee were in favour of the preferential system.

—Yes. I was not intending to indicate otherwise, I was just indicating the preference of the major parties. As Senator Harradine points out, both the Australian Democrat member and Senator Harradine agreed with the multi-member electorate system. I did not mean to overlook Senator Harradine in that sense; I had assumed he would be speaking.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has further recommended that all parties should agree to introduce, at the earliest opportunity, whichever of the two electoral systems is preferred by a majority of ACT voters. The inquiry was undertaken by a subcommittee chaired by the member for Chisholm, Dr Michael Wooldridge, the other members being the member for Fisher, Mr Michael Lavarch, Senator Chris Schacht, and the honourable member for Dobell and Chairman of the full Committee, Mr Michael Lee. On behalf of the full Committee I would like to thank Dr Wooldridge and other members of the subcommittee for their efforts. I also wish to thank members of the secretariat for their work in enabling the inquiry to be completed within such a short time of its commencement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief. I would like to echo the remarks made by Senator James Short in congratulating the Chairman of the subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Dr Wooldridge, and the members of the subcommittee. Those of us on the full Committee had the responsibility of going through the report that was presented to us by the subcommittee. It is not unusual for members of the various committees of this chamber to be engaged in matters that seem to have very little relevance at all to their own constituency. This was a case in point given its relevance to most, if not all, of the members of the subcommittee and most, if not all, members of the full Joint Committee. Yet members of that Committee, and particularly members of the subcommittee, were prepared to spend long hours in examining a problem which affects the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). They undertook that task admirably, having received a substantial number of submissions, and brought forward this report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an interesting report and no doubt will be considered by a gaggle of political scientists and commentators. I feel that it is essential to make a point that was not stated by Senator Short, that in fact the majority of members on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters supported the Hare-Clark system for the ACT.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five all.

—Five all? No, I think it was the majority-the members of the Liberal and National parties, Senator Jenkins from the Australian Democrats and me. It is important that that point be made. The modified d'Hondt system got a run over the course. It is a little unfair to wipe out the modified d'Hondt system completely because in my view it has some merits. But overall the Committee felt that it was not an appropriate system for ACT. In the back of the Committee's report there is a little folder which contains, for the benefit of those who receive and read the report, a copy of the ballot paper. I am unfolding the ballot paper. I do not know how long it is, but--
—About a metre.

—One metre, is it? Yes, it is about a metre long. It is an indication of the difficulty, or the daunting task, that was presented to electors in the national capital when faced with an election under the modified d'Hondt system which was obviously a little too onerous for not only the electors but also the people who were counting the votes.

SPEECH.PARA: I will conclude by indicating that if the system is unworkable for the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly, the appropriate system to my mind would be the Tasmanian system, the Hare-Clark system, which has worked and receives the support of all parties, as I understand it, in the State of Tasmania. It is a system which should attract a good deal of support, but we did not feel it was our right to impose such a system on the Australian Capital Territory. There are arguments for and against the system; there are arguments for and against the single member constituency. In effect, we say to the Australian Capital Territory electors that they should, at some stage, have a choice as to what voting system should operate for the Legislative Assembly, and that is recommended in the report.

It may well be that the Legislative Assembly will come up with a recommendation. The Legislative Assembly may consider that it is the body elected by the people in Canberra to represent them and it may well be that the Legislative Assembly could consider this report and say, `Well, we think that a particular system is the one that should go forward. On behalf of the people of the Australian Capital Territory, we consider that a particular system is the most desirable, and recommend to the Government, and therefore to this Parliament, a system of election which could then form the basis of legislation to be passed through both Houses of Parliament'. That is a possibility. It may, indeed, be a less expensive possibility than the one we are recommending-namely, a referendum. It may well be that if some sort of agreement or majority support is received that might be the way to go. The Committee has recommended certain aspects and I invite honourable senators to study the Committee's report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak briefly on the fifth report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters inquiring into the Australian Capital Territory election and electoral system. I would like to say at the outset that this report will make excellent Christmas reading. It is almost as riveting as a good detective novel.
—Or a Christmas present.

—Yes. Chapter 1 sets the scene, `The Road to Self-Government'. Chapter 2, `Electoral Systems', describes the possibilities. In chapter 3, `The Evolution of a Unique Electoral System' and `Whence a d'Hondt system', the story unfolds. In chapter 4, `Specifications of the Modified d'Hondt Electoral System', the plot thickens or who dunnit? Chapter 5-at last the real action-`The Conduct of the Election', `The education campaign', `The Scrutiny'. Chapter 6-the day of reckoning-`Evaluation of the Modified d'Hondt Electoral System' and `Giving Effect to Voter Intentions'. Finally, chapter 7-the light of the horizon?-`An Examination of Alternatives'. There is also a Christmas present: tucked into a pocket on the back cover is a copy of the biggest ballot paper known in Australia; for all we know it may well be the biggest in the world. What a shame we are not being televised at present. As Senator Harradine has so admirably demonstrated, the ballot paper is indeed huge and very difficult to manage.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference of the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) electoral system are as follows:
that the Committee review the electoral system and the election process.

That the Committee particularly examine whether the deposit required to be paid by candidates is adequate and whether the cut-off level for unsuccessful candidates is set at the most appropriate level.

Those matters were dealt with extremely well. This is a full and comprehensive report. The full Committee reviewed the subcommittee's report. I commend the subcommittee for the production of the basic report. I commend the Chairman, Dr Wooldridge, and the other three members of the Committee, Mr Lavarch, Mr Lee, and Senator Schacht. The Committee came to a unanimous conclusion which, given the circumstances, is quite remarkable. It stated:

A referendum be held in the ACT to establish which of the two following electoral systems would be preferred by the majority of voters a system of single member electorates using the House of Representatives voting system a system of proportional representation with multi-member electorates modelled on the Tasmanian Hare-Clark voting system.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many in the electorates?
—That was actually not specified by the Committee, Senator. The conclusion continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government provide funds for the Australian Electoral Commission to conduct the referendum.
That was the unanimous conclusion which the Committee arrived at. Both systems of election were examined. I will briefly summarise the pros and cons for each of the systems. The Committee stated:

The preferred system of the Labor Party members remains single member electorates . . . namely, that it is a simple, trusted system, giving an unrivalled degree of local representation and most likely to result in stable government. The preferred system of the Coalition and of the Democrat representative, Senator Jenkins and of the independent, Senator Harradine, is a Hare-Clark system with multi-member electorates, on the grounds that: proportional systems are inherently fairer; can also provide local representation; would be ideally suited to the circumstances of the ACT and a system of proportional representation was overwhelmingly supported by the majority of groups giving evidence to the inquiry.

The Committee could foresee that neither systems could secure a passage through both Houses of Parliament. For that reason the Committee came to the conclusion that it would let the people of the ACT decide which of the two systems they would prefer.

I could canvass the pros and cons at length, but I believe that with all the legislation we have before us that would not be at all appropriate. However, I will make a few comments on the modified d'Hondt system. I do not believe that it is a system which is inherently fair. Because candidates who do not obtain 5.5 per cent of first preference votes are excluded, the final result is that some candidates who actually obtain a percentage lower than 5.5 per cent of first preference votes are elected. It is also not a fully preferential system. The surplus votes after election are not necessarily passed on because they cannot go beyond the party list.

In conclusion we should note that on page xxiii the report describes the modified d'Hondt electoral system as hopelessly ill conceived and irredeemable. I would like it on record that during the negotiations on self-government and the form of electoral system for the ACT my advisers and I pointed out to the Minister the problems that were inevitable should the Government persist with the modified d'Hondt system. I recommended, and even went so far as to introduce, alternative legislation proposing a system of proportional representation with multi-member electorates modelled on the Tasmanian Hare-Clarke voting system with special modification to suit the population, the geography and the growth patterns of the ACT. That was the discrete communities plan. I further proposed the holding of a referendum to allow the people of the ACT to chose their own electoral system. When the Government's legislation was debated, I also proposed numerous amendments, all of which were rejected by the familiar, unholy alliance of Liberal, Labor and National party senators voting together. I am not sure where Senator Harradine stood there.

The report recommends the holding of a referendum of ACT voters to choose between the single-member electorates and the Hare-Clarke system. It saddens me that the d'Hondt system was introduced for the ACT in its first election for its substantial Legislative Assembly because it has brought the never popular concept of self-government in the ACT into further disrepute, which is a matter to be regretted. Now that this report has been tabled, and after the ACT Legislative Assembly brings down its report very shortly, I hope that the matter can be resolved sensibly. In conclusion, the report is a good report and a full report. It makes good reading, and I would certainly recommend that people should read it. I would like to place on record here my personal thanks to the Committee as a whole, which was a very good committee to work with, and also to the Secretary, Mr Allan Kelly, the subcommittee Secretary, Dr Robyn Seth-Purdie, and the staff of the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENTARY INSTITUTIONS, THE NORTH ATLANTIC ASSEMBLY, CYPRUS AND PORTUGAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions, the North Atlantic Assembly, Cyprus and Portugal in September and October 1989. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement by the leader of the delegation, Mr Ronald Edwards, MP, and to continue my remarks.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

I present the report of the visit by the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions, the North Atlantic Assembly, Cyprus and Portugal in September and October of this year.

At the outset I should say that I was honoured to lead a delegation that was characterised by the bipartisan and disciplined approach of all members. There is no doubt that the success of the visit was due to the effective and harmonious working relationship that we all agreed was necessary at a pre-departure meeting, and which developed to a level which should become the standard for all parliamentary delegations. In this regard, I would like to pay a particular tribute to Senator David Hamer, the deputy delegation leader, for his assistance and unfailing co-operation. In addition, I must thank the other members who worked so diligently to guarantee the success of the visit and they are:
Senator Graham Maguire;
Senator Terry Aulich;
the honourable member for Calwell, Dr Andrew Theophanous;
the honourable member for Wannon, Mr David Hawker, and
the honourable member for Kennedy, the Honourable Bob Katter.

It was unfortunate that because of urgent and unforeseen circumstances it became necessary for Senator Hamer and me to return to Australia at the conclusion of the visit to the European Institutions. For the official visits to Cyprus and Portugal, Dr Theophanous was the delegation leader and he was ably assisted by Mr Hawker as deputy delegation leader. Therefore, my remarks will be confined to the period for which I was leader. I trust that there will be sufficient time for the honourable member for Calwell to address that part of the report that deals with the official visits to Cyprus and Portugal.

Before proceeding further it is necessary for me to acknowledge the assistance of those support staff who laid the foundations for the success of the visit. The staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office maintained the high standard of support which perhaps we sometimes take for granted. Our particular thanks go to Kieran Schneemann, Siobhan Ni Fhaolain and Cheryl Samuels. Excellent briefing material and assistance given by Dennis Argall and Frank Frost and his team of the Parliamentary Library allowed us to leave Australia confident in the knowledge that we were well briefed on current issues. The officers of our foreign service also provided briefing material and support that was of a consistently high standard. Our thanks also go to the staff of the House of Representatives printing unit for the professional printing of this report, which was completed in record time, and to Sue Cox who typed all the drafts and the final of this report. I particularly wish to acknowledge the exceptional work of Bertha Williamson and her quite efficiency and excellent support during the course of the visit.

The delegation visited Europe at a time of intense debate about the future of the European Community, the implications of the single market after 1992 and major developments in eastern Europe. Before departure the delegation set quite optimistic and extensive aims which are detailed in the report and which we modestly believe were achieved. However, the three major objectives of the visit were to adopt a high profile in presenting the Australian Government's position on issues of importance to Australia within the scope of the organisations, and countries to be visited; to assess the implications of a single market concept in the European Community as it is likely to affect Australia, and to assess political and commercial attitudes towards free trade, post 1992, and the Common Agricultural Policy in particular. At the Council of Europe we were able to gain acceptance for a number of significant changes to the draft resolution of the Committee on Economic Affairs and Development relating to the annual report on activities of the OECD.

During the course of our visit we had the opportunity to meet with Commissioner MacSharry and Commissioner Andriessen, as well as other senior officers of the European Community. Unfortunately, these meetings confirmed that it would be unrealistic for Australia to expect any further substantial changes to be made to the Common Agricultural Policy in the short term. Indeed, nations such as Portugal, Spain, Greece and Ireland, which need rural development, are seeking to maximise the benefits afforded by the CAP. However, the delegation considers that the best strategy for assaulting the CAP is to attempt to convince those responsible for financing it, of the costly and inefficient practice that they are funding.

Before concluding, I wish to state that it is our view that the annual visit to the European Parliamentary Institutions is absolutely essential as it provides opportunities for regular contact with European parliamentarians and officials, as well as forums, to present the Australian view on a wide range of issues.

Because the delegation was absent from Australia for a period of about four weeks and visited several European Institutions, the North Atlantic Assembly, Portugal and Cyprus, the report is quite comprehensive and, of necessity, is longer than is usual. However, I urge honourable members to read it in its entirety as it will give them a better appreciation of many issues that are currently of critical importance to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to move a motion to provide for the further consideration of this report next year under sessional orders relating to consideration of committee reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That further consideration of the report be an Order of the Day under Consideration of Committee Reports pursuant to Sessional Order.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent to the following Bills reported:
Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989
Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989

Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989
