Bounty (Photographic Film) Bill 1989
Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989
Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Hill had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert ``the Senate declines to give this Bill a second reading as the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill:
(a) imposes excessive and unjustified prohibitions and restrictions on the collection and use of personal financial information;

(b) fails to provide that credit reference agencies be able to give commercial organisations reasonable access to appropriate financial information they have collected provided that the information is reasonably required by a commercial organisation to assist it in making commercial decisions;

(c) will place obstacles in the way of the detection of fraud, add to the cost of insurance, goods and services, increase interest rates and impose additional costs and inefficiencies on business, its customers and the community;

(d) falls short of the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988, particularly those Principles designed to ensure that individuals are made aware that information concerning them has been disclosed;
(e) will have many unintended consequences to the detriment of consumers, credit providers, credit reference agencies and the community as a whole; and
(f) has been introduced without adequate consultation''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are finally debating the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 which would probably represent the biggest slaughter of small business that we have seen if it were to be passed without amendment. This Bill has come before the Parliament without much consultation with industry and, I presume, as a vote buying measure by the Government. The second reading speech presented on behalf of the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 is the next step in the Government's program to introduce comprehensive privacy protection for the Australian community. The principal purpose of this Bill is to provide privacy protection for individuals in relation to their consumer credit records.

They are very noble words indeed but small businesses are being slaughtered down the line. The use of credit is a very familiar and everyday practice in Australia. What may not be known is the vast database on the users of credit that is built up in Australia, and other places no doubt. This may not be generally known, but those who provide information before obtaining credit should know that their circumstances will be recorded for each lending institution. The centralisation of such data is only an expected outcome of that system. This could be for rationalisation of resources or exchange of information between lenders. After all, lenders want to have some idea of the past performance of borrowers. Finance companies are generally lending the money they have borrowed from smaller depositors in the first place.

For some time now there has been concern as to the use of the information held, but my prime concern is whether the information held is correct. To this end the borrower should always have access to his or her file to check that information is correct. I believe also that adequate protection should be afforded to credit consumers if wrong information is deliberately used against them.

There are various credit reporting agencies in Australia, by far the biggest being the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd (CRAA). CRAA holds information on 11 million Australians and organisations. Last year it handled 7 million inquiries from its 4,800 members. The main users of the CRAA database are public utilities, banks, finance companies, stores, credit unions, building societies, insurance companies, and real estate and mercantile agents. Information is held in relation to name and address, marital status, spouse, date of birth, driver's licence, employer and address, if any, directorships, default information, date of default, nature of default, repossessor in case of default, which CRAA member is inquiring, amount, court information, any bankruptcies or bankruptcy proceedings, records of inquiries made even if one is not asking for credit, whether by cheque or by cash. The CRAA sets up the file when the consumer asks for credit in the first place.

These reports are used for monitoring ongoing accounts, whether for goods, overdrafts or whatever. They are used by mercantile agents, who do a lot of the collecting of overdue debts, and by shire councils and other local government bodies. The reports are used by insurance companies to ascertain whether the person looking for insurance will be a good risk, and are also used sometimes when there is a claim on insurance. They are used when people are looking for a tenancy, to check whether they are a good bet before renting them a unit. They are even used by government. One may ask why government should use them. But there are times when even government departments will want to see how people are set up financially and whether their situation is sustainable. The immediate examples that I can think of are when one is taking out or taking over a taxi licence or when one is taking over a fishing licence. My State of Western Australia has a big fishing industry. The crayfishing industry especially is a limited access industry. If the fishing department were to receive an application for transfer of a licence-in the case of a crayfish licence it is a big figure-it would want to ensure that the person taking over is a worthy person.

Governments also like to inquire into the credit rating of someone taking out a legal gambling licence. Legal gambling is a bit of a misnomer but there are casinos and other gambling institutions around the place that are legal. These are not like some of the illegal ones that have been mentioned around the Australian Capital Territory lately. Organisations and individuals need to use these credit reporting agencies. I agree that there could be a problem with this system which has been set up for credit reporting. There is always a problem with the privacy of the information that is held. The Federal legislation seems to have been written on the basis of the report of the New South Wales Privacy Commission of recent date. It states, in part:
The Committee acknowledges that credit bureaux provide valuable information to credit providers on the advisability of offering credit to individual consumers.
It recognises that they provide valuable information. It continues:
A consumer's credit history is often a relevant factor to be taken into account when considering whether to provide credit to that person.
I certainly hope that it is taken into account when credit providers are using a lot of small investors' funds for loan purposes. I presume that it is. The report continues:

At the same time it is important to consider the legitimate interest of individuals in ensuring that information about them is collected fairly, maintained securely and is not open to misuse or improper disclosure.
I totally agree. It continues:
The conflict between values of personal privacy and those of economic efficiency is not a new dilemma for those concerned with protecting personal autonomy in an age of computerisation.

The problem is not a new one. I believe that the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA) and other similar organisations around Australia have in the past acted honourably and with integrity.

As I have said, the conflict lies between personal privacy and economic efficiency-economic efficiency for the consumer's own good. Consumers should be advised, of course, of the existence of the record and of their rights to look into the accuracy of the information. I have already said that people should know that these records are kept. But there are some naive people so people should be advised. It should be their right to be advised. The problems that can arise-they have happened-with the CRAA and other organisations include careless reporting or deliberate misreporting. Whoever deliberately misreports should be locked up in gaol. I know of one famous case where an ex-brother-in-law of someone applying for credit was stitched up as retribution for what happened in the family. Disputed debts could cause a problem. There could be problems with failure to report on the financial position of the people who have credit with spouse debts or ex-spouse debts and with access to correction. I believe that people applying for credit, or people who receive credit, should have a right at all times to have access for correction of the records. This has been a problem sometimes.
I will now move to the provisions of the Bill. The report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills outlines the definition of the Bill. It states:
The Bill defines a credit provider as:
(a) a bank; or
(b) a corporation (other than an agency)
(i) that is a building society; or
(ii) that is a credit union; or
(iii) whose sole or principal business or undertaking is the provision of loans (including . . . credit cards) intended to be used wholly or primarily for domestic, family or household purposes;-
I will go back to that one. Again, it states:
a corporation . . . whose sole or principal business or undertaking is the provision of loans . . . intended to be used wholly or primarily for domestic, family or household purposes.

I would like to know where the stock firms as we know them-suppliers of merchandise who sell and buy stock and provide finance; in other words, Elders Pastoral, Wesfarmers, Rural and the ones in the eastern States, such as Dalgety Australia Operations Ltd-fit into the definitions. They are probably the biggest suppliers of credit to the rural industry of Australia, mainly to woolgrowers and the ones that run stock, not so much to wheatgrowers. I would like to know where they are defined. The definition in the report continues:
(iv) that carries on a retail business in the course of which it issues credit cards . . .
It goes on. That is the definition. The comment of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee goes on to state:
Section 11b, when interpreted-
that is the first section I have mentioned-

in conjunction with section 18k, would appear to have the potential to exclude a very large range of business organisations, who currently have access to credit reports on individuals. These organisations include, but are not limited to:
Let me read out some of those organisations:
many finance companies (including members of the Australian Finance Conference)
most retailers
television and video rental companies
electrical retailers who hire equipment
plant and equipment hire companies
furniture hire companies
car rental companies
accountants
solicitors . . .
In some cases, a few uncharitable people would consider that that was a wise decision. The report continues:
all insurance companies; including mortgage insurance and trade credit insurance underwriters
advertising agents
newspapers and magazines (classified advertisements)
factoring organisations
mercantile agents
all public utilities and boards . . .
I have already told honourable senators about shire councils and boards. The report also lists:
doctors
hospitals and clinics
builders and home service suppliers
real estate agents

Real estate agents are very important. Private developers in Australia supply a lot of flats and units for rental. If the Australian Democrats are interested in this Bill I would like to hear what they have to say about this. The owners of these units, the landlords, will be at great risk if they do not know what sort of tenant they are likely to get. It will mean only one thing: increased housing and rental costs. As I have said, the report lists mercantile agents. It also lists:
motor vehicle dealers
hotels
suppliers of goods
manufacturers
travel and entertainment cards . . .

The thing that concerns me about this legislation-the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has pointed this out-is that this clause, coupled with proposed section 11b, gives wide-ranging powers to a public official, that is, the Privacy Commissioner, effectively to determine whether a particular organisation, which grants credit in the marketplace anyhow, is to be allowed access to credit reporting records, including the major source of consumer credit information. So the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has deduced, and the Minister has probably admitted, that organisations which they admit are providers of credit are being excluded because a public official, by regulation, has put them in that category. This is certainly something that we cannot put up with.

I turn now to positive reporting. Positive reporting is a reporting of what is going on in respect of existing credit contracts. One has to report on how a credit contract is going, especially if one's financial position is deteriorating. That is to be banned. It is certainly not in the best interests of consumers or providers of credit. What did the Government have to say about this? Senator Bolkus said in his second reading speech, amongst other things:
The Government and the community must continue to focus on education, appropriate counselling and most importantly on responsible lending practices.

This is what the Government has said it must do to overcome these problems. Obviously, this has nothing to do with credit providers having the right to get some information as to how people are going.
I have a summary of the Opposition's objections to the Bill and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. I have already cleared it with the Minister.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUMMARY OF OBJECTIONS TO THE BILL
The definition of `credit' and `credit provider' are so narrow as to exclude several thousand trading enterprises from access to credit reports on individuals.
Those still allowed access to credit reports will be severely restricted in their use of the information they receive.
Companies may not draw a credit report to review the status of an existing customer, even when that customer may be in financial difficulties.

Debtors who have left their address to avoid their creditors (clearouts) may not be reported to a credit reporting agency until they are more than 90 days overdue. This restriction will encourage fraud.
A credit reporting agency may not advise a creditor of the new address of a missing debtor.
Suppliers of consumer credit are denied access to any information about an applicant's commercial credit debts-even when the applicant is personally liable for those debts.
Commercial credit providers may not be told about an individual applicant's consumer credit debts-even when the applicant is clearly overcommitted.
Credit providers will be prevented from reporting credit default on millions of existing accounts.
Trading and credit organisations are banned from exchanging credit references, without the prior permission of their customers.
Insurance companies are banned from all access to personal information when assessing insurance claims.
Property owners are denied the right to inquire about the payment history of prospective tenants.
A creditor, seeking to recover a written off debt, may not pass on credit reporting information to a collection agent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. How will we deal with this in government if this Bill is enacted as it reads now? We will certainly make some changes when we are in government. The main changes will be as follows: we will legislate to allow credit reference reports to be supplied to real estate agents and property owners to assist them in their decision as to whether to accept a tenant, and other decisions they have to make about tenancies. We will legislate for access to the records of debt collectors, or creditors actually engaged in collecting a debt, but not private investigators. We will also legislate in relation to firms selling goods or services on hire purchase credit or terms, underwriters of mortgages, firms engaged in leasing, renting, hire purchase, and similar activities.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a few questions to ask the Minister, Senator Bolkus, which he can think about when he is contemplating further changes to this Bill. I will read these questions into Hansard. Why, in June, did Senator Bolkus advise the Senate that the cost to the community of this legislation would be minimal, when in May his own proponents of the Bill told him that consumers would pay higher charges and higher interest rates because of it? Why does Senator Bolkus continue to disparage the only economic impact study of the Bill when, even after his many changes, the independent consultants have confirmed that a conservative estimate of its cost to the community is in the order of $1.25 billion to $2.4 billion per year? Why is the Parliament being rushed into protecting frauds and cheats at the expense of the less well-off? Those are just a couple of simple questions that I would like the Minister to mull over in the course of this debate.

This Bill will not further protect consumers of credit to any great extent; it will simply help some Australians to dodge their responsibility, which will be paid for by others. These shortfalls will be picked up by others by way of extra costs and interest rates. Anyone who reads the Canberra Times, while they are in Canberra or at any other time, would have seen a full page advertisement the other day depicting what can happen under this legislation. What amazed me--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who from?

—Senator McKiernan would not want me to incorporate this advertisement in Hansard so that he can read it. I do not think it would fit. But the number of organisations it represents is astounding. I come back to the question that I asked earlier: What will the increased cost to Australians be? The legislation will cost between $1.3 billion and $2.4 billion a year. This will lead to interest rate rises of up to 1.5 per cent. This Government is saying that it is attempting to cut interest rates. All Australians want to see interest rates cut, yet here we have a measure which will cost so much and which will cause interest rates to rise. I believe that the Government is certainly going down the wrong track.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, this is the biggest slaughter of small business that I have seen while I have been in this Parliament. For a small business to carry on, it must be able, with a limited amount of finance in the bank-it is mostly finance that is borrowed-to know who are the most reasonable people to deal with. Small businesses must have the right to collect the money owing to them by being able to extend credit to their customers. Small businesses must have this right. I think it is an inherent right for all Australians, and this Bill flies in the face of that principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 is a very good example of a problem within an industry, if the industry takes the problem to the Government, very soon becoming a crisis. The Government, fundamentally, is here to protect our privacy, not to invade it with such things as the Australia Card, and the pharmacy card that is proposed to be introduced. This Bill is a typical example of the way the Government has gone about its legislation recently. There has been improper and inadequate consultation with the industry concerned, inadequate investigation of the issues involved and incongruous conclusions derived from the meagre evidence that it has gleaned, producing inadequate legislation with many intended and unintended consequences requiring massive amendments. The Government itself has had to put up 40-odd amendments to its own Bill. The Bill is going to put insupportable controls and restrictions on business and people at increased cost and with no discernible benefit. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) is in the chamber. I think the Minister thought he was on to a winner, but he has been conned into the precipitate introduction of this Bill by some sort of ideological claptrap of support for some of his civil libertarian sycophants. That is how it appears to me.

SPEECH.PARA: There are undoubtedly some genuine complaints about the Bill, but most of them are about the reporting standards of government commercial operations-such as Telecom Australia, for example. I heard about one complaint just the other night where a married chap applied for a loan but was refused. His wife happened to work for one of the credit reference agencies and had an access number she was able to ring in order to find out why he had been refused. He was refused because he was having an argument with Telecom over his telephone bill which he had not paid. So Telecom notified the credit reference people that he had a bad debt and he was refused a loan. Subsequently, his telephone bill was rectified, but Telecom did not rectify the entry that had gone to the credit reference agency. So, undoubtedly, there are bad reporting procedures that should be got rid of but, as I say, mostly they come from government agencies, and the Government ought to fix up its own act rather than put restrictions on private business.

The whole attitude of the Australian people, I think, has been undermined by their access to credit cards. Banks and lending agencies have issued credit cards to people without asking for adequate security or without checking on their ability to repay. That has led to a plastic money society, and I think that situation has to be rectified so that people can take some responsibility for themselves without having the responsibility taken from them. I do not see this Bill as being at all urgent. The Bill is being debated in the Senate as an urgent Bill, but there is no need for the unseemly haste that has been urged upon the Senate by the Minister.

Any credit reference operation should work on the basic twin principles of reliability of the financial information stored for its members and then a mechanism for consumers to be advised that commercial enterprises will have access to this information about them. There should also be an opportunity for them to obtain redress for improper use of that information. Individuals and businesses wishing to do business with other businesses and individuals often have the need to establish the creditworthiness of the other party. To satisfy this need, credit references bodies have arisen and, in general, they operate on sound principles with regard to both accuracy and privacy.

The creditworthiness of individuals and businesses is often required to be looked into by banks and financial institutions, vehicle hiring firms, equipment hiring firms and real estate agents-and I understand that real estate agents were not covered by the first amendments that we saw, although another two swatches of amendments were circulated today which I have not yet had time to read. These thick bands of amendments were delivered to my office at about quarter-to-five this afternoon. The sellers of goods and services have to check the creditworthiness of people as do debt collectors and insurance companies in order to prevent fraud, for example. So credit checking is widespread, is done on a regular basis and is essential in today's business world.

In Australia, 98 per cent of credit referencing for individuals is done by the Credit Reference Association of Australia Limited (CRAA), which is owned by its 4,800 members, those being the major government utilities, banks, finance companies, department stores, credit unions, building societies, insurance companies, credit card companies and many manufacturing and trading companies. Enormous use is made of credit referencing by people in their trading arrangements, and it has grown from originally a card index system into a sophisticated computer network. The database now holds records of over 10 million individuals and businesses and members of CRAA make about 7 million inquiries a year-not only about lending money but also about extending credit. Credit reference is, therefore, widespread and its business is increasing and many commercial undertakings in Australia are dependent upon it.

The database files, which produce printouts, are based on information on defaults sent in from members of CRAA and from public records-for example, bankruptcy orders and judgments, company records and insurance claims. In addition to that information, inquiries made by members of CRAA are recorded for their own purposes. All of this information enables members to make a better informed decision on whether or not to lend money or to extend credit-for example, whether or not a business or an individual is a good credit risk. But, conversely, access to this information acts in the interests of the borrower to prevent an individual or a business overextending their repayment capacity.

Of course, just who has access to this database is important and has been the subject of much debate, particularly in recent times. Members of the CRAA, of course, have access to the database, which is gained by telephone, by computer to computer links or by personal computers via the telephone network. Most access is by computer. The CRAA operator brings up the file, gives the member a printout and the member then has to make his own commercial judgment on any future business arrangements he may make. Any member making improper use of the information, or not complying with the secrecy rules faces expulsion, and that is a very important prohibition on misuse of the information. Consumers who have been refused credit also have access to their own files, free of charge, to assess the reason why they have been refused. Also, any person on whom records are kept can have access to his own files at any time for a payment of a fee-I think it is currently $5.

The CRAA also operates an insurance information service and holds information on approximately three million insurance claims. Its function is to give insurers information about previous claims, together with other credit information, thus reducing the possibility of future fraudulent claims. Naturally, this keeps insurance premiums down. I notice huge full page advertisements in the Canberra Times listing the hostility there is to the Bill and warning people of the increased costs that they will be up for, should the Bill go through as it is today, not only with interest rates but also with an increase in insurance premiums.

The CRAA maintains responsible security by strictly limiting access to its database, and it has an extensive system of verification of the data stored. For example, it examines applicants for membership closely and monitors the way in which its members use the service. As I have mentioned before, the ultimate penalty for breaches is expulsion of the member. Just what information is stored is important. The CRAA has its own rules on what information it will store and what information it will not store, and it keeps only financial matters relevant to credit extension or other relevant commercial decision. It does not keep information on race or national origins; political, social or religious beliefs; lifestyle or sexual practices or preferences. It does not allow its data to be used for private investigation purposes, pre-employment checks or to generate direct mailing lists.

The Minister placed great stress on the CRAA's accent on negative reporting-as opposed to positive reporting-and used this as the basis for urging the urgency of the Bill, which is ridiculous. There is widespread discussion in progress right now about the prospects of positive reporting-that is, the reporting of an individual's cash flow payments-so that the good news can accompany the bad news, if there is any. Credit providers would be able to make a more perspicacious decision on whether to extend credit. This extension would require the CRAA to keep records of almost all transactions in Australia, and that would require an enormous expansion of the databank. It would resemble the databank that was proposed for the Australia Card, for example, and the one that will be needed for the pharmacy card, should that come in. I remember the problems that raised before. The important thing about the Australia Card was that the number on that card related to the person, as opposed to the numbers that are on Bankcards and other credit cards which belong to the card. With the Australia Card an audit trail could be established on a person and follow them around. If a married man bought a set of ladies' underclothes that was not the same size as those of his wife, he would be able to be picked up on that. There are enormous concerns and implications for recording every transaction in Australia.

Clearly, if information from the databank is stolen or improperly used, there could be a massive invasion of personal or business privacy and it is this concern which led to this Bill in the first place. But, the Bill does not allow for positive reporting, which was supposed to be one of the objects of the Bill, and even restricts negative reporting, which is the whole aim and object of credit reference reporting. Nobody is arguing that we do not need legislation to protect our privacy but this Bill is not the way to go. In fact, this Bill has become a hotchpotch of random prohibitions principally to restrict access to the files and then to restrict credit reporting itself. This is ridiculous when it is obvious from all the evidence that we need a more liberal use of credit reference reporting in order to do better business and prevent bad business and fraud.

The Government is trying to establish rules on such things as what information may be kept, how long it may be kept, its accuracy and security; access to the data base; alterations of incorrect information; disclosure of information on file; the uses the information can be put to; the penalties for including false or misleading information on the files; a code of conduct for the detailed operation of the system and enforcement by the Privacy Commissioner. This all sounds good, but the Bill is heavily slanted against business and commerce. It severely limits the use of credit referencing and it prohibits some of the uses that are both necessary and legitimate. The CRAA itself has estimated that if this Bill goes through over 90 per cent of its members will no longer be able to use its services, even with the foreshadowed amendments. I am not sure about the amendments that came around late this afternoon-there may have been later additions, but they merely go to show just how inadequate the Bill was in the first place. No wonder there has been a massive outcry from many people in the industry. I point again to the huge advertisements that have appeared in the newspapers today, and the hostility has been demonstrated in the Senate this afternoon.

Virtually the whole of the industry has ranged against the Government because of this Bill. It will force many credit referencing companies to close and severely restrict others. Business costs will escalate and insurance premiums will rise because of it. Interest rates will rise even further than they are today-and, heaven knows, they are exorbitant now. Borrowers will sometimes overcommit, and other borrowers will be hurt as decisions on advances to them will not be made on reasonable and objective information. In other words, sometimes to stop people borrowing is just as important as to allow them to borrow.

The exclusion of insurance companies and real estate agents from credit information is commercially unrealistic-and even Labor Ministers around Australia are objecting. The Bill's definitions are incomplete and inadequate. For example, credit is defined as a loan for domestic, family or household purposes. The Bill restricts provision of information to a credit provider. So how could a real estate agent check the standing of his client, because he is not providing a loan? How could a company collect a debt, because it is not providing a loan? How could a creditor locate a debtor, because a loan is not involved in that? How could a business sell goods on terms or credit? No loan is involved there. How could an underwriter back a mortgage? How could a company hire out goods or equipment? How could a credit provider review his slow payers or locate a missing debtor? No loans are involved in any of those operations. If insurance companies are prohibited from checking the credit default record of claimants, obviously this will increase fraud and cause a rise in premiums.

Bad debts are dealt with unrealistically as the Bill prohibits their recording unless they are 90 days overdue. It was 90 days overdue, I think it then went to 60 days overdue, and it may have been altered again in the subsequent amendments that were produced late this afternoon. The Bill also severely restricts the amount of default information that may be kept. The distinction between personal, domestic and business credit is unrealistic, as access to credit reference on personal files for business finance is effectively prohibited, because an agency will be permitted only to disclose information concerning domestic, family or household loans. For all its pretences this Bill does little to protect privacy. It does not reflect the information privacy principles set out in the Government's own Privacy Act 1988. The Bill stops credit providers from passing on information concerning defaulters to other credit providers without their consent. How do credit providers get this consent when they do not know where the defaulter is or if the debtor refuses consent until after the default has occurred? The Bill is not urgent; it should be withdrawn and put to the industry and the people concerned and then redrafted. I support the Opposition's amendment to this effect and seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.27 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition thanks the Minister for accepting the Opposition amendments. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, has taken on board all the queries that were raised by those on this side of the chamber and we now have what we argued for strongly in the committee stage. We have a charter, a contract, on nursing homes and hostels that will have to come under the supervision of both Houses of Parliament and the principles will have to come before both Houses of Parliament before they become an Act of Parliament, which is what we sought in the debate at the committee stage. The Minister has picked up our amendments in one form or another, and we thank him for that. I just say to Senator Cook that if he had listened to us in the first place we could have gone without all this pain and suffering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with the Opposition, we accept that the spirit of the original amendments has been accepted by the Government. The words which the Government is seeking to replace those amendments with have exactly the same effect-that is, to ensure that the charter of residents' rights will come before both Houses of Parliament and before those affected, both residents and care givers, whereby there will be an opportunity for close scrutiny for potential amendment before the charter actually becomes law.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would like to ask the Minister one question relating to amendment No. 5, clause 4 (4), which reads:
A copy of the statement referred to in subsection (2)-
which is the charter-
must be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the formulation of the statement.
How does one know when the statement has been formulated and at what stage is it regarded as having been formulated so that one knows when the 15 sitting days begin?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am but the humble instrument that conveys this message and know not all the details of the tune I play. The honourable senator asked me a penetrating question about a matter of minutia that I do not have instructions on, so let me extemporise as to what I think is the case. I believe that the Government would indicate the date that it has framed for the proposal. The Senate and the House of Representatives can count back the days to make sure that the Government complies with the 15 days. As I have said, I do not have specific instructions on that, but I believe it would be for the Government to indicate the date when the 15-day clock begins to tick.

—I think that putting 15 sitting days into this is very interesting in view of the rumours in relation to an election and the possibility of our not sitting until well into next year. I understand that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, is hoping to have the charter ready some time in March. Supposing there were an election, 15 sitting days might take it well on into April or even into May. The charter would then be laid before each House for a further 15 sitting days. I recognise that the Government is keen that the whole of this period be completed before 1 July because it wants a a 1 July start-up date. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats also want the process to be expedited as far as possible, but allowing an adequate time for review. This may be a difficult question, but I wonder whether the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) could indicate whether there is any chance of an earlier formulation of the charter?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —If an election intervenes during the period in which this charter is lying on the table in the Senate or the House of Representatives, when we come back after the election we will complete the work that we started before the election.
—You will not; the incoming government will.

—We will. I am giving an undertaking that when we come back as the Government we will complete the work. We do not make decisions on the basis of rumours that there will be an election on this date, that date, or some other date; we make decisions on the basis of what we think is reasonable management for a government. However, the question the honourable senator asked me specifically--
—Oh, come on! You'd have us believe anything.

—I am answering a question directly, and as straightforwardly as I can. Senator Coulter asked me to give a specific indication to the Committee on whether this matter can be expedited so that we can complete this 15-day lying on the table period as soon as possible in the new year. I think that was his question. If the honourable senator will just give me a moment, I will ask my adviser if he can shed some light on that. We are caught in the bind that the sooner we put it down the shorter the period for consultation. We obviously want to exhaust the prospects of consultation so that no-one can say that this is a dictatorial government trying to give the groups with whom it is consulting something that they may not want or that it did not give them sufficient time to respond. That is a constraint on my answering the question directly. I understand and sympathise with the honourable senator's point of view. We will try, as well as we humanly can, to expedite the process at the earliest possible date but, if that means that we are running into problems on the consultative front by cramping the time for the agencies and bodies to reply, we will have to fulfil our consultative commitment before putting down a statement.

—I have a final point. This first clause constrains the Government in terms of the time in which it must lay the document before both Houses of Parliament. There is no constraint, however, on the laying of that document before the affected bodies. I make a plea to the Minister that as soon as the document is formulated it be made as widely available as possible to the affected bodies so that we do not have to wait for the document to be put before both Houses of Parliament before the wide consultative process can begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that is an eminently sensible suggestion, and we are suggestible on the subject of it. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 is a very important Bill. It was introduced in the dying hours of the autumn session of Parliament this year. It has various purposes and provisions but two of the main provisions are to insert a new part IIIA into the Privacy Act 1988, providing for regulation of the practices of credit reporting agencies and credit providers in relation to personal credit information. It also provides for the development of a code of conduct for the collection and handling of personal credit information by the Privacy Commissioner in consultation with the credit industry, government, consumer and privacy groups and other relevant bodies. There are other important provisions as well, but they are encapsulated in those two main provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Bill was introduced in the dying stages of the autumn session there has been no action other than the Government's announcement on 5 October-not in this Parliament but through a press release-that it would be making 41 amendments to its still undebated Bill necessitated because of major deficiencies of both a conceptual and a drafting nature in the original version. This is typical of the sloppy thinking and administration of this Government. Rarely nowadays in the Parliament do we have a Bill introduced which is not required to be subsequently amended because the Government got it wrong in the first place. To me that is the mark of a very sloppy and lax government administration.

We are now being asked to debate and pass this Bill in the dying hours of this session. Obviously with the pressures on the Parliament-we are working right up until this Bill is passed; we are right on the knocker of Christmas-there is totally inadequate time for proper debate and deliberation. The Opposition cannot understand the rush with this Bill. It sat there for months right through this session and now it is being debated in the last two days of the session. Why the urgency? Why must this Bill be passed this session? It is a very important Bill, but it is not an urgent Bill so far as its contents are concerned. It is a contentious, controversial and a much criticised Bill. Why not give it the consideration that it deserves? That consideration is quite impossible in this frenetic time scale.

What is the reason for the rush? What is the deal? There must be a deal in this somewhere, otherwise we would not be conducting ourselves in this unseemly way. Who is the deal with? What is the hidden agenda? I urge the Government and presumably the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, who will be taking this Bill through-it is his Bill-to give us answers to those questions and to come clean with the Parliament and the electorate. Then we may have more sympathy for the Government's actions. Until it does come clean we are forced to regard this Bill with the greatest suspicion indeed.

There is very considerable opposition to this Bill. Not opposition to appropriate legislation per se-most of the parties to the consideration of this matter, the industry itself and this side of politics, recognise that appropriate legislation is desirable-but to this Bill because it does not constitute appropriate legislation. It is a fundamentally flawed Bill. The Liberal and National Parties are not alone in this view. There are no less than 44 business and industry associations which have publicly criticised the Government's proposals. In addition, thousands of individual companies, particularly small businesses, have done likewise. These associations are not small beer; they represent thousands of member companies. They also indirectly represent the interests of millions of Australian consumers. Members of these associations together have responsibility for the handling of literally tens of billions of dollars each year.

Let me name just a few of them: the Australian Finance Conference; the Life Insurance Federation of Australia; the Insurance Council of Australia Ltd; the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd (CRAA); the Institute of Mercantile Agents Ltd; huge insurance companies like the National Mutual Life Association of Australia Ltd; the Real Estate Institute of Australia; the credit union movement; banks like the Challenge Bank Ltd; organisations such as the Advertising Federation of Australia Ltd, the Australian Association of Co-operatives Ltd, the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies, the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Australian Chamber of Manufacturers, the Australian Retailers Association, the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Institute of Directors of Australia, the Victorian Credit Co-operative Association Ltd and many others.

These are big names, they are responsible names, they are associations and companies with very high reputations when it comes to their dealing with money and credit and the putting of views to Government on necessary policy issues. They are the associations and organisations which this Government would normally consult and try to reach agreement with before bringing in major pieces of legislation. I am amazed that the Government is rushing this Bill through in the way that it is in the face of that opposition. Again I ask the Government to tell us why there is the need for this unseemly haste.

I will come back to the content of some of the concerns of these organisations a little later in my remarks. As well as private sector organisations, concern has been expressed by several of the States, and it is a pretty mixed bag. For example, the South Australian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Sumner, in a press release, last month, said:

I support the need to ensure that safeguards for positive reporting exist, but this should not be at the expense of overturning the balance between consumer rights to privacy and industry rights to information.
The Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Tom Roper, in a press release on 22 October, said:
The Federal Privacy Bill will not help to stop people becoming financially over-committed.
Indeed, Mr Roper wrote publicly to the Real Estate Institute of Victoria earlier this year as follows:
. . . I wrote to Senator Nick Bolkus, the Federal Minister for Consumer Affairs, expressing my concern about the proposed Bill.

I outlined in that letter my view that insurance companies and estate agents be allowed to retain their membership of CRAA and suggested that the Bill's focus might be expanded to regulate the collection and handling of personal credit information across the three industries.
That is a political input from Victoria. In a press release on 25 October the Chairman of the Queensland Privacy Committee said:

There is little point in introducing legislation which does not significantly contribute to protecting individual privacy if it also introduces barriers to long established business practices and huge costs to the Australian community.

He was also referring to the legislation we are now debating. Mr Gerry Peacocke, the New South Wales Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, wrote to the Minister on 20 September saying that he strongly opposed the legislation and requested the Minister to withdraw it. The New South Wales Privacy Committee itself has expressed concern about the Bill on the grounds that it is inappropriate and impractical, and has criticised the focus of the credit reporting legislation for a variety of reasons, particularly those of a practical nature.
There is a formidable array of opposition to this Bill. And what does the Minister think about this? A spokesman for Senator Bolkus was reported in the Bulletin of 24 October as saying:
The lobbying against it-
that is, the Bill-
is a bit of a giggle.

Now there are not too many people in the industry, and people who have had a look at this Bill, who are giggling. It is not a laughing matter. It is a very serious matter indeed. It is a matter which poses major problems for a wide range of not only the companies involved in the industries which rely on credit reporting, but also the millions of consumers who will be adversely affected by this legislation.

Senator Bolkus has accused the Opposition of having an anti-privacy stance because of our opposition to this Bill. Let us be clear about who has the anti-privacy stance in this place. It was this Hawke Labor Government which tried to introduce the intrusive and un-Australian ID card-the Australia Card. It was this Government that tried to introduce an anti-rights bill of rights. It was this Government which introduced referendum changes which were fundamentally flawed on individual rights grounds, and which were roundly rejected by Australians. Let us have no more cant about who is concerned about the whole question of privacy in this country.
We are opposed to this Bill because it is a bad bill. It is a fundamentally flawed Bill. In his second reading speech, Senator Bolkus said:

The . . . Bill is the next step in the Government's program to introduce comprehensive privacy protection for the Australian community. The principal purpose of this Bill is to provide privacy protection for individuals in relation to their consumer credit records.

The Bill is really the Government's response to the problems that a modern democratic capitalist society has in relation to privacy and the provision of consumer credit. Specifically, it aims to establish a privacy framework for the regulation of the consumer credit reporting industry.

The coalition agrees with the principle underlying the Bill in the sense that personal and individual privacy is central to our whole value system. The Liberal and National parties, as I have said, have a proud record of protecting individual privacy and campaigning strongly against Orwellian Big Brother policies. Like the Government, we subscribe to the guidelines on personal privacy of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). I remind the Senate that those guidelines include that there should be limits to the collection of personal data and that that personal data should be relevant to the purposes for which it is to be used and it should be accurate. The purpose for which personal data is collected should be specified at the time of collection and subsequent use should be limited to the fulfilment of these purposes. Personal data should not be disclosed for other purposes except with the consent of the data subject or where required by law. Personal data should be protected by security safeguards. Individuals should be aware of who hold their personal data. Individuals should have a right of access to, and correction of, their personal data. The final OECD guideline is that data controllers should be accountable for complying with measures to give effect to these principles.

Despite our agreement with those guidelines, however, we have major concerns about the Government's proposals. We do not believe that this so called Privacy Amendment Bill can meet the laudable intentions which its name suggests in the consumer credit area. Rather than improve the lot of Australians, it will stifle business confidence and activity. It will result in more red tape and higher prices for consumers.

As I said earlier, since the introduction of the original Bill the Government has proposed no less than 41 amendments to its original draft. But those amendments do not reflect adequate consultation with organisations, companies and agencies that will be directly affected by the Bill. Apparently, Senator Bolkus is reported as having told the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that industry has no problems with this Bill. That is simply not so. Senator Bolkus ought by now to be very well aware of that.

The simple fact is that, despite those recent amendments, this Bill is still essentially flawed. Many of the objectionable anti-business and anti-consumer elements are still contained in it. There has been an expansion of the definition of credit transactions to include hire purchase, credit contracts, leases and rental agreements for goods and services, which will enable the relevant credit providers to have access to credit reporting agency files. However, many important transactions are excluded. Many existing members of the Credit Reference Association of Australia, or the CRAA, will continue to be denied access to credit files and many organisations reliant on credit rating agencies will also be deprived of essential information on creditworthiness.

In its original form, Australia's primary credit association, the CRAA, estimated that over 90 per cent of its members would no longer be able to use its services. The amendments that the Government has introduced have changed that situation to an important degree but, even with the Government's amendments, 25 per cent of CRAA's members will still be precluded from using its services. That 25 per cent, amounting to 1,200 former users, includes all mercantile agents, real estate agents, loss assessors insurance companies and brokers. It also excludes government departments, even where they offer credit. Collectively, those organisations deal with billions of dollars annually, and accurate credit information is of prime importance. Also adversely affected will be that huge range of other small businesses that depend on the creditworthiness of suppliers, customers and other clients. Businesses, including real estate agents, debt collectors and small business, have every right to do these credit checks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only a right; they have a duty.

—As my colleague Senator Archer has quite rightly pointed out, business is charged with a duty to its shareholders and its enterprise to do so. Only through such checks can business discharge its responsibilities towards it shareholders and clients. It is a legitimate and necessary function of business.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there are the responsibilities that business has towards consumers. One of the biggest problems in the credit area is that people can get in over their heads. They take out loans and purchase goods on credit which they cannot afford to repay. Over recent years, particularly with the staggering increase in interest rates, that has become an increasing problem.

The problem with the Bill which is now before the Senate is that it will exacerbate the consumer debt problem. The ability of business to perform credit checks through the credit reference agencies is essential on two counts: first, it mitigates the prospect of consumers getting in over their heads; and, second, it enables businesses to represent the interests of their clients and shareholders in a reasonable and just way. Under the Bill, real estate agents will not be allowed to check the solvency of a tenant. When it is realised that real estate agents are charged with looking after an asset-in today's terms worth on average well over $100,000-it is ridiculous that they are not allowed to take measures to protect themselves and their clients against bad debtors.

Under this Bill, members of the Mercantile Agents Association will be precluded from obtaining credit reports from credit agencies like the CRAA. The implications of this for many Australian small businesses are far-reaching. The builder, tradesman, importer-in fact, anyone who has to outlay money in providing a service and who, therefore, runs the risk of bad debts-are all precluded from being able to chase up the bad debtor in an effective manner because debt collectors, under the legislation, are excluded from using the services of a credit reference agency. Small businesses will have no-one to turn to in the event of bad debts. If defaulters change their addresses or skip the State, there is no way the small businessman can find out. Such businesses are too small to become members of the CRAA; it is expensive-and, in any case, the Hawke Government now proposes that most of them would be ineligible to join.

Credit reporting in Australia is widespread. Most of it is done through CRAA, which is the largest credit reporting agency in the country. My understanding is that there is a code of conduct for the industry and that members who break this code are liable to expulsion from the Association, and other penalties as well. So the only people who have anything to fear from credit reporting are those who have broken the law by failing to pay their debts.

A key assumption of the Bill is that everyone has the right to have their privacy protected regardless of circumstances. I think that is a very debatable proposition. There is a strong argument to be made that, when people break the law-in this case they fail to pay their debts-they lose some of their rights. Businesses considering whether to loan such people money, rent them a property, and so on, have a right to discover the credit history of their potential clients. Businesses who have suffered at the hands of bad debtors have a right to be able to chase them up in the most effective way. This Bill imposes a new regulatory framework on Australian business which is flawed and which will ultimately cost the innocent consumers through rising prices. The 90 per cent of innocent, totally credit worthy consumers will bear the burden.

I repeat that the legislation as it stands is fundamentally flawed. It is so flawed that the Minister was forced to flag his intention to move 41 amendments in an attempt to improve it. It adds to the growing list of changes. Not far down the track are the class action and product liability proposals and others-a growing list of changes that this Minister is foisting on Australian business that will inevitably and ultimately hurt ordinary consumers. This anti-business agenda of the responsible Minister-and he is doing it on behalf of the Government-can only hurt Australian consumers. It will lead to higher compliance costs and, therefore, prices. There must be a better approach to the privacy and consumer credit issue and such an approach is readily available.

The principles on which I believe legislation in this area should be based should be clearly stated. There are two basic principles which should underly such legislation. Firstly, commercial organisations should have access to appropriate information that enables them, on the basis of that information, to make sensible, commercial decisions. Secondly, consumers should be given reasonable notice that commercial organisations have had access to this information about them, should be able to obtain redress for improper use of that information and should be able to verify the accuracy of that information. This legislation satisfies neither of those principles. It will result in more red tape. Like the invidious class action and product liability proposals that are around, it is totally at odds with the commitment of the Government and of the Prime Minister personally to reduce costs and eliminate red tape for business.

The problems with the Bill go much deeper. They go to basic principles about the whole role of government in relation to business. I fear that, if the anti-business stance of this government, as exampled in this Bill and the way it is drafted, continues unabated it will ultimately destroy the Australian economy. I support very strongly, as do all members of the Opposition, the stand announced on our behalf by Senator Hill in opposing this Bill. We have a large number of amendments to move in the committee stage of the Bill. We also have a major second reading amendment which reads:
the Senate declines to give this bill a second reading as the Senate is of the opinion that the bill:
(a) imposes excessive and unjustified prohibitions and restrictions on the collection and use of personal financial information;

(b) fails to provide that credit reference agencies be able to give commercial organisations reasonable access to appropriate financial information they have collected provided that the information is reasonably required by a commercial organisation to assist it in making commercial decisions;
(c) will place obstacles in the way of the detection of fraud-
that is particularly important; it has been raised several times by the major insurance industry associations-
add to the cost of insurance, goods and services, increase interests rates and impose additional costs and inefficiencies on business, its customers and the community;

(d) falls short of the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988, particularly those Principles designed to ensure that individuals are made aware that information concerning them has been disclosed;
(e) will have many unintended consequences to the detriment of consumers, credit providers, credit reference agencies and the community as a whole; and
(f) has been introduced without adequate consultation.

The amendments that the Opposition will be moving in the committee stage of this debate are intended to include publicly available information in the provisions of the Act and to eliminate the split between consumer and commercial credit information-a totally artificial and impracticable split, which is not possible to be compiled with according to the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd. Therefore, the CRAA will be permanently in a state of illegality in its operations and will face at least potentially huge financial penalties. Our amendments will also allow general insurers and real estate agents access to credit information files and will ensure that such access is regulated. Our amendments will broaden the definition of credit provider to allow genuine trading organisations to have access to credit information files. Our amendments will remove the Commissioner's power to determine that an organisation that operates commercially as a credit provider is not a credit provider for the purposes of the Act. We will also correct the many anomalies and contradictions presently found in the Bill.

I hope very much, on behalf of industry, commerce and business and this country, and also the millions of Australian consumers who will be adversely affected by the Bill as presently drafted, that the Government will take the committee stage debate very seriously and will look at the Opposition's amendments very carefully. They have been very carefully drafted and they are in the interests of all concerned. This Bill is fundamentally flawed; it cannot be allowed to proceed unamended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Bolkus has attempted to redeem himself and present an amendment Bill which offers some constructive suggestions to guard the privacy of consumers and their credit records, I am sure that my fellow senators will agree with me when I declare that the Privacy Amendment Bill in its present form is a mess. It is a waste of time, money and resources for the Senate to be debating the Privacy Amendment Bill, replete with amendments to the amendment Bill. If this Bill was not in a satisfactory form when it was first introduced and Senator Bolkus wanted to make alterations, he should have withdrawn the Bill so that it could have been redrafted. Better still, he should have consulted the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd and its members before drafting the Bill in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been an outcry from a majority of the business sector to the Privacy Amendment Bill as originally proposed, and rightly so. It has achieved very little of what it set out to accomplish, neither improving privacy protection for individuals in relation to their consumer credit records, nor clarifying the rules with regard to access to the consumer credit reporting system. This being the case, I join with my fellow coalition senators in requesting that the proposed legislation be withdrawn and that the Government sort out what it wants in the area of privacy and introduce into the chamber one Bill which would cover the matters that it wishes to cover and which the chamber can then debate. In its present form of a 19-page Bill to amend the Privacy Act 1988-with a further nine-page document containing 41 amendments including one new definition, three altered definitions, 20 deletions and replacements, 16 new insertions and one deletion-the Bill is not in a state suitable for debate in this chamber. The procedures of the Senate are such that constructive debate is not possible when a Bill has such a large number of amendments. Thus I reiterate the call of my colleague Senator Hill that the Bill be withdrawn, redrafted and then presented to the Senate for debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has claimed that the Privacy Amendment Bill protects consumers. The Government has claimed that the Privacy Amendment Bill is a landmark for consumer protection. The Government has claimed that it is written in plain, easy to read language. The fact is, of course, that it is becoming more and more complicated every time the Government moves to try to patch up this rather faulty piece of legislation. The Bill was long awaited and we have consulted widely about the implications for business and individuals. There are undoubtedly serious problems and serious defects. It prohibits many legitimate uses of credit checks by such people as real estate agents, mortgage underwriters, businesses selling good in terms or credit, insurance companies and companies renting out or leasing goods or equipment. The absurdity of preventing business such as these from having access to credit information is patent. Even the Government ought to be able to see this if it were not so blinded by its ideology. The Bill is totally and commercially unrealistic and restrictive. That is the last sort of legislation we need in this economy at this time. In its present form it would not so much protect consumers--
—This Government is totally anti-small business.

—It is totally anti-small business. It not so much fails to protect consumers; it actually disadvantages them. If credit providers are unable to make an objective decision about creditworthiness, they may err on the side of caution. They may refuse credit or other facilities. This could occur with, say, a real estate agent and a prospective tenant. This could occur and no doubt will occur. Credit checking is an essential feature of many commercial activities and the Government's legislation, and the Government itself, has totally failed to recognise this. The Credit Reporting Forum has been formed by a number of organisations which need to use credit referencing, and they have expressed their strong opposition to the Bill in its present form. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate a list of the organisations which are members of the Credit Reporting Forum in order to save time reading them into Hansard.
—The normal courtesies have not been observed as far as I know.
—I am happy to read them in, Minister.
