TALK.START.PARA: —With this Bill, business costs will escalate-and we all know who pays for the increased costs of business. Insurance premiums and interest rates will rise. There will be overcommitment by some debtors and borrowers. Many socially disadvantaged people will be hurt. Businesses will be forced to make subjective judgments instead of relying on reasonable, reliable information supplied by the Credit Reference Association of Australia, which presently does about 98 per cent of credit reference reporting on individuals. Under this Bill credit providers cannot pass on information of actual defaults to other credit providers without debtors' consent. It is ridiculous when a credit provider of a business loan is not entitled to take account of the creditworthiness of the applicant in relation to personal credit and vice versa. The absurdity of that belies description, and I hope that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) will attempt to give some explanation of the reason for it when he responds at the end of the debate at this second reading stage.

SPEECH.PARA: When a person whose business has failed and who owes creditors applies for a personal loan, the lending institution will not be able to obtain information pertaining to the business debts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lunacy!

—It is lunacy. The coalition has expressed its clear opposition to this very biased legislation, which has raised very legitimate concerns in the business community. Earlier I mentioned real estate agents. I shall not go through the letters that I have received of the hardships that are perceived in that area for landlords and tenants, very particularly, because they will be the ones who will actually suffer. I and others have received letters from the Real Estate Institute of Australia which make it very clear that that organisation is not in the least reassured by the Minister's claims that the legislation will affect only a very small number of real estate agents. The Institute rejects the Minister's assertion that credit reporting facilities are used by only a few agents. One wonders where on earth he got that astounding piece of information from.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter from the Institute states that real estate agents have been accessing credit reporting files for over 18 years and that in the first 11 months of the 1988-89 financial year they did so over 100,000 times. The Real Estate Institute estimates that over 1.5 million inquiries have been made on behalf of property owners since the late 1960s, mostly in capital cities. The Minister states that consumer credit records do not contain tenancy information. The Institute refutes this. Real estate agents making a credit inquiry look for a history of non-payment of rent and clear-outs by tenants-those people who just take off and leave without paying their rent. They also look for non-payment of other debts. There is no doubt that there is a close correlation between non-payment of items purchased on credit, running out on paying Telecom Australia accounts and non-payment of rent. Anybody who has had any experience knows that. The Real Estate Institute believes that the Bill, if passed, would result in increasing rental defaults and an increasing incidence of fraud when dishonest tenants learn that they can move from one property to another without any details of non-payment being recorded on the file.

The Institute is concerned about privacy, but it is also concerned about the rights of property owners-something that the Government rejects totally. The Institute is concerned about the rights of honest tenants who may miss out on getting a house or flat because their creditworthiness cannot be checked. Tenants will, as a consequence, face increased rents and higher bonds as property owners seek to hedge against prospective defaults. This will greatly disadvantage low income earners, most of whom are forced into rental accommodation.

The Minister has brought in some 40 or so amendments to this Bill, which gives some indication of how flawed it was in the first instance; but these amendments have done nothing to change the situation. Real estate agents, insurance companies and companies which rent or lease goods or equipment are still excluded from using credit referencing facilities. The amendment to reduce from 90 days to 60 days the period which must elapse before a creditor can list a debtor as a credit risk is no concession. It merely highlights the absurdity of the 90-day provision in the first place. It ignores the fact that by the time 60 days has passed a defaulter may well have chalked up a series of other transactions and defaults. Creditors need to be able to act much more quickly for the protection of other credit providers and, significantly-this seems to have escaped the Minister's attention-for the benefit of the defaulter himself or herself. Allowing people to compound their credit defaults does them no favour at all, yet the Government seems to be intent on allowing this to happen.

Many of the other defects in the Bill are not addressed by the latest bunch of changes that the Minister has managed to cobble together. The legislation demonstrates a complete lack of understanding of commercial realities and, on the other side of the equation, is defective in respect of the protection which it is supposed to provide for consumers. If the Bill is passed, it will cause a great deal of hardship to many of those it was intended to protect. The Bill will cause many it was intended to protect to have to pay much higher rates for the things that they are getting than they would otherwise have done. We will be opposing the Bill. We are moving a second reading amendment to the Bill, which I shall not read out again but which I commend to the Senate, which I hope honourable senators will support when voting upon it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Privacy Amendment Bill is a very special Bill because it is easily the most stupid Bill that has been introduced since I became a member of this Parliament-and I have seen more doozeys put up at various times by various Ministers opposite. Clearly, it is to be the Bill by which Senator Bolkus will be remembered for his time in the Parliament, because it is absolutely the greatest load of philosophical garbage that we have had since I have been a member of the Senate. So all I would say is-and I regret that Senator Bolkus is not present in the chamber-good luck to Senator Bolkus; he must wear it. I will not speak for long, and I will deal with only two items. As other honourable senators have covered many of the other areas of the Bill, I will not say too much about them. As I have had a particular connection with both the insurance and property areas, both before and since I became a senator, I wish to concentrate on these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that I have ever had so many letters, calls, phone calls, lettergrams, deputations and petitions on any other issue. In fact, I have received between 3,000 and 4,000 petitions, irrespective of what other senators have received. Strangely enough, I have not had one request from anybody to support the Bill-not one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither have I.
—Is that not extraordinary?
—I haven't had one.
—They would all fit in a telephone booth.

—Senator Reid, Senator Teague and Senator Stone also have not received such a request. Who is this legislation supposed to support and why do they not come out and say that they want support? The Government talks about privacy, but this is the disreputable Government that wanted to have us all numbered. It wanted us to have an Australia card, a pharmacy card and a Bill of Rights, and now it talks about privacy. What absolute bunkum! This is the Government that wants no-one to have the right to select their own health insurance, superannuation and other things like that. It is a miserable stunt and it can only protect crooks at the expense of honest people. I do not know why this Government wants to bestow special rights on crooks. That is the first question that I ask the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to answer in due course. Why should honest people be lumbered by the misdeeds of those that this Government seems dedicated to support?

SPEECH.PARA: I start with the matter of insurance. I guess both Senator Bolkus and Senator Cook could readily tell us the figure that is placed on insurance fraud per year, mainly on arson, third party and vehicle theft. As they know, it is millions and millions of dollars. In fact, in Australia arson alone is listed as costing $1,000m per year. Who pays? It is not the crooks that pay; it is the honest people that pay. All sorts of inquiries, seminars and committees have been set up to deal with arson, and they have done a great job. I have one of the reports here, Arson: Action not Words. I recommend to the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is present, and the Minister for Consumer Affairs, whose crummy legislation we are dealing with, that they look at something like that to get a better understanding of the matter. Why do we want to tear up all the good work that has been done by introducing a stupid Bill like this?

I hope that Senator Bolkus found the masses of documented cases of insurance fraud amusing or at least interesting. I wonder whether he saw a recent public affairs television program on the subject which would have given him a bit of background to the matter. I am not sure whether he believes it is funny, clever, or just business, or whether he is one of those people who brushes it off and says, `Oh, well, it doesn't matter; it's all covered by insurance'. Just to cover fraud, every insured person in Australia is currently paying for their insurance twice as high a premium as they otherwise might. They pay twice as much as they should do just to cover fraud. It is not only the actual amount of insurance loss that we are talking about; think of the lawyers, the police, the fire services, the loss assessors, the various committees, the law reformers, the courts and the insurance clerks that are part of the cost of fraud.

The privacy of crooks involved in insurance fraud is given paramount status by Senator Bolkus and his Government. Why? Does it extend to all crooks or is it selective? Do we also look after the people who pinch milk money or crack the cases in telephone boxes? If not, why not? Is it not the job of this Government, or any government, to do all that is possible to protect the interests of the honest people? Why is the effort to protect the privacy of the crooks at the expense of the honest people?

I have spent years involved with people concerned about insurance fraud. One secure way of combating it is through adequate sophisticated record keeping and checking. Even Senator Bolkus, maybe even Senator Cook, would concede that that is the case. Insurance fraud, as Senator Bolkus well knows, is commonly a repetitive crime. Once people do it, they do it over and over again. Difficult economic times cause an increase in the crime, and we are facing very difficult economic times. I say categorically that we are facing a period of increased insurance fraud unless we do something more about making the system work.

Recourse to central records can allow us to catch up with many of the crooks involved in insurance fraud-if Senator Bolkus and his colleagues want to catch up with them. With all the imagination that I can muster, I cannot imagine whose crazy idea this legislation could be or why any Minister of this Government should be so stupid as to go along with it. With all the rising costs, how has the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA) been able to cut compulsory third party premiums two years in a row? It is not because there have been fewer accidents or less serious ones; it is totally due to the organisation using better checking mechanisms and catching more crooks.

The insurance information service speaks for itself. It has worked well and it is working well, and that is what the Government is about to stop. What a maniacal action this is. The NRMA's action has been proved to be successful; because of that we are going to wipe it out. Every crook in Australia will drink to Senator Cook and Senator Bolkus on the night this appalling travesty of legislation is passed into law, should that ever happen-and God spare us. I really despair that we could be faced with such an awful law.

What about the people involved in house rentals? I wonder who convinced this Government that the crooks who do not pay the rent, who tear the place to pieces and then quit or have to be evicted, deserve more consideration than those tenants who look after their house and pay the rent, or, if it comes to that, than the owners of the house itself. I wonder whether Senator Bolkus has ever owned a rental property that provides a home to somebody who otherwise may not have had one. If so, I wonder whether he has had the sorts of problems I am talking about of non-payment of rent, considerable damage, eviction problems and things like that. I wonder whether he has found how difficult it is to evict such people from a house in the first place, probably with no chance of ever recovering the loss of rent. These days when one starts to look at 90 days rent for a unit or a house that is worth, say, $150 a week, one is up for $2,000 before one knows where one is. That is before one tries to get the cost of recovery and before one then has to go back, try to restore the damage and look for another tenant.

I do not know whether Senator Bolkus has ever been in that sort of position, but if he has not I can tell him that it is not much fun. I do not know whether, as a result of not being able to tell people about the credit or standing of his tenants, he would be happy if one of those tenants moved into a house of, say, a friend of his and repeated the dose, maybe for the tenth time, as he has done elsewhere. Why should people who cannot behave in a social way be protected by this Government? If those things happen simply because people are unable to get recourse to records that exist, it is too jolly bad.

Besides the individual loss, tenants are going to find it much more difficult to get housing. People will be less inclined to own rental housing; the rents will have to increase. I am pleased to see Senator Bolkus enter the chamber because he might need to know some of these things before he makes decisions on them. Agents and owners will have to be more selective. Bonds will have to be much higher. Is that what this legislation is all about? Are we trying to provide less accommodation at higher rates with greater bonds as a means of solving a problem? Is that what we are trying to do? We will be able to put every one of these results fairly and squarely at the feet of Senator Bolkus. Is this the best that this disintegrating Government can do? Is this why we have been kept in Canberra until Christmas? Is this the Government's demonstration of the sorts of priorities that it is putting before the people preparatory to going to an election? The cost of this legislation to the public will be huge. It is absolutely ridiculous. If there is any sanity amongst those opposite, they should scrap the Bill now. In the meantime I support the Opposition amendment and I object strongly to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989. Having heard some of the recent contributions from honourable senators it is worth having a look at the actual provisions of this Bill. An outline of what the Bill is designed to do includes the following functions it is designed to provide:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . regulation of the practices of credit reporting agencies and credit providers in relation to personal credit information;

provide for the development of a Code of Conduct for the collection and handling of personal credit information by the Privacy Commissioner in consultation with the credit industry, government, consumer and privacy groups and other relevant bodies;
provide individuals with an enforceable right of access to, correction of, their personal credit records;
limit the types of information which a credit reporting agency may hold;

provide that credit providers cannot disclose personal credit information about individuals without the express agreement of those individuals unless such a disclosure is necessary to prevent fraudulent practices by individuals to obtain credit . . .

And the list goes on. Since this Bill was introduced specifically within a timeframe to allow for comments and amendment, the Australian Democrats, as usual, have engaged in an intensive range of consultations with all relevant industry groups. The concerns which were raised during these discussions pointed to an obvious need to improve the Bill, which was brought before the Parliament in time to do that. A number of amendments are proposed to the Bill that is in front of us, which this chamber hopefully will get around to passing. The Australian Democrats see themselves as playing an important role in this exercise. This has provided a useful example of that particular role. Having determined where problems existed, and being guided by our consultations with a whole range of groups, I have consulted with the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) several times and we are very pleased to see that he has acceded to the matters we raised as per the Government's schedule of amendments. We have that enormous schedule of amendments before us. It is testimony to the work that has gone on since this Bill was first introduced.

I will take the opportunity to remind this chamber that the Democrats are the only party to remain consistent on the issue of privacy protection. A vote earlier today on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill demonstrated that. Last year during the debate on the Privacy Bill we sought to strengthen the legislation and apply that Bill to the private sector. The major parties-the Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties-joined together to defeat the improvements which we had put up by way of amendment, including the ludicrous situation of the Opposition voting against its own amendments when the Bill came back from the House. I remind honourable senators of Senator Haines's words when we were debating the Privacy Bill last year, which is now embodied in the Acts which we are currently amending. On 8 December last year, Senator Haines stated:

Privacy legislation is something that the Democrats have been seeking since my colleagues came into this chamber in 1978. Australia has never had privacy legislation, unlike a number of other countries, and it sorely needs it.
One of the areas that we all need protection from is the release of information about us from the private sector.
we introduced privacy legislation of our own. We have always argued that the private sector should be covered by privacy legislation.

Of course we can see why the heckling is coming from the Opposition benches at the moment. The Bill before us addresses part of the problem by extending privacy protection to at least one sector of private industry; that is, the credit reporting sector. The Opposition's lack of commitment to privacy protection is evident here tonight as is its double standards. It seems that government departments must be obliged to comply with privacy obligations, but the private sector can be trusted to regulate itself. According to the Opposition, the credit reporting segment of the private sector is perfectly able, and we should trust it, to look after itself. The Government has had to wait for the threat of positive reporting and massive, unregulated, centralised databanks, before acting. Honourable senators should remember that the threat, the spectre of positive reporting, has actually finally motivated the Government to bring some legislation on privacy in the private sector before the Parliament. I was present at a conference in Sydney convened by the New South Wales Privacy Committee. Many groups which have subsequently strongly opposed this legislation said, `Yes, we believe in privacy legislation. No, we do not want positive reporting', and have done everything they can since to destroy this legislation.

This legislation is vitally important and long overdue. It behoves us to make it as workable and effective a piece of legislation as we can in the interests of both consumers and industry. The need for privacy protection should not need to be recounted here, but I will mention a few, significant aspects of that particular need. Apart from a range of international human rights instruments which point to the importance of privacy as a human right, Australia has lagged well behind the United States, for example, that great bastion of free enterprise, in developing protections under the law for privacy. The situation has been compounded in recent years by rapid developments in information technology and the enormous potential for the compilation of centrally held, but easily accessible, personal and other information on people. In fact, `potential' is probably the wrong word because, indeed, the actuality of massive computer data is with us already. That fact became apparent in the Australia Card debate, as it has in the context of the Privacy Amendment Bill. It is interesting to note the position of the Opposition on two pieces of legislation-the Australia Card Bill and the Privacy Amendment Bill, which we are debating. As I said, this points to the fact that the Australian Democrats is the only party to remain consistent on this issue. In the particular area addressed by this Bill, credit reporting-it does address only one area of the private sector; however, one has to begin somewhere and, as I said, the spectre of positive reporting is an obvious motivation of the Government which, of course, we welcome-it has become quite clear that the existence of these millions of files was unknown to most of the people who were subject of them. They were not aware, except in the vaguest imaginable way, that a consumer credit reporting industry operates nationwide-I am not talking about people in the business and industry sector, but ordinary consumers-or that the use of information about their creditworthiness had a direct and significant impact on their financial affairs.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Speakers from the Opposition have been listened to in reasonable silence. I ask honourable senators to extend the same courtesy to Senator Powell.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will just digress momentarily and make the point that this whole debate has actually been extremely useful in drawing people's attention to the existence of these files and the fact that the consumers actually have rights of access and correction in relation to them. As is certainly true, at least in the case of the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA), people have always been able to get copies of their files, at a small price in some circumstances. But people can exercise their rights only if they know about them and if they know about the information in relation to which those rights exist. Apart from the rights of individual consumers, privacy legislation is most important in terms of educating the public, record keepers, and those using the files, about the importance of privacy protection. Under the Act passed in 1988 and moving through the legislation the role of the Privacy Commissioner is crucial in the whole process, because he is responsible for the development of the code of conduct in consultation with the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Although we will deal in detail with this Bill in the committee stage, I want to mention a couple of aspects now. I am referring here to areas where sections of industry consider that denial or limitation of access to CRAA files will have serious effects on our economy, among other things. This point has been made in the debate. To illustrate my point I will use real estate agents who have hitherto had access to the files-or at least those who chose to be members of the Credit Reference Association had access. It is worth noting that, as the Bill stands, real estate agents will be excluded, and much has been said already about that. For the information of honourable senators only 655 of Australia's 9,000 real estate agents belong to CRAA-that figure includes those managing commercial properties-and real estate agents' inquiries constitute less than 3 per cent of annual usage.

Property owners and agents will continue to be able to seek information on a prospective tenant's employment details, income, previous tenancy history and require references and then check with the relevant independent third parties. This legislation does not affect those rights at all. They could, of course, seek more information from the prospective tenant, including his or her CRAA report. If they start collecting credit information for the purposes of providing that information to others, they would come within the ambit of this legislation as a credit reporting business and be bound by the obligations of this legislation accordingly. If we look at the matter logically and rationally, which I fear has not happened in this debate so far, we note that comprehensive tenancy legislation exists in all States. Landlords are well protected under it. This includes the payment of rent in advance, bonds, enforceable rights of entry and inspection, statutory rights of eviction, a lien against the property and the protection of courts and tribunals.

The experience of the New South Wales Privacy Committee is that credit checks by real estate agents are often a pretext for excluding certain tenants-those very tenants over whom many crocodile tears have been shed in this debate and in some of the representations during the progress of this legislation. In fact, tenants' unions are very strongly in favour of this legislation. I noted earlier that we were told that nobody was coming forward in favour of this legislation. Tenants' unions and other such advocates in the community are interested in protection for their clientele; protection which they know can be gained only through this sort of legislation.

The Tenants Union of Victoria, my home State, has surveyed 32 real estate agencies in the inner Melbourne area in order to find out what sort of information the agents require of prospective tenants. It found that, in relation to a tenant's identity, the agents asked a total of 246 questions over 22 categories of information-more than the Department of Social Security and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade together require of applicants for benefits or passports. In comparison to the wealth of information which agents can obtain from a prospective tenant, a credit reference, with its few details, would appear to be of relatively little significance.

I also make reference to other means of control in this area and their adequacy or otherwise. First, there is State legislation. Three States-Queensland, South Australia and Victoria-have credit reporting legislation of an essentially similar nature to this. Apart from the fact that the legislation does not cover the whole nation, it was drafted in the 1970s and, therefore, is seriously deficient in particular with respect to the sophisticated information technology of the late 1980s and, of course, the coming decade, the 1990s. The CRAA operates under a self-regulatory code of conduct and it has been argued that this is an adequate basis for control. While it is admirable that the CRAA instituted the code, I certainly differ from those who assert that it is adequate. It deals only with disputed accuracy records and not other aspects which might give cause for concern; for example, splitting the files of married couples. The categories of the information are expressed in terms of those which must not be collected, rather than a definitive list of those which may be collected, thereby leaving lots of room for expansion. Sanctions and remedies are very limited indeed and it seems to the Democrats that a more formal, clear, nationally applied set of obligations and guidelines is warranted.

I note in passing that some opponents of this Bill seem to have a very strange idea of respect for privacy. I have here one of the many faxed letters forwarded to our office as part of the lobbying campaign against this Bill, and I will say more about that later. This letter gives an example in support of its claim and it attaches a CRAA file. The letter carefully notes:
The member's name has been deleted to respect his privacy.

For obvious reasons, I will not table this letter. However, the file still contains-this is clearly readable-the person's address, employer, previous address, name of brother-in-law, the name of a cross reference, car registration number and other identifying information. It is quite astounding that the person who wrote this letter to our office believes that adequate protection has been given to this person's privacy just by deleting the name and that, therefore, we do not need the legislation. This letter was sent to our office as a demonstration that we do not need this legislation. This is perhaps one of the strongest pieces of evidence that we have that this legislation is necessary, because after the passage of this Bill the sending of such a document will be entirely and utterly illegal in the interests of the privacy of the individual whose file I have in my hand and whose name it would be very easy for me to find out.

I wish now to make a few general points on the subject of lobbying, although given the lateness of the hour and the session I can scarcely give it the time that I would like to. I note that one Minister is looking at the question of junk faxes. We would have a pretty massive submission to give to that inquiry. It seems that the people from the private sector who are involved-I see a Government backbencher nodding vigorously in agreement-believe that the people in this Parliament, the back bench of the Government, and the Democrats in particular, make their decisions based on the weight of paper which comes into their offices. One can hardly get into Senator Jenkins's office these days, and the mail from the west has been incredible. That is not the way we make our decisions; we make them on the basis of the substance of the issue.

We have heard misleading claims that the Democrats have done a deal with the Government to gag this legislation. One of this morning's newspapers-and just hold your sides, folks, because really this is the most laughable thing that I have seen for a long time-states that debate on this Bill has been accelerated. If Senator Bolkus were in the chamber right now he would be crying at the thought of that. Mind you, I also have received letters which say that the debate on this Bill has been pushed forward. Pushed forward to 21 December? In the whole of this lobbying campaign it would be interesting to speculate what sorts of briefing papers these people have been given before they have sent their junk faxes to us. In that advertisement in the newspaper this morning, we see that question 5 asks:
What is wrong with the industry sponsored alternatives?

If honourable senators want to look at my diary-if there were time to make a personal explanation I would make one about Senator Stone's earlier interjection `Rubbish' when I said I had consulted widely with the industry-it will show them how widely I and the limited staff available to the Australian Democrats have consulted with individuals and groups on this legislation. Yet in all that time we have not seen one single industry sponsored alternative. So I suppose that the answer to question No. 5, `What is wrong with the industry sponsored alternatives?' is that they do not exist. Every time the industry put to us a series of problems and we went to the Minister, discussed them and went through them, the industry then tossed up yet another set of problems. To date, although we are moving an amendment to quarantine the old files as against new files, which was put to us as the problem which would put the industry out of business, we have not heard from the industry, `Thank you for moving that amendment. Thank you for meeting the ultimate problem'. I am quite sure that we will get some more junk faxes telling us what else is wrong with this legislation.

What worries me more than anything is that bona fide groups in our community have had the wool pulled over their eyes by the lobbyists in this exercise. In particular, the credit cooperatives which are writing to us and faxing letters to us are desperate about this legislation, believing that they are not included. They are included. We have negotiated with the Minister over this period and we now have an expanded definition of credit providers and credit reporting agencies. As a result, those credit cooperatives are included in the legislation. They have wasted their money and their time-and presumably their members' money-in an enormous lobbying campaign which is a fraud. This lobby group has misled people and, obviously, members of Opposition have swallowed it hook, line and sinker.

Sadly, all of this has occurred despite what in many respects has really been a constructive consultative process. As I said, I have spent a lot of time on this matter. I have also spent a lot of time with the Minister discussing this. The Bill before us tonight shows how much the original Bill which was put down for discussion and amendment has been changed. A much improved Bill is before us tonight, reflected in these Government amendments, many of which are amendments which we pressed for following submissions and representations from the industry. As I said, one outstanding matter that concerned us-it was pressed upon us by the people met with-was the inability of the CRAA to comply with the legislation with respect to its existing files. I will move an amendment to allow those files to be quarantined.

I conclude by reiterating the Democrats' commitment to privacy protection and the need to balance that with commercial reality. In supporting this Bill in its form, I remind the chamber that this country's foremost privacy body, the New South Wales Privacy Committee, supports the Bill. Privacy, particularly in the private sector, has remained unprotected for too long. We welcome this long overdue legislation. We regret the delay which has meant that it is the second last Bill on the list for consideration this year. We regret the Opposition's obvious filibuster. On the basis of both of those factors we question the commitment to privacy, particularly of the Opposition, and wish that the Government's commitment to privacy had been sufficiently strong enough for us to have taken these sorts of measures when we passed the original Bill in 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express my strong support for the second reading amendment that the Opposition has moved. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate declines to give this Bill a second reading as the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill:
(a) imposes excessive and unjustified prohibitions and restrictions on the collection and use of personal financial information;

(b) fails to provide that credit reference agencies should be able to give commercial organisations reasonable access to financial information they have collected provided the information is reasonably required by the commercial organisation to assist it in making commercial decisions;

(c) will place obstacles in the way of detection of fraud, add to the cost of insurance, goods and services, increase interest rates and impose additional costs and inefficiencies on business, its customers and the community;

(d) falls short of the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988, particularly those Principles designed to ensure that individuals are made aware that information concerning them has been disclosed;
(e) will have many unintended consequences to the detriment of consumers, credit providers, credit reference agencies and the community as a whole; and
(f) has been introduced without adequate consultation.

The fact that the Bill has been introduced without adequate consultation is self-evident from the volume of amendments proposed by the Government, let alone by the Opposition. If this Bill had been even half thought out it would have been in a coherent form, even if offensive. It would have been in a coherent form before it came into this chamber. As for Senator Powell's suggestion that it has not been rushed ahead, for heaven's sake, if it had not been rushed ahead, why was it brought in needing massive amendment? Why was it not drafted properly the first time? That is the simple, uncomplicated answer. The Bill has been brought into this chamber in a state of total disarray by an incompetent government being pushed into a stupid Bill by a Minister who is obsessive about this subject. Quite frankly, it is fascinating to see the intellectual gymnastics going on from the other side, and of course from the Australian Democrats, about questions of principle. Let us recognise that it was the Opposition which, in a very clear and determined way, established a real concern for privacy in this place at the time of the tax file number debate. It was the Opposition that insisted on and corrected the Government's incompetent legislation in that area. There is no doubt that in the Opposition ranks there is clear concern about the need for privacy and for appropriate legislation to protect people. We have to come to a coherent, intelligent balance between the two pressures that are evident here-a pressure for a need for privacy and a real need to protect Australians from the fraud of dishonest people who are adding multi-billions of dollars to the bills having to be paid by ordinary, decent Australians.

It intrigues me that at the time of the tax file number debate, the Australian Labor Party said exactly that about the need for a tax file number and the Australia Card. Now, magically, it says, `No, we can't be concerned'. Maybe it cannot be concerned about it because it is the private sector which is losing a lot of money. After all, apparently this Government does not care much about the private sector and what happens in the private sector. What we were saying, and we say it now, is that we must seek a proper balance between these conflicting pressures-that is, the pressure for proper privacy and the pressure for proper protection of honest people trying to do honest business in Australia. On almost all grounds this Bill fails dismally to come anywhere near meeting any kind of coherent balance.

There are a whole range of matters I want to raise. I want to deal firstly with a couple of the points in the letter from the Australian Finance Conference which Senator Powell did not deal with. She wanted to know what was wrong with the industry sponsored alternatives and so on, but she did not answer this question: Why have several Labor and coalition State governments, plus over 50 national and State industry and professional bodies, as well as the government departments responsible, urged that this Bill be withdrawn? It would be nice to have an answer to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has no answers.

—As Senator Stone says, it has no answer. Why did Senator Bolkus advise the Senate in June that the cost to the community of this legislation would be minimal when in May his own proponents of the Bill told him that consumers would pay higher charges and higher interest rates because of it? I will go into just how expensive it will be and how much additional cost will be imposed on people as a result of it. Why does Senator Bolkus continue to disparage the only economic impact study of the Bill, when even after his many changes independent consultants have confirmed that a conservative estimate of its cost to the community is in order of between $1,250m and $2,400m a year? Other questions include: why was the original Bill rushed into the Senate in the last days of the autumn session and why is debate on the latest version, with 40-plus amendments already, being pushed through in the last days of the Budget session? Is it in the hope that the Opposition will lie down and let it rush through without proper surveillance, without proper debate of the--
—Do you want to go home for Christmas?
—Yes; the Government is using the blackmail that if we want to go home for Christmas we do not debate this Bill and we do not deal with the 40-odd-
—Let it go through.

—We let it go through and we do not deal in any sort of detail with the 40-odd amendments that we are trying to put into the Bill to make it less worse, let alone the Government's amendments. I stress that it is not nonsense to suggest that if this Bill goes through there will be a massive increase in costs to people, in particular the insurance industry, because of the increased capacity for fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: The Insurance Council of Australia represents the interests of 92 private sector general insurance companies which together account for approximately $5 billion in premium income. Of this amount $4 billion is paid out in claims, and expenses total approximately $1.5 billion. Significantly, it is estimated that claims which are the result of fraudulent activity amount to around $1.5 billion each year. The industry's responsibility, therefore, on behalf of the honest majority of policyholders, is to do as much as is possible to combat this problem. As I said, the conflict between what is required in terms of protecting privacy and the massive and real cost to the people of Australia of having this kind of legislation has to be resolved.
The Illawarra Credit Union Ltd from my area has written a letter to me which states:

This Bill will severely restrict our ability to assess members capacity to service a loan debt, and will invariably impact on the lower socio-economic members of society, the same group that this Bill purports to protect.
Your urgent assistance is sought to defer the Bill to enable further investigation which can result in legislation which supports the privacy of the individual balanced with commercial reality.

That is not from a terrible, reactionary, multinational seeking to assault poor, innocent Australians. That is from the Illawarra Credit Union which is involved with people in the lower income groups and which is seeking to protect their interests against this marauding, ludicrous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The kind of people you normally hear the Government bleating about-not to mention the Democrats.

—Exactly. The people who will suffer as a result of this Bill, if it goes through, are the very people in what was the heartland of the Labor movement, who are-regrettably, I might say-represented entirely by Labor members in the other place and, as a result, get a lousy deal.
—They have lost touch with their roots.
—As Senator Stone said, they are out of touch with their roots. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989OVERSEAS STUDENTS (INSTALMENT PAYMENTS) CHARGE BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Walsh)-by leave-agreed to:
That the Order of the Senate of 6 September 1989, relating to the introduction of Bills into the Senate after 24 November 1989, not apply to these Bills.
Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act 1979 to enable payment of the Overseas Students Charge to be made in two equal instalments each year from the beginning of the 1990 academic year. The charge is payable by overseas students enrolled in Australian education institutions under the subsidised program to which the Act relates.

The Overseas Students Charge was expected to raise $51.449m in 1989-90 based on the full payment being made by 1 May 1990. With the second of the two instalments due for payment after 30 June 1990, revenue in 1989-90 is expected to be reduced by up to half.
In addition, administrative costs associated with the collection of the charge may increase by up to $30,000.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS (INSTALMENT PAYMENTS) CHARGE BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for an instalment payment fee which will be incurred where the Overseas Students Charge is paid by two instalments each year from the beginning of the 1990 academic year, as provided for in the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1989 which is being considered cognately with this Bill. The Charge is payable by overseas students enrolled in Australian education institutions under the subsidised program to which the Bill relates.

The amount of the instalment payment which will be payable at the time of the second instalment of the Charge will be calculated pro rata on the basis of the three year indicator Commonwealth Bond rate for the period between the two instalment payments. The instalment payment will cover the public debt interest revenue forgone as a result of the introduction of arrangements for the Charge to be paid by instalments.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989OVERSEAS STUDENTS (INSTALMENT PAYMENTS) CHARGE BILL 1989OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1989, the Overseas Students (Instalment Payments) Charge Bill 1989 and the Bill listed as Government Business Order of the Day No. 7 (Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1989), may be taken together for their remaining stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us, taken together for their remaining stages, the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill and two related Bills. On 13 December-as appears on page 4415 of the Senate Hansard-at the committee stage we reported progress on a Bill which had passed the second reading stage, that is, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. This Bill seeks to raise the overseas student charge by about 10 per cent for each category. We determined that we would come back to the committee stage of that Bill only when we had before us legislation that would fulfil the promise made by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, in December 1988, when the education package was being debated in the Senate, that from 1 January 1990 there would be legislative provision for the overseas student charge to be paid in two instalments.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have before us, transmitted from the House of Representatives a few minutes ago, the two Bills which will enable the overseas student charge to be paid in two instalments. The first Bill, the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill, essentially provides the framework for the two equal instalments to commence from the beginning of next month. The actual payment dates are to be specified in a determination made by the Minister. The Bill provides that in the event that the first instalment is not paid on the due date, the right to pay by instalments would be forfeited. The Bill also makes provision for exemptions and for the granting of visas and temporary entry permits to overseas students at appropriate times. There has been this need to change the singular to the plural in the existing Act to follow through repercussions with regard to visas and temporary entry permits because there will be two payments rather than just the one, as has been the case for the last seven or eight years in which we have had an overseas student charge.

The second Bill, the Overseas Students (Instalment Payments) Charge Bill, imposes a charge which amounts to interest accrued on the half of the annual fee for the period for which the second instalment is now deferred. The formula set out in the second Bill relates to the days that have elapsed between the two instalment payments, and the interest applied is the three-year average Commonwealth bond rate as of February of the year of the charge. This is a reasonable provision, as is the provision that the ability to pay by two instalments is available only if the first instalment is paid on time.

These Bills bring the overseas student charge into line with the contribution provisions in other legislation for all other students. Full fee students already have the ability to pay the charge for their studies in at least two instalments a year. In the case of the higher education contribution scheme (HECS)-the graduate tax-students have the ability to make, as a minimum, the two instalments a year, one each six-monthly semester. With the election in a few months time of a coalition government and the abolition of HECS, the tuition fee that we will introduce at two-thirds the rate of HECS will be able to be paid direct to the institutions on a semester basis-that is, in two instalments. Therefore, this legislation brings the overseas student charge into a two-instalment approach, parallel with that which applies, or will apply, for all other students.

I have only one other comment to make, and that is that the passing of this legislation enabling a second instalment to be made lawfully in the latter part of the 1990 calendar year means that some $51m of moneys that are in the present Budget, calculated to be received by Commonwealth revenue, will be deferred until the next financial year and, to that extent, will lower the surplus in this financial year by $51m. That is the estimate set out in the documents provided by the Government in association with the Bill.

In conclusion, I refer to my speech at the second reading stage of the education package on 12 December where in Hansard, at pages 4364 and 4365, I set out the letters from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, to me on 7 December and 12 December. The letters are self-explanatory and are a foundation for the legislation before us.

The Opposition supports the two new Bills, and the Senate should acknowledge that had the Australian Democrats not supported the Opposition in making an issue of this matter 12 months ago, and had the Democrats not indicated their support for the Opposition's proposal that there be in place a two-instalment approach, to be fair and to be equitable to overseas students facing this charge, assuredly we would not have had the response that is set out in the Minister's letters of 7 and 12 December to me and which I have incorporated in Hansard on the pages that I have indicated. It is, therefore, at the Opposition's request that the Government has made this legislation available and that we have it before us now, having been passed by the House of Representatives. The Opposition supports the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill which was promised by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) the last time we debated-I think it was on 12 and 13 December-the education package of six or seven Bills. This issue, as Senator Teague has said, goes back quite some time. In fact, the original proposition was an amendment moved by me to enable students to pay their fees by four instalments in a year-indeed, not in the manner set out here but in a simplified way. The Government, however, has chosen a more complicated method. That is the Government's right if it wishes to do that, but I think there are far simpler ways.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some good reasons as to why we would seek to amend the Bill, not least of which, of course, is that it would assist students who are paying a fairly significant fee and their families to be able to spread the cost over a whole year rather than pay it at one point in the year; but, in addition, the massive embarrassment to Australia that has been occasioned by deporting overseas students, hopefully, would be lessened by this exercise. If it is not possible for a student to meet the first of the payments, obviously it will not be possible to meet the second, and hence there is a much larger timeframe in which students can be convinced that the best that they can do is quit the course and return home. Deportation is an exercise that overseas students, and certainly the Australian education industry, does not want to see occurring again.

Quite significant problems still exist for overseas students over the payment of fees. In other circumstances, I would move amendments yet again with regard to these items. Since the Opposition has not supported the amendments in the past, I presume it will not support them now. However, I think that they ought to be mentioned again. The Australian-American Education Foundation operates, at least by the terms of its charter, as a result of a 50 : 50 cooperative arrangement between Australia and the United States. The Bicentennial has raised Australia's profile in the eyes of the world, and certainly within the United States, and there is massive competition for the types of scholarships and the like that are available to overseas students.

While the Australian-American Education Foundation has raised in excess of an additional $120,000 from private funds and has done its work well, as a government and as a community we have not kept our part of the bargain by funding that exercise on a 50-50 basis. That is to be deplored. If we are to continue with this exercise, the least we can do is keep our part of the bargain and put in 50 per cent of the cost, as we are pledged to do, considering that the studying is done in Australia and that through the whole period the United States has contributed more than its share.

During 1989, 24 postgraduate scholarships were awarded to developing countries through schemes administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The annual living allowance, which is non-taxable, is just over $10,000. Eight scholarships, which provide for a minimum study period of two years, were awarded under the Commonwealth scholarship and fellowship plan administered by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau. Sixteen scholarships were awarded for the Australian-European awards program, which provides for a one-year postgraduate study course in Australia. The difficulty is that all those scholarships have again been affected by the way we are administering the operations in Australia. We are in fact depriving many of these students from coming to Australia to pursue those courses of study.

One of the things that people do not seem to realise is that in our educational institutions it is principally overseas postgraduate students who comprise the bulk of our tutors and demonstrators for our undergraduate courses. After all, where else are we going to find people who will work odd hours and for a mere pittance at such a high level? The only place where we can get those people is from the ranks of the postgraduate students.

Our engineering and science courses are in a great deal of trouble as a result of our mean-fisted approach to the postgraduate study programs offered overseas. I have raised this in the past. No action has been taken. I believe that it is an indictment on this Government that it has not seen fit to honour the obligations under the Australian-American Education Foundation agreement, or to exempt those students who are undertaking or have a postgraduate scholarship awarded either by an Australian institution or by a Commonwealth authority. It is ludicrous when one considers this exercise. Students believe that they are getting a stipend at a particular level and it is being taken away from them. I hope that these items will be addressed before we discuss these Bills again next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I did not know until about an hour and a half ago that it was proposed that these amendments be considered by the Committee tonight. I thought it was going to be tomorrow. I understand that it has been agreed with the Opposition that the substitute amendments moved in the House of Representatives be accepted. —You can seek to incorporate it.

—I have explanatory notes which have been supplied by the Australian Taxation Office. In summary, they state that the intentions of the Senate amendments have been incorporated in the substitute amendments passed by the House of Representatives but that they are technically more sound and, in particular, more precise. The notes are not formal explanatory memoranda but explanations supplied by the Australian Taxation Office regarding the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendments Bill (No. 2) 1989. I seek leave to incorporate the two documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
SALES TAX LAWS (COMPUTER PROGRAMS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill, as introduced, would have resulted in sales tax continuing to apply to games and educational programs on microchips which are placed inside cartridges that are for use with basic personal computers, or with games consoles such as the Atari Video Computer System and the Nintendo Home Entertainment System. In some cases, however, the same program is also available on floppy disc, and the amendment of the Bill made by the Senate removes this distortion.

Since the passing of the Senate amendment, the Government has received suggestions for improving the amendment and has had time to give it more detailed consideration. The substituted amendment brought forward in the House of Representatives is the result of that.

The new amendment differs from that made by the Senate in a number of significant ways. Firstly, the nature of the programs that qualify for sales tax exemption has been extended to included those marketed as being exclusively for both educational and entertainment use. Secondly, a similar change has been made to the cartridges affected, extending the range of cartridges to those marketed as being exclusively for use with either a personal computer or an acceptable home electronic device.

The third significant change made is to replace the term ``visual display unit'' with the description ``a computer monitor or a television screen''. This will remove any uncertainty as to what is a visual display unit. It is possible that a television screen falls outside the current conception of a visual display unit, although the Government intended that such a screen be included. On the other hand, the term ``visual display unit'' in the Bill could have resulted in any LCO or LED display no matter how small or how limited its display capabilities being classed as a ``visual display unit''-contrary to the Government's intention.

The inclusion test in the Senate amendment could have opened up the exemption sought to be granted to a wider range of devices than the Government intended. A further change will, therefore, ensure that home electronic devices that include a computer monitor or television screen are excluded from the range of acceptable devices. However, personal computers that include a screen will remain acceptable.

Finally, the substituted amendment, in specifying what are unacceptable home electronic devices, includes articles that are a combination of a number of devices and that include one or more of the devices specified. This will reduce the frequency with which regulations might otherwise need to be made to extend the list of specified devices.
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1989

Honourable senators will recall that the object of the first and third amendments of this Bill that were made by the Senate was, first, to make clear that the proposed exemption for certain paper products applies to goods only if all the paper in the goods is wholly recycled paper and, second, to define what is meant by the term ``recycled'' in relation to recycled paper and cardboard. The second amendment made by the Senate was intended to extend the proposed exemption so that the use of recycled fibre, and not just recycled paper, would qualify.

The House of Representatives, in not accepting the second and third amendments made by the Senate, did not disagree with the principles behind those amendments. The amendment the House made to replace those two amendments re-expresses the Senate amendments and, in so doing, and consistent with the definition of ``recycled'' in relation to recycled paper and cardboard accepted by the Senate, extends that definition to fibre.

This new definition specifies that, for the purposes for the proposed exemption, the recycled test will be satisfied only where all the fibre in the cardboard or paper has previously been used, as fibre, in the manufacture of other goods-for example, cotton lint from shirting material and hemp fibre from rope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, people who are being affected by this include many in lower socioeconomic parts of our society who the Bill purports to protect but who are, in fact, inevitably suffering because of the severe restriction on bodies such as credit unions in working class areas such as mine, the Illawarra region. By restricting their ability to assess members' capacity to service a loan debt this will affect those people who are in the heartland, as I said, of the Australian Labor Party. It makes one wonder who is protecting whom from what in this legislation. That is the essence of this matter. It does seem that there is a greater determination to protect the guilty than there is to protect the community, the innocent. It is a curious trend. It seems to me that we have not yet seen any empirical evidence on the need for this legislation. We have certainly seen none about its effects or its costs-nothing that is coherent, anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Bill facilitates fraud. The costs of fraud in insurance, finance and government is borne by the community, not by companies. That cost, of course, has risen enormously in recent times. The community's perception is that fraud is a major problem and that something should be done about it. The Commonwealth's anti-business pro-fraud stance reflected in this and other legislation, such as the Insurance Contracts Act, contrasts starkly with its own tough anti-fraud stance and its own business. That is the intriguing thing. There is a clear, uncomplicated double standard involved on the part of this Government. We have seen how the Commonwealth heavily penalises fraud in government business. The Proceeds of Crime Act, which was enacted at about the same time as the Insurance Contracts Act, displays a much more muscular attitude to fraud, providing that a person who engages in organised fraud, if a natural person, is liable to a fine not exceeding $250,000, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 25 years, or both.

There is no doubt that this Government-and I am not quite certain what its motives are-appears to be much more highly excited about the prospect of protecting itself from fraud than allowing the private sector to protect itself. That is the essential point. It is limiting the capacity of the private sector to protect its customers, the ordinary people of Australia, from the impact of fraud. That is what this legislation is all about. I must say that I am astounded at the sort of bunkum that the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, writes to people in significant positions about this sort of legislation. I have a copy of a letter he wrote on 18 December to NRMA Insurance Ltd in which he says:

However, the Government is not prepared to treat general insurers as credit providers in order to enable them to access credit data. The principle that information should be used in a manner appropriate to the purpose for which it was provided has been central to the Government's deliberations in connection with this Bill.

It is not a central principle to assist the people of Australia by limiting the capacity for fraud. The Government is not concerned about that. Its concern is an esoteric and very expensive principle. As I have said, it has not balanced these two principles of the need for privacy and the need to protect the innocent in this community from the activities of the fraudulent. Senator Bolkus went on:
Information I have received from the Insurance Council of Australia does not indicate that overcommitment is a major cause of insurance fraud.

That is one of the most curious statements that even this Minister could come out with. I would be very grateful if the Minister would release that information to the Senate because I note the very careful wording of that statement. Does the honourable senator mean that he has received information from the Insurance Council of Australia which indicates that overcommitment is not a major cause of insurance fraud? He does not say that. He just does not indicate that it is. I wonder why he used the negative. No doubt because the positive is not so. The fact is that it is part of the accepted wisdom of the insurance industry that financial difficulties of the insured are often found to be the motivation for insurance fraud. That accords with experience of almost every major operator in this industry. It seems to me that the letter from Senator Bolkus to Mr Willing is deliberately misleading. Unless the honourable senator produces the information and advice that he has received from the Insurance Council, then the honourable senator is exposed as playing with words, deliberately seeking to mislead. He then goes on:
ICA figures-
that is, the Insurance Council of Australia figures-
further indicate that only 39 insurance companies out of some 170 licensed insurers in Australia are members of CRAA.

That is a disgraceful statement because it deliberately seeks to mislead this chamber. It certainly seeks to mislead the person to whom it was addressed and who, frankly, refuses to be misled. I could be generous and say that perhaps the Minister simply does not know that these 39 insurance companies include the largest insurers operating in the personal loans market in Australia, where most fraud activity occurs. It would be much more honourable if the Minister were to concede that the 39 operate at the coalface where the problem exists. That kind of nonsensical statement, the implication that it is inconsequential because the figure is only 39 out of 170, is just the sort of cant that we have been hearing throughout this debate from the Government.

As I mentioned earlier, this Government has taken a strong, very muscular view about fraud attacking itself, but the insurance industry is now being blocked in its endeavours to protect not only itself, but also its customers from fraud. In its 1988 brochure analysing fraud, the Munich Reinsurance Group expressed a commonly held view. It has this to say about the development of fraud to epidemic proportions in insurance:
The frequent and favourable argument put forward mainly in non-insurance circles, namely that this development-
that is, the development of fraud-

ought not to worry insurers who have only to raise their premiums accordingly, can now no longer stand unchallenged. Indeed, the concept of risk management, correctly understood, requires that insurers take countermeasures in their own interests. Honest policyholders have a right to demand that their insurers reject unjustified claims for compensation and combat fraud in connection with insurance business.

There is no doubt then that it is necessary, both from the point of view of the insurance industry and in the interests of the individual policyholder, that effective countermeasures be introduced as soon as possible. That is very sound, very sensible and universally accepted as true, but this legislation now before the Parliament moves in exactly the opposite direction. This Bill proposes that insurers be debarred from access to information concerning individuals' financial dealings. It makes substantial changes to the nature of personal information which may be retained, and by whom. Credit reporting agencies will not be permitted to retain records of insurance fraud or default in payment of claims or premiums. After representations, some amendments to the Bill have been made allowing for some information to be entered in a separate central claims register, probably at mind-boggling cost. Most of the problems which the Bill gratuitously creates have not been addressed. It is a matter of conjecture as to whether some of these credit reporting agencies will be able to function effectively under this legislation. I am referring to large insurance companies.

As I mentioned earlier, the Illawarra Credit Union Ltd has written to me. The people who have signed this advertisement, to which Senator Powell referred so disparagingly, are not simply the big retail trading groups, major employers, insurance organisations or the Confederation of Australian Industry. The Australian Association of Cooperatives Ltd is not a big business bandit, which the Government seems to charge as being everyone who has a profit motive. There is also the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies. Are these organisations all big multinationals? Not on your life. The Australian Federation of Credit Unions is the poor man's bank. These are the people being hit by this legislation, the very people that this Government has pretended to represent for so long. There is the small business people's movement-small business. Do honourable senators know how to become a small business under Labor-start off as a big business and it will soon become a small business.

This widespread group of people have all expressed major concerns about this legislation. My concerns at this stage are mainly to do with the effect on the insurance industry. The Commonwealth Government has created further problems for the insurance industry in combating fraud, despite undisputed evidence, much of it from the Commonwealth itself, that the community is paying a heavy price for fraud, and the community expects the Government to do something about it. Fraud is a major problem in all areas of business in which benefits are paid to people on production of proof that an event entitling payment has occurred. There is the same problem in social security as there is in third party insurance; yet the Government is cracking down heavily on social security but will not let the private sector protect itself. If a person can satisfy certain criteria, usually solely by the production of an appropriate document, payment is made. As I said, in its own affairs, the Commonwealth Government zealously provides itself with increasingly powerful solutions to confront fraud. On the other hand in private business the Commonwealth places little value on the eradication of fraud. In legislation such as the Insurance Contracts Act and the Privacy Amendment Bill, the Commonwealth goes way beyond what is required to protect legitimate interests and in the final analysis protects the fraudulent at the cost of the honest consumer.

It is intriguing that this Bill covers what was dealt with over a period of seven years or so by the Australian Law Reform Commission. Senator Bolkus, in his second reading speech, relied on the findings of a public opinion poll conducted by the Commission some time before 1983 as evidence of current public concern about the credit reference bureau and privacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In any case, how well informed was the concern?

—This lack of Government understanding of the genuine concern in the community about the impact and the cost of fraud, is in disgraceful contrast to the protection of its own activities, its own areas of potential fraud, such as social security. In particular I want to deal with the consequences of fraud in terms of the cost to the individual.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a lawyer friend who was involved in a lot of motor vehicle cases in which the plaintiff sued for damages for personal injuries allegedly sustained in collisions. The insurer, which was the defendant, contended that no accidents had, in fact, occurred. The defendant succeeded in its claim. I do not want to go into the nature of the cases, except to say that it was clearly self-evident that as most of the people seemed to be members of the same family, from the same racial group and the same country town in their country of origin, it was established to be quite clearly a fraud. This occurred in the Australian Capital Territory. As a result of this successful legal activity, the volume of fraudulent claims in the Australian Capital Territory has diminished massively. My lawyer friend has presented me with a table showing that back in 1984 compulsory third party insurance in the Australian Capital Territory cost $206 as against $150 in New South Wales. It mounted then in the Australian Capital Territory to $243 in 1986, still well ahead of New South Wales with $213. Since then in 1989 it has fallen from $243 to $155 in the Australian Capital Territory. In New South Wales it has gone up to $350, more than double the rate of 1984, while the Australian Capital Territory is $50 less than it was in 1984.

I am just dramatising what the impact of uncontrolled fraud basically has on an insurance premium of that order. This is so self-evident that it is depressing to see that this Government is making it harder and harder for insurance companies to protect themselves from the very clear evidence of widespread fraudulent activity which will proceed apace under this legislation without providing an effective counter to the insurance companies involved. For example, at common law an insurer was not obliged to meet fraudulent claims and the making of such a claim entitled the insurer to avoid the contract. That remains the position in other branches of contract law. Fraud in contract amounts at law to repudiation enabling the other party to treat the contract as being at an end, or at his election to continue to keep the contract on foot and sue for damages.

That principle, which extends to every other contract, has been overturned in this legislation in relation to these activities. This legislation further permits the courts to forgive the fraudulent claimant and allow him to recover against the insurer. What is the motive in this? Have we seen a justification for the overturning of this principle? The answer is, `No, we have not'. There has been no coherent argument to establish the need to turn such a principle on its head and the Government wonders why the Opposition is unhappy about this legislation. The Government wonders why almost every organisation that will have any contact with this legislation is enraged, disturbed and prompted to advertise in the paper to try to generate public concern about the way in which this Government, in its doctrinaire way, is proceeding with this matter. I find it fascinating that the Privacy Commissioner, in his annual report which was delivered to this place today, deals with this legislation by saying:
This development is significant for privacy protection in Australia in that it involves the first possible extension of the Privacy Act to cover a major private sector industry.

In other words, the Commissioner is saying that this is a very significant step. If it is such a significant step, why was the industry not properly consulted? Why have we got 40 last-minute amendments from the Government? Why is the whole industry objecting? It is objecting because this Government has botched it once again. It has not, in fact, established clearly any coherent case to overturn the traditions of the law. It has not established any coherent case for protecting the guilty at the expense of the innocent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Privacy Amendment Bill. This Hawke Labor Government, having tried only three years ago to inflict on us the Australian Card with its national database, is now trying to restore its civil liberties credentials with the Privacy Amendment Bill. That is a Bill that worries me greatly because of all the down sides that will affect not only business but also private individuals in Australia. This legislation can be described neither as a reform that will enhance privacy, nor even as a bit of meaningless pre-election window dressing; rather, it is a savage, ignorant attack on legitimate business practice, having an impact upon both business and the consumer. The only conclusion we can draw is that the Hawke Labor Government believes on the one hand that it is fine for governments and bureaucrats to amass data on Australians. Who can forget the outburst of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) when he declared that privacy was not really important because it was a bourgeois right concerned with private property? On the other hand, the Government dismissed the right of business to protect its property and assets by checking and monitoring the creditworthiness of those Australians who choose to apply for credit, goods, insurance and accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again this Labor Government demonstrated its lack of appreciation of business reality and its arrogance by holding minimal consultations with business prior to the introduction of the Bill in June. It is worth remembering that this Bill was introduced in the dying hours of the autumn session in June and here it is being debated on 21 December in the dying hours of the Budget session. It is a great tragedy that this Bill will not receive the due consideration that it is worthy of and it will be zoomed through the Senate because now, with undiminished arrogance, the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) tells the business community that his belated damage control of 41 amendments is as good as it is going to get. I think that is very sad because the business community and the people of Australia deserve better. An awful lot of patch-up work has been done that will not serve the community well.
Senate adjourned at 10.30 p.m.
